topic: Bill Nye The Science Guy Is Now A Married Man
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Bill Nye is celebrating his first month as a married man. The host of the long-running â€œBill Nye the Science Guyâ€ TV series tied the knot with journalist and author Liza Mundy in May, People confirmed Wednesday. The ceremony took place in the Enid A. Haupt Garden of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., and was officiated by â€œStar Trek: Voyagerâ€ actor Robert Picardo. Photos of the nuptials were taken by former White House photographer Pete Souza. The couple wrote their own vows, which one attendee described as â€œequal parts moving and comical.â€ Mundy, a former Washington Post reporter, mentioned Nyeâ€™s mother, cryptanalyst Jacqueline Jenkins-Nye, in her 2017 book, â€œCode Girls: The Untold Story of the American Women Code Breakers of World War II.â€ Nye emailed Mundy following the release of the book, and the two began dating shortly afterward. The pair have kept their relationship mostly private. Last week, they attended the premiere of Nyeâ€™s new Peacock series, â€œThe End Is Nye,â€ at the 2022 Tribeca Film Festival in New York. And in March, Mundy was by Nyeâ€™s side at the Captain Planet Foundationâ€™s 30th anniversary gala, a nonprofit organization in Atlanta. â€œThe End Is Nyeâ€ due out Aug. 25, will feature Nye as he explores â€œthe most epic global disasters imaginable â€• both natural and unnatural â€• and then demystifies them using science to show how we can survive, mitigate, and even prevent them,â€ according to press notes. The six-episode series will include guest appearances by Seth MacFarlane, who is also an executive producer. Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Martin Sheen Says He â€˜Regretsâ€™ Not Using His Real Name Professionally
content: Reporter, HuffPost Martin Sheen may be a household name, but the actor himself wishes you knew him by his real name. Sheen â€” the son of a Spanish immigrant father and Irish immigrant mother â€” was born with the name Ramon EstÃ©vez. In an interview with Closer Weekly published Monday, the â€œApocalypse Nowâ€ star said that he wishes he used his actual name when he was starting out as an actor. â€œThatâ€™s one of my regrets,â€ he told the magazine. â€œI never changed my name officially. Itâ€™s still Ramon EstÃ©vez on my birth certificate. Itâ€™s on my marriage license, my passport, driverâ€™s license.â€ He chalked up the decision of being naive when he first started in show business. â€œSometimes you get persuaded when you donâ€™t have enough insight or even enough courage to stand up for what you believe in, and you pay for it later,â€ he said. â€œBut, of course, Iâ€™m only speaking for myself.â€ He added that when his son, Emilio EstÃ©vez, first started acting professionally, he advised his son to stay true to his name. â€œThe only influence I had on Emilio was to keep his name,â€ Sheen told Closer. â€œWhen he started out, his agent was advising him to change his name to Sheen and he wouldnâ€™t do it. And I thank God he didnâ€™t.â€ Sheenâ€™s other famous son, Charlie Sheen, didnâ€™t take the same advice â€” initially. In 2013, he was credited in Robert Rodriguezâ€˜s film â€œMachete Killsâ€ by his real name, Carlos EstÃ©vez, in the title cards. But in 2017â€™s â€œMad Families,â€ Charlie Sheen was credited by his professional name. Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Brad Pitt Gets Conned Into Hunting For Fake Buried Treasure At His French Mansion
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost In a stunning rebuke of todayâ€™s relatable celebrity culture, Brad Pitt revealed he spent a year hunting for buried medieval treasure that never existed beneath his French estate. Yes, for some reason the Oscar winner chose to come clean about getting swindled by an unnamed man who convinced him that the property he once shared with ex-wife Angelina Jolie was even more valuable than the estimated $60 million the former couple forked over for it back in 2008. Speaking with GQ in a profile published on Wednesday, Pitt said he was told that there were â€œmillions of dollars worth of goldâ€ left by the villaâ€™s medieval owners that had been â€œtaken from the Levant during the Crusades and buried on the grounds.â€ â€œI got obsessed,â€ said Pitt, who acquired radar equipment to hunt for the loot. â€œLike for a year, this was all I could think about, just the excitement of it all. Maybe it has something to do with where I grew up, because in the Ozark Mountainsâ€ near his childhood home in Missouri, â€œthere were always stories of hidden caches of gold.â€ Ultimately, Pitt came up empty, and it was revealed that the man had targeted him as a potential investor in a radar company and (successfully) pitched the prospect of undiscovered riches to dupe the actor. Pitt said the ordeal left him feeling â€œpretty foolish in the end.â€ â€œIt was just the hunt that was exciting,â€ he remarked. Despite the slightly embarrassing admission, there are grounds to believe buried treasure may lay beneath the historic villa. Pittâ€™s ChÃ¢teau Miraval sits along an ancient Roman trade route and contains a sprawling estate and various structures, including the 13th-century chapel where he and Jolie wed. The chÃ¢teau and its award-winning wine from the propertyâ€™s vineyards have since become a major source of contention in the former coupleâ€™s ongoing divorce battle. After Jolie sold her stake in the business last year to Russian billionaire Yuri Shefler, Pitt sued her in February, claiming she unlawfully disregarded their agreement never to sell their shares without the otherâ€™s permission. In a filing from Pittâ€™s legal team earlier this month, the actor claims Jolie â€œsought to inflict harm onâ€ him by forcing him to partner with â€œa stranger with poisonous associations and intentionsâ€ who plans to launch a â€œhostileâ€ takeover of the business. Jolie hasnâ€™t commented on Pittâ€™s allegations or his hunt for fake treasure. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: James Rado, Co-Creator Of Groundbreaking Musical â€˜Hair,â€™ Dead At 90
content: NEW YORK (AP) â€” James Rado, co-creator of the groundbreaking hippie musical â€œHair,â€ which celebrated protest, pot and free love and paved the way for the sound of rock on Broadway, has died. He was 90. Rado died Tuesday night in New York City of cardio respiratory arrest, according to friend and publicist Merle Frimark. â€œHair,â€ which has a story and lyrics by Rado and Gerome Ragni and music by Galt MacDermot, was the first rock musical on Broadway, the first Broadway show to feature full nudity and the first to feature a same-sex kiss. â€œHairâ€ made possible other rock musicals like â€œJesus Christ Superstarâ€ and â€œRent.â€ Like â€œHamilton,â€ it was one of only a handful of Broadway shows in the past few decades to find its songs on the pop charts. The so-called â€œAmerican tribal love-rock musical,â€ had its world premiere at the Public Theater in New York Cityâ€™s East Village in 1967 and transferred the following year to Broadway, where the musical ran more than 1,800 performances. Rado played Claude, a young man about to be drafted and sent to the war in Vietnam. Clive Barnes, theater critic for The New York Times, called the show â€œthe first Broadway musical in some time to have the authentic voice of today rather than the day before yesterday.â€ The New York Post said it had â€œunintentional charm,â€ contagious high spirits and a â€œyoung zestfulnessâ€ that â€œmake it difficult to resist.â€ Variety, however, called it â€œloony.â€ It lost the Tony in 1969 to the more traditional â€œ1776â€ but won a Grammy Award. The 2009 revival won the best revival Tony. The show was revived on Broadway in 1977 and again in 2009. It was made into a movie directed by Milos Forman in 1979 starring Treat Williams and Beverly Dâ€™Angelo. â€œHairâ€ spawned four top four singles on the American pop charts, including the No. 1 hit â€œAquarius/Let the Sunshine Inâ€ by the Fifth Dimension, which won the Grammy Award for record of the year and best pop vocal performance by a group in 1970. Others included â€œHairâ€ by the Cowsills, â€œGood Morning, Starshineâ€ by the singer Oliver and â€œEasy to Be Hardâ€ by Three Dog Night. The cast album itself stayed at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 for 13 weeks â€œHairâ€ tells the story of Claude and Berger, best buddies who find freedom in the late 1960s. Between draft-card burnings, love-ins, bad LSD trips and a parade of protest marches, the two wander through a New York filled with flower children, drugged-out hippies and outraged tourists who donâ€™t approve of the wild goings-on. In one song, Claude poignantly sings, â€œWhy do I live, why do I die, tell me where do I go, tell me why.â€ The show is playful and chaotic, but thereâ€™s also a sense of outrage in its protests against war, racism, sexism, pollution and the general hypocrisy of an era dominated by the American involvement in Vietnam. â€œIâ€™d still like â€˜Hairâ€™ to be about what it was about then,â€ Rado told The Associated Press in 1993. â€œâ€˜Hairâ€™ had a spiritual message, and it has a mystical message I hope is coming through â€” thereâ€™s more to life than the way itâ€™s been devised for us, explained to us, taught to us.â€ The songs of â€œHairâ€ have been used in everything from the films â€œForrest Gump,â€ â€œMinionsâ€ and â€œThe 40-Year-Old Virginâ€ to TV shows like â€œGlee,â€ â€œSo You Think You Can Danceâ€ and â€œMy Name Is Earl.â€ Billboard magazine lists â€œAquarius/Let the Sunshine Inâ€ at No. 66 of all-time top 100 songs. In 2019, the original 1968 Broadway cast recording was inducted into the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress. Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden deemed â€œthese aural treasures worthy of preservation because of their cultural, historic and aesthetic importance to the nationâ€™s recorded sound heritage.â€ Rado was born in Venice, California, and raised in Rochester, New York, and Washington, D.C. After serving two years in the U.S. Navy, he moved to New York and studied acting with Paula and Lee Strasberg. Rado was part of the ensemble of the Broadway play â€œMarathon â€™33â€ in 1963 and played Richard Lionheart in â€œThe Lion in Winterâ€ in 1966 opposite Christopher Walken. He met Ragni when he was cast in the off-Broadway musical â€œHang Down Your Head and Die.â€ The two were interested in birthing a new kind of show and focused on the hippie scene. They wrote the script while sharing an apartment in Hoboken, New Jersey. Rado originated the â€œHairâ€ role of the draftee Claude on Broadway. â€œHairâ€ met resistance across the country. In addition to the use of four-letter words, the flouting of authority, sexual references and gross-out humor, the end of Act 1 had the entire cast strip naked to â€œWhere Do I Goâ€ and there was what many believed was desecration of the American flag. There were church pickets in Evansville, Indiana. Municipal officials in Chattanooga, Tennessee, denied a request to stage the show, determining that it would not be â€œin the best interest of the community.â€ In Denver, police threatened to arrest anyone who appeared nude onstage. A Boston visit was challenged in court on the basis of flag desecration. The original Public Theater production had cut the nude scene, but the creators wanted it back for the Broadway debut. Under the law at that time, New York City allowed nudity onstage onstage as long as the actors werenâ€™t moving, which is why the whole cast of â€œHairâ€ stood together in a row, nude and perfectly still. After â€œHair,â€ Rado wrote the music and lyrics of the off-Broadway show â€œRainbow,â€ co-authoring the book with his brother, Ted Rado. He later teamed up with Ragni to create the book and lyrics for the show â€œSun.â€ Ragni died in 1991. Rado wrote a new show called â€œAmerican Soldierâ€ with his brother. In 2009, Rado, MacDermot and Ragni were inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame. Marilyn McCoo and Billy Davis Jr., of the group The Fifth Dimension, were joined onstage by the Broadway cast at the time for a finale that brought the ceremonyâ€™s approximately 1,000 guests to their feet. MacDermot died in 2018. Rado told the Hudson Reporter in 2009 that none of the showâ€™s creators anticipated that it would have such an enormous impact. â€œWe thought weâ€™d stumbled on a great idea, and something that potentially could be a hit on Broadway, never thinking of the distant future.â€ He is survived by his brother Ted Rado, sister-in-law Kay Rado, nieces Melanie Khoury, Emily DiBona and Melissa Stuart, great-nieces and a great-nephew. ___ Mark Kennedy is at http://twitter.com/KennedyTwits

topic: David Muir Swiftly Shuts Down Chris Christie After His Jan. 6 Comparison
content: ABC News anchor David Muir shut down Chris Christieâ€™s attempt to compare the 2000 and 2016 presidential election results with the GOP-backed attempt to overturn the electoral vote count on Jan. 6, 2021. Muir, during the networkâ€™s coverage of the Jan. 6 committee hearings on Tuesday, pointed out that Republicans across the country are running campaigns based on claims of a â€œfaultyâ€ 2020 presidential election. Christie, a former New Jersey governor who headed Donald Trumpâ€™s presidential transition team, claimed former Secretary of State Hilary Clinton in 2016 and supporters of then-Vice President Al Gore in 2000 refused to accept the â€œlegitimateâ€ results of their presidential defeats long before Jan. 6. Clinton conceded following the 2016 election and Gore acknowledged his 2000 loss after a Florida recount battle. â€œThis is a very dangerous thing in this country, which was brought to a new level in 2020 by Donald Trump and his campaign,â€ Christie said. Muir interrupted. â€œI just donâ€™t want our audience to think Iâ€™m not aware that there isnâ€™t a real equivalency here when you have a former president who is sowing seeds of doubt,â€ Muir said. You can watch the moment Muir cuts Christie off below. ABC News anchor David Muir pushes back against Chris Christie for equating the 2000 election between Gore and Bush to the Jan. 6 insurrection."I just don't want our audience thinking there is a real equivalency here when you have a former president who is sowing seeds of doubt" pic.twitter.com/7wNtQMIfUK

topic: Fox News Anchor Calls Out 'Stunning' Lack Of Evidence For Trump Election Fraud Claim
content:
General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Fox News anchor Martha MacCallum on Tuesday called out the â€œstunningâ€ absence of proof to support Donald Trumpâ€™s election-fraud claims during the latest hearing on the Jan. 6, 2021 attack, The Hill reported. MacCallum said a rift among Republicans over whether to buy into the former presidentâ€™s continued allegations of cheating will be exploited by the Democratic-dominated House panel investigating the Capitol riot, according to the news outlet. â€œThe lack of evidence is the huge stunning clear moment here where these people are saying, â€˜Look I supported you, please give me something to work with,â€™ and it simply doesnâ€™t materialize,â€ MacCallum said, per The Hill. Arizona Republican House Speaker Rusty Bowers testified Tuesday that Trump and his lawyers pressured him to overturn President Joe Bidenâ€™s victory in the state. â€œThere was no â€• no evidence being presented of any strength ... anything that would say to me, â€˜You have a doubt. Deny your oath.â€™ I will not do that,â€ Bowers said of Trumpâ€™s fraud claims. Trump in May accused Fox News, which amplified Trumpâ€™s lies about the 2020 results and got sued for it, of failing to spread his falsehoods. He said it decreased the conservative channelâ€™s ratings. â€œThatâ€™s the one subject they donâ€™t want to talk about,â€ the ex-president said. McCallum on Tuesday said the hearings could influence Trumpâ€™s decision on whether to run in 2024. â€œWe never wanna see what we saw happen on Jan. 6 at the Capitol ever happen again,â€ she added. General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Andrew Gillum, Former Candidate For Florida Governor, Facing Federal Charges
content:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) â€” Andrew Gillum, the 2018 Democratic nominee for Florida governor, is facing 21 federal charges related to a scheme to seek donations and funnel a portion of them back to him through third parties, the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office announced Wednesday. Gillum, 42, and co-defendant Janet Lettman-Hicks, 53, face 19 counts of wire fraud. Gillum is also charged with making false statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office said the pair â€œconspired to commit wire fraud, by unlawfully soliciting and obtaining funds from various entities and individuals through false and fraudulent promises and representations that the funds would be used for a legitimate purpose.â€ Lettman-Hicks then used her company to fraudulently give money to Gillum disguised as payroll payments, the office said in a press release. Itâ€™s the latest trouble for Gillum, who narrowly lost to Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis in a race that required a recount. Gillum served as mayor of Tallahassee before running for governor. In March 2020, Gillum was found intoxicated and unconscious in a hotel room with two men, including one who works as a male escort. Two days later he entered a rehabilitation center, and later did a television interview and said heâ€™s bisexual. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Newt Gingrich's Kamala Harris Insult Barrage Might Be Beneath Even Him
content:
General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Far-right pot-stirrer Newt Gingrich mocked Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ qualifications to be president on Fox News Tuesday. (Watch the video below.) The former House speaker, a guest on â€œJesse Watters Primetime,â€ launched a dismissive, demeaning and somewhat racist broadside against the veep, frequently mentioned as a possible Democratic successor to President Joe Biden. Gingrich attacked her intelligence and called her a prospect â€œcrazy enough to satisfy the leftâ€ who checks the box of â€œbeing a woman of color.â€ â€œShe doesnâ€™t know anything, she doesnâ€™t know how to learn anything, sheâ€™s inarticulate, and sheâ€™s not sure what the big words mean anyway,â€ he said. Gingrich previously said Harris â€œmay be the dumbest person ever elected vice president in American history.â€ If Biden doesnâ€™t seek reelection, Harris would be the leading Democratic candidate to replace him by a fairly wide margin, according to a recent poll. Biden has said he intends to stand for reelection, especially if Donald Trump runs. Gingrich called the prospect of Harris assuming the presidency under â€œterribleâ€ circumstances â€œhorrifying.â€ She would â€œachieve worst president in American history, I think, within 30 days,â€ Gingrich said. H/T Media Matters General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Baltimore Ravens Linebacker Jaylon Ferguson Dies At Age 26
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Jaylon Ferguson, a linebacker for the Baltimore Ravens who played in 10 games last season, has died. He was 26. â€œWe are profoundly saddened by the tragic passing of Jaylon Ferguson,â€ the team said in a statement on Wednesday. â€œHe was a kind, respectful young man with a big smile and infectious personality. We express our heartfelt condolences to Jaylonâ€™s family and friends as we mourn a life lost much too soon.â€ Ferguson, a father of three young children with fiancÃ©e Doni Smith, was due to report to training camp for his fourth season in late July. He practiced last week with the Ravens at a minicamp where he sprained his ankle, the Baltimore Sun reported. Police found an unresponsive Ferguson being tended to by medics in Baltimore Tuesday night and told the newspaper there was no initial indication of â€œtrauma or foul play.â€ The cause of death has not yet been determined. Ferguson played all three of his NFL seasons with the Ravens, appearing in 38 games. The Ravens made him a third-round pick out of Louisiana Tech in 2019. â€œThe last person I talked to leaving the facility,â€ Ravens linebacker Patrick Queen tweeted. â€œSpent almost everyday in the sauna together tryna see who gone last longer. Said it was our turn this year man. Ima miss you bro.â€ Fergusonâ€™s agent, Safarrah Lawson, said in a statement shared by ESPN: â€œHe will be remembered not just as a football player, but as a great father, son, brother and friend.â€ General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Sen. Ron Johnson Caught Faking Phone Call To Avoid Fake Elector Questions
content:
National Reporter, HuffPost Facing searing questions about the revelation he tried to give false election documents to then-Vice President Mike Pence, Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) opted to fake a phone call. He got caught doing that, too. NBC News reporter Frank Thorp V spotted the Wisconsin Republican as he left the Capitol building Tuesday. Earlier that day, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol aired damning texts sent by Johnsonâ€™s chief of staff, Sean Riley, to a Pence staffer saying the senator wanted to hand the vice president an â€[a]lternate slate of electorsâ€ â€• the fake election documents used to push the idea that former President Donald Trump won in states he actually lost. â€œHow much did you know about what your chief of staff was doing with the alternate slates of electors?â€ Thorp asked Johnson, as captured in a video of the encounter. â€œIâ€™m on the phone right now,â€ Johnson said, pointing to the device and dismissively waving Thorp away. â€œNo youâ€™re not,â€ Thorp replied. â€œI can see your phone. I can see your screen.â€ Sen. Ron Johnson so much didn't want to talk to reporters about his office trying to pass fake elector lists to the vice president's office that he tried to pretend he was on the phone. pic.twitter.com/V1VwBDs42t Caught in the act, Johnson nevertheless continued the ruse, holding the phone to his ear in a one-sided, silent conversation with no one. After 30 awkward seconds, the senator put his phone down â€• still having not uttered a word into it â€• to tell reporters the apparent bombshell is â€œa complete non-story.â€ â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re even concerned about here,â€ he said. Johnson denied any knowledge of what transpired between his chief of staff and Mike Penceâ€™s staff, saying he had no idea the falsified election documents had â€œeven been delivered to us.â€ National Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Watch Lebanese Dance Troupe Unleash The Artistry of Arab Women On 'AGT'
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost The Mayyas dance troupe set out to â€œprove to the world what Arab women can do, the arts we can create,â€ one member said on Tuesdayâ€™s â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talent.â€ (Watch the video below.) Mission accomplished. The Lebanese troupe amazed the panelists and audience with coordinated arm movements that generated a kaleidoscopic vibe and a creature-like illusion. The routine delivered on Mayyasâ€™ promise to â€œhypnotize.â€ The same performer said earlier in the segment that â€œbeing a dancer as a female Arab is not fully supported yetâ€ â€• but Simon Cowell said the groupâ€™s performance will make a difference. He called them â€œarguably the best dance act.â€ Judge Sofia Vergara gave perhaps the highest compliment, pushing the Golden Buzzer to vault the team to the live rounds. The former â€œModern Familyâ€ star told the group she was â€œso honored to empower you even more.â€ General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Tom Hanks Reveals Why He Canâ€™t Stop Crashing His Fansâ€™ Weddings
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Tom Hanks shared on Tuesdayâ€™s â€œLate Night with Seth Meyersâ€ why in recent years heâ€™s become a serial wedding crasher at his fansâ€™ weddings, whether heâ€™s â€œinvited or not.â€ The â€œElvisâ€ actor, who loves to hilariously photobomb his supporters on their big day, revealed why he has a passion for wedding crashing. â€œItâ€™s my ego, unchecked,â€ Hanks said jokingly. He added: â€œI just canâ€™t help but think, â€˜What would these people like more than anything else to remember this magic day of days? Oh, I know, me!â€™â€ In March, Hanks stunned a bride when he united with her bridal party outside of a hotel in downtown Pittsburgh to take photos. The group was preparing to leave the venue when the longtime actor pulled up to join in on the snapshot session. The bride, Grace Gwaltney, shared that she was blown away to see the star. â€œHe was like, â€˜Hey! Iâ€™m Tom Hanks. I would love to get a photo with you,â€™ and I immediately froze and was just looking around,â€ Gwaltney told KCRA at the time. â€œI didnâ€™t know what to do.â€ Hanks, who was declared a â€œman of many hatsâ€ by the showâ€™s host, has crashed so many weddings that Meyers showcased the actorâ€™s best wedding-crasher moments during the episode, with some clips even dating back to the early 2000s. The movie heavyweight also explained the time he took his affinity for wedding crashing internationally, after he stumbled upon a brideâ€™s wedding while filming 2009â€™s â€œAngels and Demonsâ€ in Rome. Hanks told Meyers that the set crew wasnâ€™t privy that a wedding party had booked the venue they were filming in, the Pantheon, on the same day. â€œThis limousine pulled up, and it was the bride and the groom trying to â€˜get me to the church on time,â€™â€ Hanks said. â€œAnd they couldnâ€™t do it because we had all this stuff going on.â€ â€œIt was like â€˜Uh, how do we fix this?â€™ So, like a stalker â€” you know, â€˜Hey miss, miss, miss!â€™ â€” I knocked on the window, I said â€˜Hey listen, we have a thing, but would you do me the honor of escorting you to your bridal altar?â€™ So we did it!â€ the actor recalled. Hanks then joked to Meyers that the couple may not have initially recognized him at the time due to his â€œchemically straightened hair,â€ he said, pointing to his hairstyle in the throwback photo from the ceremony. â€œI donâ€™t like to think I crashed a wedding. I provided a service,â€ the leading man added. â€œElvis,â€ in which Hanks plays manager to the rock â€˜nâ€™ roll icon, hits theaters on Friday. Watch the trailer below. Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Stephen Colbert Spots Trump's Most 'Pathetic' Moment Yet
content: Overnight Editor, HuffPost Stephen Colbert spotted a revealing moment for Donald Trump â€• one the â€œLate Showâ€ host said proves just how â€œpatheticâ€ the former president truly is. In new audio played during Tuesdayâ€™s Jan. 6 committee hearings, Trump pressured Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger to overturn the results of the 2020 election. â€œI only need 11,000 votes,â€ Trump said during the phone call after the election. â€œFellas, I need 11,000 votes, give me a break.â€ â€œThat is just pathetic,â€ Colbert said after airing the audio. â€œHeâ€™s literally begging them to invent votes for him. Itâ€™s like watching an old man try to mooch an extra pancake at the Dennyâ€™s.â€ See more in Colbertâ€™s Tuesday night monologue: Overnight Editor, HuffPost

topic: Kim Kardashian Reveals How She Knew When To Introduce Pete Davidson To Her Kids
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Kim Kardashian revealed that she relied on the advice of one of her sisters when it came to figuring out the right time to introduce her boyfriend, Pete Davidson, to her four children. The SKKN by Kim founder, who shares North, Saint, Chicago and Psalm with her ex Kanye West, spoke to Hoda Kotb and Savannah Guthrie on â€œTodayâ€  Tuesday about why she decided to wait six months for the big meeting. â€œLuckily I have a sister that has been through it all, and we talked about it,â€ Kardashian said, seemingly referencing her older sister, Kourtney, who has navigated co-parenting with her ex, Scott Disick, over the years. â€œI consulted with a few therapists and friends that have been through it,â€ the reality star added. â€œI definitely wanted to wait six months. And that was the marker.â€ But in her mind, there isnâ€™t a perfect formula for navigating new relationships with kids. â€œI think itâ€™s different for everyone,â€ Kardashian explained. â€œDifferent things work for different people, but you just have to do what feels right and try to be as respectful and cautious as possible.â€ Kotb and Guthrie also asked the Skims creator if her new relationship with the former â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ star took her â€œby surprise.â€ â€œIt did,â€ Kardashian answered with a smile, but said that she also â€œwaited a whileâ€ before jumping into something new. â€œI waited, like, a good 10 months before I was ready to open myself up,â€ she said. â€œAnd I think you definitely need that time to yourself. And then once youâ€™re ready to get out there, I felt like I just wanted new energy and something different. And it definitely took me by surprise.â€ Kardashian spoke about the difficulties both she and her family faced during her marriage to West, who now goes by Ye, on a recent episode of the Kardashianâ€™s Hulu reality show. â€œI do recognize the impact that my relationship has had on my family and that Iâ€™ve never had the opportunity to just say, â€˜Iâ€™m sorry, guys,â€™â€ Kardashian said during the episode, which aired in May. â€œI canâ€™t control how he treats me or how he has always treated you guys,â€ she added. â€œI protected that for so long, but I said, â€˜I will never let that happen to you guys again.â€™ For once in my life, I feel strong. I am not going to let anyone treat you guys a way or myself.â€ Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Elliot Page Says Life Has 'Drastically' Improved Since Coming Out As Trans
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Life has only gotten better for Elliot Page since coming out as transgender. The â€œUmbrella Academyâ€ star opened up about feeling a â€œdegree of joyâ€ he never thought possible on Tuesdayâ€™s episode of â€œLate Night With Seth Meyers,â€ sharing that heâ€™s learned to tune out peopleâ€™s negative reactions. â€œItâ€™s improved my life drastically,â€ Page said about transitioning. â€œI hope, you know, I hope maybe people who do have an issue with me can maybe try and hear that, or embrace that on some level.â€ â€œWhat I want to focus on right now and has been so extraordinary is the degree of joy that I feel, the degree of presence that I feel,â€ he added. â€œI feel a way that I really never thought possible for a long, long time.â€ While Pageâ€™s loved ones have been supportive, the actor has previously spoken about the â€œhatred and crueltyâ€ heâ€™s received since publicly disclosing that he is a transgender man in late 2020, including being verbally accosted by a stranger on the street. Page said certain â€œmoments can be overwhelming,â€ but heâ€™s choosing to concentrate on the positive, despite the spate of anti-trans bills that are rolling out across the nation. â€œI feel like itâ€™s one of those things where itâ€™s so unfortunate because itâ€™s like, weâ€™re all on the same team here, you know?â€ he told Meyers, adding that everybody faces â€œlimits and constraints because of peopleâ€™s obsession with the binaryâ€ regardless of their gender identity. The actor added, â€œTo me, itâ€™d be so special for us to all be able to connect and talk about how similar we are in all of our journeys.â€ Ultimately, Page said transitioning â€œmade me betterâ€ both as a person and as an actor. Mirroring Pageâ€™s own real-life experience, his character on Netflixâ€™s superhero series â€œUmbrella Academy,â€ who previously presented as female, comes out as transgender in the new season, which premiered on Wednesday. The characterâ€™s transition has drawn praise from fans and critics alike with Page explaining that showrunner Steve Blackman was â€œreally excited about incorporating it into the showâ€ and remarking that he feels â€œproud of it and excited for people to see it.â€ â€œItâ€™s a beautiful thing to experience now,â€ Page said. â€œBecause a lot of the time my life was just trying to move forward, so getting to embrace the experience as much as I get to now, I think itâ€™s made me better in so many facets. As a person, as a friend, relationships.â€ Page plans to release a memoir next year about his journey. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Trey Anastasio Fans Blown Away When 7-Year-Old Joins Him On Stage For 'Bug'
content: Overnight Editor, HuffPost Phish frontman Trey Anastasio received some unexpected help during a solo show in Michigan on Monday when he spotted a 7-year-old girl in the audience with a sign asking: â€œCan I sing Bug with u?â€ According to Relix, Anastasio asked the young fanâ€™s mother if she could do exactly that. Then, Jovi Crusen delivered an unforgettable rendition of the song from the 2000 Phish album â€œFarmhouse.â€ She had the audience cheering â€• and Anastasio grinning from ear to ear: â€œI wasnâ€™t nervous but I had to take a big breath just to keep the tears away,â€ Jovi told the JamBase website. â€œI like â€˜Bugâ€™ because I get to raise my voice and sometimes yell â€˜Bug!â€™ Itâ€™s fun to sing.â€ Hereâ€™s the original for comparison: Overnight Editor, HuffPost

topic: Bill Nye The Science Guy Is Now A Married Man
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Bill Nye is celebrating his first month as a married man. The host of the long-running â€œBill Nye the Science Guyâ€ TV series tied the knot with journalist and author Liza Mundy in May, People confirmed Wednesday. The ceremony took place in the Enid A. Haupt Garden of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., and was officiated by â€œStar Trek: Voyagerâ€ actor Robert Picardo. Photos of the nuptials were taken by former White House photographer Pete Souza. The couple wrote their own vows, which one attendee described as â€œequal parts moving and comical.â€ Mundy, a former Washington Post reporter, mentioned Nyeâ€™s mother, cryptanalyst Jacqueline Jenkins-Nye, in her 2017 book, â€œCode Girls: The Untold Story of the American Women Code Breakers of World War II.â€ Nye emailed Mundy following the release of the book, and the two began dating shortly afterward. The pair have kept their relationship mostly private. Last week, they attended the premiere of Nyeâ€™s new Peacock series, â€œThe End Is Nye,â€ at the 2022 Tribeca Film Festival in New York. And in March, Mundy was by Nyeâ€™s side at the Captain Planet Foundationâ€™s 30th anniversary gala, a nonprofit organization in Atlanta. â€œThe End Is Nyeâ€ due out Aug. 25, will feature Nye as he explores â€œthe most epic global disasters imaginable â€• both natural and unnatural â€• and then demystifies them using science to show how we can survive, mitigate, and even prevent them,â€ according to press notes. The six-episode series will include guest appearances by Seth MacFarlane, who is also an executive producer. Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Martin Sheen Says He â€˜Regretsâ€™ Not Using His Real Name Professionally
content: Reporter, HuffPost Martin Sheen may be a household name, but the actor himself wishes you knew him by his real name. Sheen â€” the son of a Spanish immigrant father and Irish immigrant mother â€” was born with the name Ramon EstÃ©vez. In an interview with Closer Weekly published Monday, the â€œApocalypse Nowâ€ star said that he wishes he used his actual name when he was starting out as an actor. â€œThatâ€™s one of my regrets,â€ he told the magazine. â€œI never changed my name officially. Itâ€™s still Ramon EstÃ©vez on my birth certificate. Itâ€™s on my marriage license, my passport, driverâ€™s license.â€ He chalked up the decision of being naive when he first started in show business. â€œSometimes you get persuaded when you donâ€™t have enough insight or even enough courage to stand up for what you believe in, and you pay for it later,â€ he said. â€œBut, of course, Iâ€™m only speaking for myself.â€ He added that when his son, Emilio EstÃ©vez, first started acting professionally, he advised his son to stay true to his name. â€œThe only influence I had on Emilio was to keep his name,â€ Sheen told Closer. â€œWhen he started out, his agent was advising him to change his name to Sheen and he wouldnâ€™t do it. And I thank God he didnâ€™t.â€ Sheenâ€™s other famous son, Charlie Sheen, didnâ€™t take the same advice â€” initially. In 2013, he was credited in Robert Rodriguezâ€˜s film â€œMachete Killsâ€ by his real name, Carlos EstÃ©vez, in the title cards. But in 2017â€™s â€œMad Families,â€ Charlie Sheen was credited by his professional name. Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Gloria Estefan Shades Jennifer Lopez Over Super Bowl Halftime Comments
content: Reporter, HuffPost Gloriaâ€™s gonna get you. Gloria Estefan had no qualms about poking a little fun at actor-singer Jennifer Lopez during an episode of â€œWatch What Happens Live With Andy Cohenâ€ on Tuesday. During one segment, Cohen asked the Cuban American icon what she thought about the comments Lopez made about the 2020 Super Bowl halftime show, in which she performed with Colombian singer Shakira. In her Netflix documentary â€œHalftime,â€ Lopez complained about the time constraints of having to share the stage, calling it â€œthe worst idea in the world.â€ In response, Estefan told Cohen that she was asked to join Lopez and Shakira on the Super Bowl stage but rejected the offer. â€œLook, this is the bottom line. You have very little time, like 12 minutes or something, to get things on and off the set,â€ Estefan explained. â€œSo, could you do it with one person? Yes, but I think they wanted to throw a Miami and Latin extravaganza, and they tried to pack it as much as possible.â€ And although Estefan said that the women â€œkilled itâ€ and that it was an â€œamazing show,â€ the â€œRhythm Is Gonna Get Youâ€ singer also took the opportunity to throw a little shade at Lopez. â€œOK, and imagine what J.Lo would have said if I was the third [performer]!â€ Estefan said, bugging out her eyes. â€œI literally would come out, done â€˜come on shake your body,â€™ out!â€ Estefan joked, referring to the lyrics of her 1985 Miami Sound Machine hit, â€œConga!â€ Estefan then added that sheâ€™s performed at a few Super Bowls and that Lopez and Shakiraâ€™s show was â€œtheir momentâ€ to shine. â€œPlus, I didnâ€™t want to go on a diet in December,â€ Estefan said. â€œItâ€™s Christmas!â€ Lopezâ€™s complaints about her Super Bowl performance in â€œHalftimeâ€ werenâ€™t directed at Shakira but at the NFL. Lopezâ€™s manager Benny Medina shared his clientâ€™s frustrations over the NFLâ€™s choice of a co-headlining performance. â€œTypically, you have one headliner at a Super Bowl. That headliner constructs a show, and, should they choose to have other guests, thatâ€™s their choice,â€ he said, according to Entertainment Weekly. â€œIt was an insult to say you needed two Latinas to do the job that one artist historically has done.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Watch Lebanese Dance Troupe Unleash The Artistry of Arab Women On 'AGT'
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost The Mayyas dance troupe set out to â€œprove to the world what Arab women can do, the arts we can create,â€ one member said on Tuesdayâ€™s â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talent.â€ (Watch the video below.) Mission accomplished. The Lebanese troupe amazed the panelists and audience with coordinated arm movements that generated a kaleidoscopic vibe and a creature-like illusion. The routine delivered on Mayyasâ€™ promise to â€œhypnotize.â€ The same performer said earlier in the segment that â€œbeing a dancer as a female Arab is not fully supported yetâ€ â€• but Simon Cowell said the groupâ€™s performance will make a difference. He called them â€œarguably the best dance act.â€ Judge Sofia Vergara gave perhaps the highest compliment, pushing the Golden Buzzer to vault the team to the live rounds. The former â€œModern Familyâ€ star told the group she was â€œso honored to empower you even more.â€ General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Herschel Walker Says There Are 52 States
content:
Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost There are 50 states in the United States of America. But in an interview Tuesday, Georgia GOP Senate candidate Herschel Walker said there were 52. Walker was going after Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor, for recently saying, â€œI am tired of hearing about [Georgia] being the best state in the country to do business when we are the worst state in the country to live.â€ Abrams cited the stateâ€™s problems with mental health treatment, maternal mortality, incarceration rates and wages. Republicans seized upon the remark and used it to criticize her, although Abrams said she stood by her belief that Republican Brian Kemp is â€œa failed governor, who doesnâ€™t care about the people of Georgia.â€ In an interview Tuesday with the Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show, Walker said Abrams should go live in another state â€• saying she had 51 others from which to choose. â€œIf you donâ€™t believe in the country, leave and go somewhere else,â€ he said. â€œIf itâ€™s the worst state, why are you here? Why donâ€™t you leave â€• go to another? Thereâ€™s, what, 51 more other states that you can go to?â€ â€œHerschel misspoke â€• he obviously knows there are 50 states,â€ spokeswoman Mallory Blount told HuffPost. Walker is a former NFL star whose campaign has been filled with controversies and misstatements. He has faced domestic violence allegations, and recently, claims of being an absent father. Walker has talked frequently about his 22-year-old son Christian and railed against fatherless homes. But The Daily Beast reported that Walker actually has three other children he doesnâ€™t talk about publicly. He has since acknowledged his four children, saying he â€œnever denied any of my kids.â€ Walker has also said heâ€™s skeptical of evolution, pointing to the fact that apes and humans coexist. â€œAt one time, science said man came from apes, did it not? ... If that is true, why are there still apes? Think about it,â€ Walker said in March. After the massacre in Uvalde, Texas, Walker called for â€œa department that can look at young men thatâ€™s looking at women thatâ€™s looking at social media,â€ as a solution to curb school shootings, but it was not clear what that was or how it would solve the problem. In 2008, then-candidate Barack Obama also misspoke on the number of states. â€œIt is wonderful to be back in Oregon,â€ Obama said. â€œOver the last 15 months, weâ€™ve traveled to every corner of the United States. Iâ€™ve now been in 57 states? I think one left to go. Alaska and Hawaii, I was not allowed to go to even though I really wanted to visit, but my staff would not justify it.â€ He later said it was â€œa sign that my numeracy is getting a little, uh â€•â€ before an aide cut him off. Some on took this comment as further proof of the birther conspiracy, claiming that he was actually referencing Muslim countries. Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Sen. Ron Johnson Caught Faking Phone Call To Avoid Fake Elector Questions
content:
National Reporter, HuffPost Facing searing questions about the revelation he tried to give false election documents to then-Vice President Mike Pence, Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) opted to fake a phone call. He got caught doing that, too. NBC News reporter Frank Thorp V spotted the Wisconsin Republican as he left the Capitol building Tuesday. Earlier that day, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol aired damning texts sent by Johnsonâ€™s chief of staff, Sean Riley, to a Pence staffer saying the senator wanted to hand the vice president an â€[a]lternate slate of electorsâ€ â€• the fake election documents used to push the idea that former President Donald Trump won in states he actually lost. â€œHow much did you know about what your chief of staff was doing with the alternate slates of electors?â€ Thorp asked Johnson, as captured in a video of the encounter. â€œIâ€™m on the phone right now,â€ Johnson said, pointing to the device and dismissively waving Thorp away. â€œNo youâ€™re not,â€ Thorp replied. â€œI can see your phone. I can see your screen.â€ Sen. Ron Johnson so much didn't want to talk to reporters about his office trying to pass fake elector lists to the vice president's office that he tried to pretend he was on the phone. pic.twitter.com/V1VwBDs42t Caught in the act, Johnson nevertheless continued the ruse, holding the phone to his ear in a one-sided, silent conversation with no one. After 30 awkward seconds, the senator put his phone down â€• still having not uttered a word into it â€• to tell reporters the apparent bombshell is â€œa complete non-story.â€ â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re even concerned about here,â€ he said. Johnson denied any knowledge of what transpired between his chief of staff and Mike Penceâ€™s staff, saying he had no idea the falsified election documents had â€œeven been delivered to us.â€ National Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Andrew Gillum, Former Candidate For Florida Governor, Facing Federal Charges
content:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) â€” Andrew Gillum, the 2018 Democratic nominee for Florida governor, is facing 21 federal charges related to a scheme to seek donations and funnel a portion of them back to him through third parties, the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office announced Wednesday. Gillum, 42, and co-defendant Janet Lettman-Hicks, 53, face 19 counts of wire fraud. Gillum is also charged with making false statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office said the pair â€œconspired to commit wire fraud, by unlawfully soliciting and obtaining funds from various entities and individuals through false and fraudulent promises and representations that the funds would be used for a legitimate purpose.â€ Lettman-Hicks then used her company to fraudulently give money to Gillum disguised as payroll payments, the office said in a press release. Itâ€™s the latest trouble for Gillum, who narrowly lost to Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis in a race that required a recount. Gillum served as mayor of Tallahassee before running for governor. In March 2020, Gillum was found intoxicated and unconscious in a hotel room with two men, including one who works as a male escort. Two days later he entered a rehabilitation center, and later did a television interview and said heâ€™s bisexual. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Tony Siragusa, Former NFL Star, Dead At 55
content: Tony Siragusa, the charismatic defensive tackle who helped lead a stout Baltimore defense to a Super Bowl title, has died. He was 55. Siragusaâ€™s broadcast agent, Jim Ornstein, confirmed the death Wednesday. The cause of death was not immediately available. â€œThis is a really sad day,â€ he said. â€œTony was way more than my client, he was family. My heart goes out to Tonyâ€™s loved ones.â€ Siragusa, known as â€œthe Goose,â€ played seven seasons with the Indianapolis Colts and five with the Ravens. Baltimoreâ€™s 2000 team won the Super Bowl behind a defense that included Siragusa, Ray Lewis and Sam Adams. The Goose,Tony Siracusa has passed away at 55.. Iâ€™m heart broken as is all of Colts Nationâ¤ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ¼ğŸˆ Siragusa was popular with fans because of his fun-loving personality, which also helped him transition quickly to broadcasting after his playing career. Siragusa came to Baltimore as a free agent in 1997 and teamed up with Adams to form an imposing defensive tackle tandem. In the Ravensâ€™ 2000 championship season, the 6-foot-3, 340-pound Siragusa was sixth among Baltimore defenders with 75 tackles. He finished his career with 22 sacks. The news of Siragusaâ€™s death came on what was already a tragic day for the Ravens. The death of Jaylon Ferguson, a linebacker for Baltimore, at age 26 was announced earlier in the day.

topic: Democrats Pan Joe Biden's Call For A Gas Tax Holiday
content:
Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Senior Political Reporter, HuffPost Democratic lawmakers are pushing back on President Joe Bidenâ€™s call for a gas tax holiday, arguing that oil companies would pocket the savings rather than passing it on to consumers. The resistance from key members of Bidenâ€™s own party highlights the dismal prospects for the proposal in Congress, even as it was eagerly embraced by Democratic governors and other legislators facing tough reelection battles in 2022. â€œWe can give families just a little bit of relief,â€ Biden said at a Wednesday afternoon event to pitch his proposal. â€œI call on the companies to pass every penny of this 18-cent reduction on to the consumers. This is no time for profiteering.â€ Earlier in the day, Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works committee, called the proposal a â€œshortsighted and inefficient way to provide relief.â€ Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.) also expressed skepticism. â€œIâ€™d like to see some of the data and some of the states that have tried that, whether thatâ€™s actually resulted in fully lower gas prices,â€ he said in an interview with HuffPost. Biden is urging Congress to pass a three-month suspension of the 18.4 cents-a-gallon tax on gasoline and the 24.4 cents-a-gallon tax on diesel. The proposal should be enacted in such a way as to not affect funding for road projects that rely on federal gas tax revenue, he said. Biden is also calling on more governors to suspend their state gas taxes. Several Republican governors have already moved to do so, including in Maryland, Virginia, and Georgia. The average price of gas in the U.S. has hovered around $5 a gallon this week. Biden blamed a recent spike in prices on Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and the subsequent sanctions on energy-rich Russia â€• an argument with merit, even if gas prices had risen significantly even before the invasion. â€œFor all those Republicans in Congress criticizing me for high gas prices in America, are you now saying we were wrong to support Ukraine?â€ Biden said. â€œAre you saying we would rather have low gas prices in America than Putinâ€™s iron first in Europe?â€ A Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday shows how dominant gas prices have become as a political and economic issue. Nearly two-thirds of Americans said the price of gas is the economic problem worrying them the most right now, compared to just 11% who said the stock market and 3% who said their personal job situation. And 68% of Americans said the price of gasoline has been at least a somewhat serious problem for their family, while 55% said it caused them to cut back on household spending and 40% said it caused them to change their summer vacation plans. The pain at the pump has rattled Democrats about their fortunes in the coming midterm elections. Vulnerable Democratic lawmakers, in particular, have been pushing for a federal gas tax holiday for months. â€œWhile I am encouraged that the President now supports a gas tax holiday, I continue to believe that we should seek to suspend the gas tax for at least the rest of the year, not just 90 days,â€ Sen. Maggie Hassan (D-N.H.) said in a statement on Wednesday. Hassan has made a call for a gas tax holiday a centerpiece of her reelection bid. Democratic governors, who donâ€™t have a vote on the controversial idea, greeted the proposal in a warmer fashion. Biden praised Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker for offering relief for high prices. Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer called on Biden to work with Congress to â€œoffer American families real relief at the pump.â€ â€œGetting this done will save Michiganders money right now,â€ the Democrat said in a video posted to Twitter. But the opposition within Congress could doom the plan. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) has repeatedly dismissed it, calling the move â€œvery showbiz.â€ â€œThe con is that the oil companies do not necessarily pass that on to the consumer ... you cannot write a law that requires them to pass it on,â€ Pelosi said earlier this year. Economists have also argued that a gas tax holiday could make inflation even worse. Jason Furman, a former top economic adviser to President Barack Obama, said that consumers are in less of a position to benefit from a gas tax holiday today than they were six months ago because of supply issues. Whatever you thought of the merits of a gas tax holiday in February it is a worse idea now. Refineries are even more constrained now so supply is nearly fully inelastic. Most of the 18.4 cent reduction would be pocketed by industry--with maybe a few cents passed on to consumers. Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Senior Political Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: These Republicans Resisted Trumpâ€™s Attempt To Steal The Election. Theyâ€™d Vote For Him Again.
content:
Reporter, HuffPost Rusty Bowers, the Republican speaker of the Arizona state House of Representatives, on Tuesday detailed his efforts to thwart former President Donald Trumpâ€™s attempt to steal the 2020 presidential election in stirring testimony to a select congressional committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Bowers told the committee that Trump and his lawyers failed to produce any evidence of fraud, and that they asked him to ignore the law and overturn the election anyway. He became emotional, at times, as he described the barrage of violent threats he and his family have faced since. Bowers read from a journal entry he wrote in December 2020, in which he completely dismissed the then-presidentâ€™s efforts to undermine democracy: â€œI do not want to be a winner by cheating,â€ he wrote. â€œI will not play with laws I swore allegiance to.â€ Hours later, Bowers said he would vote for Trump again. â€œIf he is the nominee, if he was up against Biden, Iâ€™d vote for him again,â€ Bowers told The Associated Press. â€œSimply because what he did the first time, before COVID, was so good for the county. In my view it was great.â€ Bowers was among a small group of Republican elected officials who broke with Trump and refused to go along with the plot to overturn the 2020 election. Now, he is the latest among them to suggest that he would still support Trump in a future contest, even as the former president and his Republican allies intensify their efforts to undermine American democracy. Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, who refused Trumpâ€™s infamous request to â€œfindâ€ the votes necessary to overturn his stateâ€™s election results, did not rule out another vote for Trump in an interview with HuffPost last year. â€œI think thatâ€™s so far out in the future, I donâ€™t even think heâ€™s announced heâ€™s running yet,â€ Raffensperger, who testified alongside Bowers on Tuesday, said in November. â€œSo letâ€™s circle back and talk about that in the future.â€ Raffensperger did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s inquiry on Wednesday. And former Attorney General Bill Barr, who tried to convince Trump that his fraud claims were baseless, said in March that he would support his old boss if Trump were the 2024 Republican nominee. â€œI certainly have made it clear I donâ€™t think he should be our nominee, and Iâ€™m going to support somebody else for the nomination,â€ Barr said on the â€œTodayâ€ show. But, he added, â€œbecause I believe that the greatest threat to the country is the progressive agenda being pushed by the Democratic Party, itâ€™s inconceivable to me that I wouldnâ€™t vote for the Republican nominee.â€ During Tuesdayâ€™s hearing, Bowers described Trumpâ€™s haphazard attempt to overturn the 2020 election as a â€œtragic parody.â€ But since his unwilling departure from the presidency, Trump and his allies within the GOP have launched a far more coordinated and deliberate assault on democracy, with the apparent aim of taking control of the countryâ€™s electoral system in a way that could make it far more likely that a future attempt to undermine an election actually succeeds. Republican election deniers have lined up to run for major statewide offices and congressional seats across the country, with the key swing states that decided the 2020 contest as their chief focus. Candidates who have spread conspiracies about Trumpâ€™s defeat have already won primaries in major battlegrounds: The GOP nominee for governor in Pennsylvania attempted to overturn the 2020 results in his state, while the Republican winner in Nevadaâ€™s secretary of state primary questioned the legitimacy of the outcome and has built a coalition of like-minded candidates in an attempt to â€œtake backâ€ control of the American election system. Dozens of Republicans who have embraced Trumpâ€™s lies have won congressional primaries, and the GOP is likely to nominate election deniers in statewide primaries in Colorado, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin. In May, Raffensperger survived a Republican primary against a Trump-endorsed challenger who twice voted to contest the results of the 2020 election in Congress, and accused Raffensperger of â€œcompromisingâ€ Georgiaâ€™s elections by refusing to help Trump overturn it. In Bowersâ€™ Arizona, meanwhile, upcoming GOP primaries for governor and secretary of state have been dominated by candidates who have spread conspiracies about the last election or refused to commit to the certification of future contests. The grip Trump and his election lies hold on the GOP has inspired deep fears among experts who worry that American democracy is far more vulnerable ahead of the next presidential contest than it was in 2020, especially as the former president sets the stage to run again. Trump has continued to hold campaign-style rallies since he left the White House, and he hinted at a possible 2024 run as recently as last week. A majority of Republican voters said they would support him in the GOP primary if he does run, according to a recent poll from Morning Consult. And Trump has made it clear that his loss in the 2020 election â€” as well as his failed effort to overturn the results â€” would be the driving theme in his next campaign. â€œWeâ€™re not forgetting 2020,â€ Trump said at a Georgia rally in October. â€œThe most corrupt election in the history of our country. Most corrupt election in the history of most countries, to be followed by an even more glorious victory in November of 2024.â€ Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Elliot Page Says Life Has 'Drastically' Improved Since Coming Out As Trans
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Life has only gotten better for Elliot Page since coming out as transgender. The â€œUmbrella Academyâ€ star opened up about feeling a â€œdegree of joyâ€ he never thought possible on Tuesdayâ€™s episode of â€œLate Night With Seth Meyers,â€ sharing that heâ€™s learned to tune out peopleâ€™s negative reactions. â€œItâ€™s improved my life drastically,â€ Page said about transitioning. â€œI hope, you know, I hope maybe people who do have an issue with me can maybe try and hear that, or embrace that on some level.â€ â€œWhat I want to focus on right now and has been so extraordinary is the degree of joy that I feel, the degree of presence that I feel,â€ he added. â€œI feel a way that I really never thought possible for a long, long time.â€ While Pageâ€™s loved ones have been supportive, the actor has previously spoken about the â€œhatred and crueltyâ€ heâ€™s received since publicly disclosing that he is a transgender man in late 2020, including being verbally accosted by a stranger on the street. Page said certain â€œmoments can be overwhelming,â€ but heâ€™s choosing to concentrate on the positive, despite the spate of anti-trans bills that are rolling out across the nation. â€œI feel like itâ€™s one of those things where itâ€™s so unfortunate because itâ€™s like, weâ€™re all on the same team here, you know?â€ he told Meyers, adding that everybody faces â€œlimits and constraints because of peopleâ€™s obsession with the binaryâ€ regardless of their gender identity. The actor added, â€œTo me, itâ€™d be so special for us to all be able to connect and talk about how similar we are in all of our journeys.â€ Ultimately, Page said transitioning â€œmade me betterâ€ both as a person and as an actor. Mirroring Pageâ€™s own real-life experience, his character on Netflixâ€™s superhero series â€œUmbrella Academy,â€ who previously presented as female, comes out as transgender in the new season, which premiered on Wednesday. The characterâ€™s transition has drawn praise from fans and critics alike with Page explaining that showrunner Steve Blackman was â€œreally excited about incorporating it into the showâ€ and remarking that he feels â€œproud of it and excited for people to see it.â€ â€œItâ€™s a beautiful thing to experience now,â€ Page said. â€œBecause a lot of the time my life was just trying to move forward, so getting to embrace the experience as much as I get to now, I think itâ€™s made me better in so many facets. As a person, as a friend, relationships.â€ Page plans to release a memoir next year about his journey. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Brad Pitt Gets Conned Into Hunting For Fake Buried Treasure At His French Mansion
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost In a stunning rebuke of todayâ€™s relatable celebrity culture, Brad Pitt revealed he spent a year hunting for buried medieval treasure that never existed beneath his French estate. Yes, for some reason the Oscar winner chose to come clean about getting swindled by an unnamed man who convinced him that the property he once shared with ex-wife Angelina Jolie was even more valuable than the estimated $60 million the former couple forked over for it back in 2008. Speaking with GQ in a profile published on Wednesday, Pitt said he was told that there were â€œmillions of dollars worth of goldâ€ left by the villaâ€™s medieval owners that had been â€œtaken from the Levant during the Crusades and buried on the grounds.â€ â€œI got obsessed,â€ said Pitt, who acquired radar equipment to hunt for the loot. â€œLike for a year, this was all I could think about, just the excitement of it all. Maybe it has something to do with where I grew up, because in the Ozark Mountainsâ€ near his childhood home in Missouri, â€œthere were always stories of hidden caches of gold.â€ Ultimately, Pitt came up empty, and it was revealed that the man had targeted him as a potential investor in a radar company and (successfully) pitched the prospect of undiscovered riches to dupe the actor. Pitt said the ordeal left him feeling â€œpretty foolish in the end.â€ â€œIt was just the hunt that was exciting,â€ he remarked. Despite the slightly embarrassing admission, there are grounds to believe buried treasure may lay beneath the historic villa. Pittâ€™s ChÃ¢teau Miraval sits along an ancient Roman trade route and contains a sprawling estate and various structures, including the 13th-century chapel where he and Jolie wed. The chÃ¢teau and its award-winning wine from the propertyâ€™s vineyards have since become a major source of contention in the former coupleâ€™s ongoing divorce battle. After Jolie sold her stake in the business last year to Russian billionaire Yuri Shefler, Pitt sued her in February, claiming she unlawfully disregarded their agreement never to sell their shares without the otherâ€™s permission. In a filing from Pittâ€™s legal team earlier this month, the actor claims Jolie â€œsought to inflict harm onâ€ him by forcing him to partner with â€œa stranger with poisonous associations and intentionsâ€ who plans to launch a â€œhostileâ€ takeover of the business. Jolie hasnâ€™t commented on Pittâ€™s allegations or his hunt for fake treasure. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Tom Hanks Reveals Why He Canâ€™t Stop Crashing His Fansâ€™ Weddings
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Tom Hanks shared on Tuesdayâ€™s â€œLate Night with Seth Meyersâ€ why in recent years heâ€™s become a serial wedding crasher at his fansâ€™ weddings, whether heâ€™s â€œinvited or not.â€ The â€œElvisâ€ actor, who loves to hilariously photobomb his supporters on their big day, revealed why he has a passion for wedding crashing. â€œItâ€™s my ego, unchecked,â€ Hanks said jokingly. He added: â€œI just canâ€™t help but think, â€˜What would these people like more than anything else to remember this magic day of days? Oh, I know, me!â€™â€ In March, Hanks stunned a bride when he united with her bridal party outside of a hotel in downtown Pittsburgh to take photos. The group was preparing to leave the venue when the longtime actor pulled up to join in on the snapshot session. The bride, Grace Gwaltney, shared that she was blown away to see the star. â€œHe was like, â€˜Hey! Iâ€™m Tom Hanks. I would love to get a photo with you,â€™ and I immediately froze and was just looking around,â€ Gwaltney told KCRA at the time. â€œI didnâ€™t know what to do.â€ Hanks, who was declared a â€œman of many hatsâ€ by the showâ€™s host, has crashed so many weddings that Meyers showcased the actorâ€™s best wedding-crasher moments during the episode, with some clips even dating back to the early 2000s. The movie heavyweight also explained the time he took his affinity for wedding crashing internationally, after he stumbled upon a brideâ€™s wedding while filming 2009â€™s â€œAngels and Demonsâ€ in Rome. Hanks told Meyers that the set crew wasnâ€™t privy that a wedding party had booked the venue they were filming in, the Pantheon, on the same day. â€œThis limousine pulled up, and it was the bride and the groom trying to â€˜get me to the church on time,â€™â€ Hanks said. â€œAnd they couldnâ€™t do it because we had all this stuff going on.â€ â€œIt was like â€˜Uh, how do we fix this?â€™ So, like a stalker â€” you know, â€˜Hey miss, miss, miss!â€™ â€” I knocked on the window, I said â€˜Hey listen, we have a thing, but would you do me the honor of escorting you to your bridal altar?â€™ So we did it!â€ the actor recalled. Hanks then joked to Meyers that the couple may not have initially recognized him at the time due to his â€œchemically straightened hair,â€ he said, pointing to his hairstyle in the throwback photo from the ceremony. â€œI donâ€™t like to think I crashed a wedding. I provided a service,â€ the leading man added. â€œElvis,â€ in which Hanks plays manager to the rock â€˜nâ€™ roll icon, hits theaters on Friday. Watch the trailer below. Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: James Rado, Co-Creator Of Groundbreaking Musical â€˜Hair,â€™ Dead At 90
content: NEW YORK (AP) â€” James Rado, co-creator of the groundbreaking hippie musical â€œHair,â€ which celebrated protest, pot and free love and paved the way for the sound of rock on Broadway, has died. He was 90. Rado died Tuesday night in New York City of cardio respiratory arrest, according to friend and publicist Merle Frimark. â€œHair,â€ which has a story and lyrics by Rado and Gerome Ragni and music by Galt MacDermot, was the first rock musical on Broadway, the first Broadway show to feature full nudity and the first to feature a same-sex kiss. â€œHairâ€ made possible other rock musicals like â€œJesus Christ Superstarâ€ and â€œRent.â€ Like â€œHamilton,â€ it was one of only a handful of Broadway shows in the past few decades to find its songs on the pop charts. The so-called â€œAmerican tribal love-rock musical,â€ had its world premiere at the Public Theater in New York Cityâ€™s East Village in 1967 and transferred the following year to Broadway, where the musical ran more than 1,800 performances. Rado played Claude, a young man about to be drafted and sent to the war in Vietnam. Clive Barnes, theater critic for The New York Times, called the show â€œthe first Broadway musical in some time to have the authentic voice of today rather than the day before yesterday.â€ The New York Post said it had â€œunintentional charm,â€ contagious high spirits and a â€œyoung zestfulnessâ€ that â€œmake it difficult to resist.â€ Variety, however, called it â€œloony.â€ It lost the Tony in 1969 to the more traditional â€œ1776â€ but won a Grammy Award. The 2009 revival won the best revival Tony. The show was revived on Broadway in 1977 and again in 2009. It was made into a movie directed by Milos Forman in 1979 starring Treat Williams and Beverly Dâ€™Angelo. â€œHairâ€ spawned four top four singles on the American pop charts, including the No. 1 hit â€œAquarius/Let the Sunshine Inâ€ by the Fifth Dimension, which won the Grammy Award for record of the year and best pop vocal performance by a group in 1970. Others included â€œHairâ€ by the Cowsills, â€œGood Morning, Starshineâ€ by the singer Oliver and â€œEasy to Be Hardâ€ by Three Dog Night. The cast album itself stayed at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 for 13 weeks â€œHairâ€ tells the story of Claude and Berger, best buddies who find freedom in the late 1960s. Between draft-card burnings, love-ins, bad LSD trips and a parade of protest marches, the two wander through a New York filled with flower children, drugged-out hippies and outraged tourists who donâ€™t approve of the wild goings-on. In one song, Claude poignantly sings, â€œWhy do I live, why do I die, tell me where do I go, tell me why.â€ The show is playful and chaotic, but thereâ€™s also a sense of outrage in its protests against war, racism, sexism, pollution and the general hypocrisy of an era dominated by the American involvement in Vietnam. â€œIâ€™d still like â€˜Hairâ€™ to be about what it was about then,â€ Rado told The Associated Press in 1993. â€œâ€˜Hairâ€™ had a spiritual message, and it has a mystical message I hope is coming through â€” thereâ€™s more to life than the way itâ€™s been devised for us, explained to us, taught to us.â€ The songs of â€œHairâ€ have been used in everything from the films â€œForrest Gump,â€ â€œMinionsâ€ and â€œThe 40-Year-Old Virginâ€ to TV shows like â€œGlee,â€ â€œSo You Think You Can Danceâ€ and â€œMy Name Is Earl.â€ Billboard magazine lists â€œAquarius/Let the Sunshine Inâ€ at No. 66 of all-time top 100 songs. In 2019, the original 1968 Broadway cast recording was inducted into the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress. Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden deemed â€œthese aural treasures worthy of preservation because of their cultural, historic and aesthetic importance to the nationâ€™s recorded sound heritage.â€ Rado was born in Venice, California, and raised in Rochester, New York, and Washington, D.C. After serving two years in the U.S. Navy, he moved to New York and studied acting with Paula and Lee Strasberg. Rado was part of the ensemble of the Broadway play â€œMarathon â€™33â€ in 1963 and played Richard Lionheart in â€œThe Lion in Winterâ€ in 1966 opposite Christopher Walken. He met Ragni when he was cast in the off-Broadway musical â€œHang Down Your Head and Die.â€ The two were interested in birthing a new kind of show and focused on the hippie scene. They wrote the script while sharing an apartment in Hoboken, New Jersey. Rado originated the â€œHairâ€ role of the draftee Claude on Broadway. â€œHairâ€ met resistance across the country. In addition to the use of four-letter words, the flouting of authority, sexual references and gross-out humor, the end of Act 1 had the entire cast strip naked to â€œWhere Do I Goâ€ and there was what many believed was desecration of the American flag. There were church pickets in Evansville, Indiana. Municipal officials in Chattanooga, Tennessee, denied a request to stage the show, determining that it would not be â€œin the best interest of the community.â€ In Denver, police threatened to arrest anyone who appeared nude onstage. A Boston visit was challenged in court on the basis of flag desecration. The original Public Theater production had cut the nude scene, but the creators wanted it back for the Broadway debut. Under the law at that time, New York City allowed nudity onstage onstage as long as the actors werenâ€™t moving, which is why the whole cast of â€œHairâ€ stood together in a row, nude and perfectly still. After â€œHair,â€ Rado wrote the music and lyrics of the off-Broadway show â€œRainbow,â€ co-authoring the book with his brother, Ted Rado. He later teamed up with Ragni to create the book and lyrics for the show â€œSun.â€ Ragni died in 1991. Rado wrote a new show called â€œAmerican Soldierâ€ with his brother. In 2009, Rado, MacDermot and Ragni were inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame. Marilyn McCoo and Billy Davis Jr., of the group The Fifth Dimension, were joined onstage by the Broadway cast at the time for a finale that brought the ceremonyâ€™s approximately 1,000 guests to their feet. MacDermot died in 2018. Rado told the Hudson Reporter in 2009 that none of the showâ€™s creators anticipated that it would have such an enormous impact. â€œWe thought weâ€™d stumbled on a great idea, and something that potentially could be a hit on Broadway, never thinking of the distant future.â€ He is survived by his brother Ted Rado, sister-in-law Kay Rado, nieces Melanie Khoury, Emily DiBona and Melissa Stuart, great-nieces and a great-nephew. ___ Mark Kennedy is at http://twitter.com/KennedyTwits

topic: Kim Kardashian Reveals How She Knew When To Introduce Pete Davidson To Her Kids
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Kim Kardashian revealed that she relied on the advice of one of her sisters when it came to figuring out the right time to introduce her boyfriend, Pete Davidson, to her four children. The SKKN by Kim founder, who shares North, Saint, Chicago and Psalm with her ex Kanye West, spoke to Hoda Kotb and Savannah Guthrie on â€œTodayâ€  Tuesday about why she decided to wait six months for the big meeting. â€œLuckily I have a sister that has been through it all, and we talked about it,â€ Kardashian said, seemingly referencing her older sister, Kourtney, who has navigated co-parenting with her ex, Scott Disick, over the years. â€œI consulted with a few therapists and friends that have been through it,â€ the reality star added. â€œI definitely wanted to wait six months. And that was the marker.â€ But in her mind, there isnâ€™t a perfect formula for navigating new relationships with kids. â€œI think itâ€™s different for everyone,â€ Kardashian explained. â€œDifferent things work for different people, but you just have to do what feels right and try to be as respectful and cautious as possible.â€ Kotb and Guthrie also asked the Skims creator if her new relationship with the former â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ star took her â€œby surprise.â€ â€œIt did,â€ Kardashian answered with a smile, but said that she also â€œwaited a whileâ€ before jumping into something new. â€œI waited, like, a good 10 months before I was ready to open myself up,â€ she said. â€œAnd I think you definitely need that time to yourself. And then once youâ€™re ready to get out there, I felt like I just wanted new energy and something different. And it definitely took me by surprise.â€ Kardashian spoke about the difficulties both she and her family faced during her marriage to West, who now goes by Ye, on a recent episode of the Kardashianâ€™s Hulu reality show. â€œI do recognize the impact that my relationship has had on my family and that Iâ€™ve never had the opportunity to just say, â€˜Iâ€™m sorry, guys,â€™â€ Kardashian said during the episode, which aired in May. â€œI canâ€™t control how he treats me or how he has always treated you guys,â€ she added. â€œI protected that for so long, but I said, â€˜I will never let that happen to you guys again.â€™ For once in my life, I feel strong. I am not going to let anyone treat you guys a way or myself.â€ Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Christian Bale Didnâ€™t Know What The MCU Was Before 'Thor: Love And Thunder'
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Actor Christian Bale was unaware he had entered any kind of â€œcinematic universeâ€ when he joined the cast of Marvelâ€™s â€œThor: Love And Thunder.â€ The actor â€” who played Gothamâ€™s caped crusader in the â€œDark Knightâ€ trilogy â€” recently told Total Film he didnâ€™t even know what the acronym â€œMCUâ€ (Marvel Cinematic Universe) stood for before he ditched DC Comics for the opposing multiverse. â€œIâ€™d read that, and people would go, â€˜Oh, look at this! Heâ€™s entered the MCU!â€™ And Iâ€™d go, â€˜Iâ€™ve done what? I havenâ€™t entered shit, thank you very much,â€™â€ Bale said. â€œIâ€™m like, â€˜The MCU?â€™ I had to ask what that was.â€ The Oscar-winner also recounted the hilarious moment he learned about his character, Gorr the God Butcher, a sinister Marvel supervillain he didnâ€™t even know existed. â€œI did make the mistake of Googling [Gorr] and, oh no! [In the comics,] he runs around in a G-string all the time,â€ Bale told Total Film. He added: â€œAnd I thought, â€˜They donâ€™t have the right man for that!â€™ And then [director Taika Waititi] quickly dispelled any notions of running around in that.â€ Christian Bale on researching for #Gorr:I know what he does. It's right there in the name, isn't it? But I did make the mistake of Googling him and, oh no! [In the comics] he runs around in a G-string all the time, and I thought, 'They don't have the right man for that!â€™ pic.twitter.com/nGs3EDWS5a Asked if he had any reservations about portraying another comic book character after playing Batman to critical acclaim, Bale rapidly banished the notion. â€œAbsolutely not, no. That didnâ€™t even enter into my head at all,â€ he said. The Method actor also shared that he and Waititi had discussed making the character less serious and that heâ€™d wanted to add a dance sequence inspired by singer Kate Bush, who recently enjoyed a resurgence in â€œStranger Things.â€ â€œThereâ€™s obviously sort of a â€˜Nosferatuâ€™ slight attitude,â€ Bale said. â€œTaika and I wanted to do a whole dance, which we didnâ€™t get to do, but we had all this sort of Kate Bush stuff that we worked at. But I think he just realized he was never going to be allowed to put that in the final film.â€ â€œThor: Love And Thunder,â€ the fourth installment of the â€œThorâ€ franchise, is set to hit theaters on July 8. Watch the latest trailer below. Trends Reporter, HuffPost
