topic: Rob Kardashian And Blac Chyna Settle Before Trial's Sequel
content: LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” A settlement agreement has been reached on the eve of a second trial pitting the Kardashian family against former reality TV star Blac Chyna. Jury selection had been set to begin Monday in the trial over Chyna's allegations that her former fiance Rob Kardashian maliciously posted nude photos of her in 2017 after their tumultuous breakup, but according to court documents, the parties informed the judge that they had agreed to a settlement. Emails to attorneys for both sides seeking comment and details on the terms of the settlement were not immediately returned. A trial had seemed a virtual certainty after the judge last week denied a motion by Kardashian's attorneys to enforce a settlement agreement they said the two sides had reached. The trial was to be a sequel of sorts to a defamation trial earlier this year in which Chyna, whose legal name is Angela White, alleged that Kardashian's mother and sisters â€” Kris Jenner, Kim Kardashian, KhloÃ© Kardashian and Kylie Jenner â€” had defamed her as violent and unstable, and persuaded producers and executives to cancel her reality show, â€œRob & Chyna.â€ The Kardashians won a clear-cut victory in that trial May 2. The four women had attended most of the proceedings, and all four testified, though they were in New York at the Met Gala when the verdict was read. Rob Kardashian, who has a daughter with Chyna, was not a defendant in that trial, but he gave often angry and sometimes sad testimony about the late-night fight that led to the end of their relationship. Chyna had initially filed one lawsuit against the whole family, but the judge ruled that the allegations against Rob â€” which also included assault accusations â€” should get their own trial. Fewer members of the famous family had been expected to attend the second trial, and only Rob and Kris Kardashian had been expected to testify. At the first trial, jurors found that the Kardashians acted in bad faith in their conversations about the couple's troubles with producers of â€œRob & Chynaâ€ and executives from the E! network, which aired it. But they found that it had no substantial effect on Chynaâ€™s contract or the fate of the show, and she was awarded no damages. Chynaâ€™s attorney Lynne Ciani said after the verdict that she and her client were disappointed but felt vindicated by the jury's findings, which she said demonstrated that Chyna had not physically abused Rob, and validated their claim that the Kardashian women had attempted to interfere with her contract to be on the show. ___ Follow AP Entertainment Writer Andrew Dalton on Twitter: https://twitter.com/andyjamesdalton

topic: How The Tribeca Film Festival Underscored The Resilience of Filmmaking
content: Senior Culture Reporter This yearâ€™s Tribeca Film Festival was, as they say, an embarrassment of riches. Incorporating films and TV series from across the world, and spanning many genres and formats, it ultimately underscored the resilience of filmmaking even during times of turmoil. From a soul-altering pregnancy experience to the origin story of techno music and a young girlâ€™s spiritual odyssey told through animation, these narratives were the highlights at the festival. â€œLiquor Store Dreamsâ€ Those alive amid the 1992 Los Angeles uprising might recall seeing myriad images of Korean proprietors, some who were armed, standing on the roofs of their buildings as businesses around them burst into flames. Itâ€™s a narrative that, still to this day, isnâ€™t treated with nearly the amount of nuance as it deserves. But documentarian So Yun Um takes a humanistic approach to detailing the complicated, and at times tragic, stories of the Korean liquor store owners and their first-generation children â€” like herself â€” struggling to be seen. And while doing so, Um takes on the difficult task of exploring the fraught evolution of Black-Korean relations in LA. â€œHueseraâ€ Thereâ€™s definitely no shortage of horror screen narratives that hinge on the terror of motherhood, from â€œRosemaryâ€™s Babyâ€ to this yearâ€™s â€œThe Baby.â€ But writer-director Michelle Garza Cevera, with co-writer Abia Castillo, explores the well-worn concept with an entirely original Mexican film that is ultimately about a pregnant woman (Natalia SoliÃ¡n) who discovers her path to motherhood comes at grave costs. Most terrifying is her sense of self. â€œMy Love Affair With Marriageâ€ With the success of last yearâ€™s â€œFlee,â€ which shattered all expectations of both animation and documentary, filmmakers seem to be taking even more chances that are paying off in dividends. With â€œMy Love Affair with Marriage,â€ Latvian filmmaker Signe Baumane explores the effects of human condition in this remarkable coming-of-age story that tests the bounds of fiction as it traces a girlâ€™s 23-year journey to achieve love and romantic partnership. Throughout the process, the film asks its protagonist, and to some extent the audience, to understand the intricacies of why sheâ€™s on this quest in the first place â€” for herself or to satisfy certain expectations of her. â€œPink Moonâ€ A routine meal at the dinner table throws one family into tense discussions about deciding oneâ€™s own mortality when a father (Johan Leysen) with no known health issues announces to his adult children that his next birthday will be his last in this surprisingly earnest Dutch film. Director Floor van der Meulen, with screenwriter Bastiaan Kroeger, delicately balances drama with pitch dark comedy in a story that ponders the notion of self-determined fate and the lives, chiefly daughter Iris (a fantastic Julia Akkermans), that it impacts. â€œOfficial Competitionâ€ Neither PenÃ©lope Cruz nor Antonio Banderas are strangers to starring in quirky films like â€œVanilla Skyâ€ or â€œIâ€™m So Excited.â€ But directors Mariano Cohn and GastÃ³n Duprat, with co-writer AndrÃ©s Duprat, challenge the pair in a whole new way in a film essentially about the narcissistic nature of filmmaking. Cruz is an off-the-wall director who pushes her actors, played by Banderas and Oscar MartÃ­nez, to go deep into the narrative by any means (sometimes even by sacrificing their own prized possessions). Hilarity ensues. â€œFamily Dinnerâ€ Especially after â€œFreshâ€ earlier this year, horror fans might anticipate, and maybe even be eager for, a film that engages in the many complexities of carnal pleasure. But trust, you will not expect what happens in Austrian filmmaker Peter Henglâ€™s â€œFamily Dinner,â€ which takes a sweet premise like a girl (Nina Katlein) visiting her aunt (Pia Hierzegger), whom she looks up to, and her new family unit and turns it into a mounting nightmare. â€œButterfly in the Skyâ€ If youâ€™re an elder millennial, chances are you grew up on a healthy diet of â€œReading Rainbowâ€ with host LeVar Burton. In fact, just the mere mention of the title of this PBS educational series, which ran from 1983 to 2006, probably stirs memories of its iconic theme song. Directors Bradford Thomason and Brett Whitcomb engage with that nostalgia in this documentary that chronicles why the series was a success and made Burton an icon of scholarship, the racial and social barriers it broke, and why it was a tragedy when it lost its funding. â€œGod Said Give â€™Em Drum Machinesâ€ Even if youâ€™re not part of the techno fandom, youâ€™ll get something out of this documentary, directed by Kristian R. Hill, that puts credit for the music genre back into the hands of Black DJs and musicians in Detroit. This story doesnâ€™t so much ask whether or why it was co-opted by white recording artists, though it does give that question the thought it deserves. Rather, how these young Black men created the music and found each other as well as a largely queer Black club community in the process. â€œThe Right to Offend: The Black Comedy Revolutionâ€ Weâ€™re living during a time when it seems like every day a stand-up comedian is getting canceled or assaulted, whether that is verbally or physically, for the words they speak. So it seems like an interesting time to reflect on the ways particularly Black comics throughout history have never backed down from statements considered controversial to the public â€” from Moms Mabley and Dick Gregory to Chris Rock and Dave Chappelle. Directors Jessica Sherif and Mario Diaz trace the complexity of the punchline in this timely docuseries. â€œA League of Their Ownâ€ Admittedly, the mere idea of yet another TV series adapted from a classic film in this saturated climate is eye-roll-worthy. But showrunner Will Grahamâ€™s thoughtful exploration of the beloved female baseball players at the center of this story incorporates multiple queer characters and characters of color that help ground the humanity of both the time period, the narrative and the sport. It doesnâ€™t take away from the original 1992 film, but itâ€™s a nice companion piece. â€œMenudo: Forever Youngâ€ From the title alone, you might want to file this under another docuseries reflecting on one of your favorite nostalgic bands. But â€œMenudo: Forever Youngâ€ goes farther than that as directors Angel Manuel Soto and Kristofer RÃ­os grapple with the iconic boy bandâ€™s impact on their Puerto Rican community, the exploitative nature of their industry and the horrible debt they paid. Senior Culture Reporter

topic: Katelina Eccleston Is Giving Black Latinas In Reggaeton Their Flowers
content: Culture Reporter This profile is part of our Culture Shifters series, which highlights people who are changing the way we think about the world around us. Read about film archivist Maya Cade, internet star Keyon Elkins, rapper LatashÃ¡, filmmaker Alika Tengan and artist Kay Rufai. Music historian Katelina Eccleston has always loved reggaeton. â€œI have home videos [of me] dancing to El General at 3 years old in a puffy yellow dress and black shoes,â€ Eccleston said, referring to the legendary Panamanian reggaeton artist. â€œI was born into listening to reggae en espaÃ±ol and reggaeton by El General.â€ Raised by Panamanian parents in Boston, Eccleston is a proud Black Latina. That pride in her heritage and love for reggaeton inspired Eccleston to give Afro-Latinas the spotlight they deserve. The historian and artist is the founder of Reggaeton Con La Gata, the first femme brand and platform dedicated to the intersectional analysis and history of reggaeton. In addition to its biweekly newsletter, the brandâ€™s official Twitter account @ReggaetonXGata spotlights Black Latinas in Reggaeton â€” such as La Zista, Glory â€œLa Gata Gangster,â€ Amara La Negra, and more â€” through curated playlists, roundups of music industry news and conversations between Eccleston, artists and music experts. Created in Ecclestonâ€™s college dorm room, Reggaeton Con La Gata has been featured in Harperâ€™s Bazaar, Remezcla, NPR and other outlets. Sheâ€™s given guest lectures at Harvard University and produced the Spotify podcast â€œLoud: the History of Reggaeton.â€ Eccleston is a lead researcher on MTV and Paramountâ€™s forthcoming show â€œDe La Calle.â€ The docuseries is hosted by Nick Barili and explores the â€œevolution of Urbano music and cultures that ignited the musical revolution of Hip Hop, Reggaeton, Bachata, Latin trap, Cumbia, and other sounds,â€ according to Deadline. Eccelstonâ€™s musical acumen and upbringing is shaped by a fusion of cultures. She spent her Sundays in an African American Baptist church, where she learned how to play the piano. She attended West Indian Carnival and Dominican parties where the sound of bachata beats reverberated through the walls. â€œI feel like throughout all of that, one thing that has always mattered to me was the music,â€ Eccleston said. At age 11 or 12, she remembers making the conscious decision to â€œchoose reggaeton.â€ However, listening to the genre was initially off-limits for Eccleston, whose mother categorized reggaeton in the same box as painting her nails and other â€œgrown folkâ€ activities. â€I remember going to a quinces and dancing reggaeton with a family friend, and my momâ€™s like, â€˜You donâ€™t dance reggaeton because thatâ€™s for older people,â€™â€ she said. â€œWhen a religious mother tells you you canâ€™t have something, you just want it all the more.â€ What was once off-limits to Eccleston has catalyzed her legacy. â€œI have home videos [of me] dancing to El General at 3 years old in a puffy yellow dress and black shoes. I was born into listening to reggae en espaÃ±ol and reggaeton by El General.â€ â€œMy obsession with music has always been infectious in my social situations,â€ Eccleston said. But that pride in her heritage has at times been complicated by anti-Blackness within her communities. The 27-year-old â€œcomunicadora socialâ€ recalled pressures as a kid from people outside of her family to conform to â€œLatinidadâ€ â€” a term that loosely translates to Latino-ness and the attributes of a shared Latino identity â€” because she is darker-skinned. She said that, fortunately, her immediate family has always been very pro-Black and has raised her to disregard comments such as â€œpelo malo,â€ made in reference to kinky or coily Black hair. â€œTo paint a very specific picture,â€ said Eccleston, recounting her childhood, â€œin the third grade, my own peers would ask me, â€˜Are you sitting at the Black table or the Spanish table?â€™ Itâ€™s funny because at the Spanish table, theyâ€™re all Black Latinos. I would consciously choose not to sit at either, so I was so alone.â€ Growing up in very segregated Boston, which has a prominent Dominican population, Eccleston and her cousins were often the only Panamanians in social settings. For her, home was not only a safe haven, but a venue to share music. In the days of Limewire and iPods, crowds of classmates would show up on Ecclestonâ€™s doorstep, demanding that she host the next party. But when her father died by suicide when she was 12, her energy shifted. â€œI was the most depressed teenager,â€ Eccleston said. â€œI had the emo haircut. You could not get me to stop wearing skulls, studded belts, Jordans. Around 18, I was like, â€˜You know what? Iâ€™m alive. Heâ€™s not. I have to live my life. I donâ€™t want to be sad anymore.â€™ I made the conscious decision to forgive him, forgive myself for wasting my own time, being sad and being mean to myself.â€ With a new lease on life, she sought to expand her horizons and pursued college in the Big Apple. In 2012, she started at the Pratt Institute, but the joys of freshman year were curtailed by a traumatic sexual assault. Music is what saved her, she said. â€œIâ€™m a moody listener. Iâ€™ll go from Flyleaf and Three Days Grace to the nastiest reggaeton and back to Jay-Z, then back to the nastiest reggaeton,â€ laughed Eccleston. â€œI feel like itâ€™s the sexiest genre thatâ€™s out there. Thereâ€™s a lot of intelligence that comes from it â€” when you take apart all of the misogyny â€” the intention behind it and its process. I have a profound respect for it.â€ In 2016, she transferred to Marymount Manhattan College to study communication and media arts, with the goal of becoming the next Ilia Calderon, a well-known Colombian journalist. Then it dawned on her: Eccleston didnâ€™t want the pressure of being â€œthe nextâ€ anything. She asked herself, what if I did my own thing? â€œThis is coming on senior year where we had to present our capstones. I was like, has anyone ever studied reggaeton? Thatâ€™s when I found the work of Marisol LeBrÃ³n, Wayne Marshall and people whoâ€™ve done it before me,â€ Eccleston said. â€œIt hit me at that moment that people donâ€™t know Panamaniansâ€™ contributions on a larger scale. Iâ€™m like, â€˜Oh, people donâ€™t know my history. Thereâ€™s no bridge between academia and entertainment? No? What the heck! Why isnâ€™t this a thing?â€™â€ Following her capstone thesis and presentation, Eccleston knew she had so much more to say â€” and Reggaeton Con La Gata was born. As a tween softball player, her friends gave her the nickname â€œGata,â€ which translates to â€œcatâ€ (short for Katelina). So she infused it into the brandâ€™s name. After graduation, Eccleston worked at Dickâ€™s Sporting Goods by day. At night, sheâ€™d move from venue to venue, interviewing artists at local nightclubs. Her online following blew up when cultural critic Zahira Kelly retweeted her after they met. â€œShe was like, â€˜Make a video. Talk about reggaeton history!â€™â€ recalled Eccleston. â€œ[Zahira] had like 30,000 followers. Sheâ€™s like, â€˜Iâ€™m gonna retweet you and youâ€™re gonna see!â€™ I wake up the next day, and I have thousands of retweets.â€ While building comunidad through Reggaeton Con La Gata, Eccleston, a longtime lover of poetry, sought to create her own music. With an EP on the way, she said that her â€œaudacityâ€ to take the leap stemmed from the fact that in the music industry, Black Latinas are written out of their own stories. According to Ecclestonâ€™s research, less than 10% of reggaeton performers are Black Latinas. â€œ[Reggaeton] was a medium of resistance. Sure, it got fun, but it was first used to spread messages. Thatâ€™s in the spirit of this music, to stand for something. I say reggaeton is a daughter of hip hop, and thereâ€™s different objectives.â€ Too often popular artists contribute to the erasure of Black Latinos in the genre. Case in point: For Paper magazine, Eccleston spoke to J. Balvin about his self-acclaimed status as an ambassador of â€œthe culture.â€ In the interview, he said he â€œdidnâ€™t have Latinos in mindâ€ when making his hit song â€œIn Da Getto.â€ â€œThe purpose of this song was to showcase the Projects as a main element of â€˜El Movimiento,â€™â€ Balvin said in the article. Eccleston noted that the â€œtrack highlights the issue of Black Latinos being spoken for without consideration of their plight.â€ By centering himself at the reggaeton movementâ€™s core, Balvin is effectively ignoring the Black Latino predecessors who made his ascent possible, Eccleston said. She said itâ€™s a bone that many Black Latinos have to pick with him. (Last year, the issue came more into focus when he was named Afro-Latino Artist of the Year by the African Entertainment Awards, despite not being Afro Latino. The award name was later changed to Best Latin Artist of the year. Moreover, in 2021, J. Balvin had to apologize for depicting Black women as dogs on leashes in the music video for his single â€œPerra.â€) Due to Latinidadâ€™s connection to white supremacy, said Eccleston, she often finds herself exasperated trying to explain the implications of being a Black individual in hyperwhite environments, such as the Latin music industry. Eccleston said this is largely due to the fact that many white Latino artists and community members fail to understand the power they wield in the industry. â€œYes, I love this music, but on a personal and professional note, what I want is for people to pause and think about what weâ€™re doing to each other,â€ Eccleston said about how erasure of Black Latino contributions to music. â€œIf theyâ€™re backed by institutions, for example, which a lot of these artists and the teams are, they have the ability to enact violence on others if they donâ€™t recognize what their power is or that they have it. They donâ€™t even know what that means.â€ Eccleston noted that the barriers to entry for Afro-Latino performers differ greatly across gender. Rattling off male musicians such as Sech, Zion y Lennox, O.G. Black, Yaga y Mackie and others, she pointed out the vast disparity between the number of Black men compared to Black women in reggaeton. Eccleston said â€œthereâ€™s no sort of advocacy for Black women,â€ citing singer Amara La Negra as an example of what often happens to Black Latinas in music. Amara La Negra, who broke through on VH1â€™s â€œLove & Hip-Hop: Miami,â€ has talked about anti-Blackness and colorism in Latino communities and the music business. â€œPeople were tired of hearing about racism, about problems they couldnâ€™t relate to. Over time, thereâ€™s this sort of tokenization that happens,â€ said Eccleston. â€œFor her to share that she was homeless? I absolutely believe it. Because wouldnâ€™t that be me if I went off on that as well? Thatâ€™s how extreme it is. People can be like â€˜we hear you,â€™ and not not give a damn if you have a place to sleep.â€ Eccleston added that for female artists and listeners, navigating the difference between gratuitous sexuality and sexual empowerment in reggaeton is akin to walking a tightrope. A part of the issue, she added, is some people canâ€™t fathom women, especially Black women, claiming power through sex positivity. As a former sex worker, Eccleston hopes people grasp that reggaeton is not only about sex, but about liberation. â€œ[Reggaeton] was a medium of resistance. Sure, it got fun, but it was first used to spread messages. Thatâ€™s in the spirit of this music, to stand for something,â€ Eccleston said. â€œI say reggaeton is a daughter of hip-hop, and thereâ€™s different objectives. The mission might be to own sexuality or to have fun.â€ Through Reggaeton Con La Gata, Eccleston hopes to advance and continue the genreâ€™s legacy. â€œQuite frankly, thereâ€™s a mission [with Reggaeton con La Gata] in regards to owning its authenticity and its Blackness, whichever way it may present itself because thereâ€™s a policing as to what type of Blackness is acceptable,â€ Eccleston said. â€œWith my platform, I hope to just be a space where you can recognize all these different things in bite-sized pieces.â€ Culture Reporter

topic: Stephen Colbert Addresses His Teamâ€™s Arrest By U.S. Capitol Police: â€˜Just Doing Their Jobâ€™
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Stephen Colbert on Monday addressed the arrest of his production crew by U.S. Capitol Police last week and joked that they were guilty of â€œpuppetry in the first degree.â€ Seven members of the â€œLate Nightâ€ team were arrested in the Longworth House Office Building Thursday night and charged with unlawful entry. CBS said the production team was recording a comedy segment featuring Triumph the Insult Comic Dog and had filmed authorized and pre-arranged interviews with members of Congress. The network said the team was detained while filming stand-ups and other elements in the halls after their last interview of the day. Robert Smigel, who provides the voice for the toy dog, was among those arrested. â€œThe Capitol Police are much more cautious than they were, say, 18 months ago. And for a very good reason. If you donâ€™t know what that reason is, I know what news network you watch,â€ Colbert said on Monday. â€œThe Capitol Police were just doing their job. My staff was just doing their job. Everyone was very professional. Everyone was very calm. My staffers were detained, processed and released.â€ While it was a â€œvery unpleasant experienceâ€ for his staff, Colbert said it was all a fairly simple story â€• until a certain TV personality falsely declared â€œLate Nightâ€ staff had â€œcommitted insurrection at the U.S. Capitol building.â€ (Colbert didnâ€™t mention him by name, but those words were spoken by Fox News host Tucker Carlson on Friday night.) â€œFirst of all, what? Second of all, huh? Third of all, they werenâ€™t in the Capitol building. Fourth of all â€• and I am shocked I have to explain the difference â€• but an insurrection involves disrupting the lawful actions of Congress and howling for the blood of elected leaders all to prevent the peaceful transfer of power,â€ Colbert said. â€œThis was first degree puppetry. This was hijinks with intent to goof. Misappropriation of an old Conan bit.â€ Watch his full explanation below: Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Herschel Walker Says There Are 52 States
content:
Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost There are 50 states in the United States of America. But in an interview Tuesday, Georgia GOP Senate candidate Herschel Walker said there were 52. Walker was going after Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor, for recently saying, â€œI am tired of hearing about [Georgia] being the best state in the country to do business when we are the worst state in the country to live.â€ Abrams cited the stateâ€™s problems with mental health treatment, maternal mortality, incarceration rates and wages. Republicans seized upon the remark and used it to criticize her, although Abrams said she stood by her belief that Republican Brian Kemp is â€œa failed governor, who doesnâ€™t care about the people of Georgia.â€ In an interview Tuesday with the Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show, Walker said Abrams should go live in another state â€• saying she had 51 others from which to choose. â€œIf you donâ€™t believe in the country, leave and go somewhere else,â€ he said. â€œIf itâ€™s the worst state, why are you here? Why donâ€™t you leave â€• go to another? Thereâ€™s, what, 51 more other states that you can go to?â€ â€œHerschel misspoke â€• he obviously knows there are 50 states,â€ spokeswoman Mallory Blount told HuffPost. Walker is a former NFL star whose campaign has been filled with controversies and misstatements. He has faced domestic violence allegations, and recently, claims of being an absent father. Walker has talked frequently about his 22-year-old son Christian and railed against fatherless homes. But The Daily Beast reported that Walker actually has three other children he doesnâ€™t talk about publicly. He has since acknowledged his four children, saying he â€œnever denied any of my kids.â€ Walker has also said heâ€™s skeptical of evolution, pointing to the fact that apes and humans coexist. â€œAt one time, science said man came from apes, did it not? ... If that is true, why are there still apes? Think about it,â€ Walker said in March. After the massacre in Uvalde, Texas, Walker called for â€œa department that can look at young men thatâ€™s looking at women thatâ€™s looking at social media,â€ as a solution to curb school shootings, but it was not clear what that was or how it would solve the problem. In 2008, then-candidate Barack Obama also misspoke on the number of states. â€œIt is wonderful to be back in Oregon,â€ Obama said. â€œOver the last 15 months, weâ€™ve traveled to every corner of the United States. Iâ€™ve now been in 57 states? I think one left to go. Alaska and Hawaii, I was not allowed to go to even though I really wanted to visit, but my staff would not justify it.â€ He later said it was â€œa sign that my numeracy is getting a little, uh â€•â€ before an aide cut him off. Some on took this comment as further proof of the birther conspiracy, claiming that he was actually referencing Muslim countries. Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Sen. Ron Johnson Caught Faking Phone Call To Avoid Fake Elector Questions
content:
National Reporter, HuffPost Facing searing questions about the revelation he tried to give false election documents to then-Vice President Mike Pence, Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) opted to fake a phone call. He got caught doing that, too. NBC News reporter Frank Thorp V spotted the Wisconsin Republican as he left the Capitol building Tuesday. Earlier that day, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol aired damning texts sent by Johnsonâ€™s chief of staff, Sean Riley, to a Pence staffer saying the senator wanted to hand the vice president an â€[a]lternate slate of electorsâ€ â€• the fake election documents used to push the idea that former President Donald Trump won in states he actually lost. â€œHow much did you know about what your chief of staff was doing with the alternate slates of electors?â€ Thorp asked Johnson, as captured in a video of the encounter. â€œIâ€™m on the phone right now,â€ Johnson said, pointing to the device and dismissively waving Thorp away. â€œNo youâ€™re not,â€ Thorp replied. â€œI can see your phone. I can see your screen.â€ Sen. Ron Johnson so much didn't want to talk to reporters about his office trying to pass fake elector lists to the vice president's office that he tried to pretend he was on the phone. pic.twitter.com/V1VwBDs42t Caught in the act, Johnson nevertheless continued the ruse, holding the phone to his ear in a one-sided, silent conversation with no one. After 30 awkward seconds, the senator put his phone down â€• still having not uttered a word into it â€• to tell reporters the apparent bombshell is â€œa complete non-story.â€ â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re even concerned about here,â€ he said. Johnson denied any knowledge of what transpired between his chief of staff and Mike Penceâ€™s staff, saying he had no idea the falsified election documents had â€œeven been delivered to us.â€ National Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Andrew Gillum, Former Candidate For Florida Governor, Facing Federal Charges
content:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) â€” Andrew Gillum, the 2018 Democratic nominee for Florida governor, is facing 21 federal charges related to a scheme to seek donations and funnel a portion of them back to him through third parties, the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office announced Wednesday. Gillum, 42, and co-defendant Janet Lettman-Hicks, 53, face 19 counts of wire fraud. Gillum is also charged with making false statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office said the pair â€œconspired to commit wire fraud, by unlawfully soliciting and obtaining funds from various entities and individuals through false and fraudulent promises and representations that the funds would be used for a legitimate purpose.â€ Lettman-Hicks then used her company to fraudulently give money to Gillum disguised as payroll payments, the office said in a press release. Itâ€™s the latest trouble for Gillum, who narrowly lost to Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis in a race that required a recount. Gillum served as mayor of Tallahassee before running for governor. In March 2020, Gillum was found intoxicated and unconscious in a hotel room with two men, including one who works as a male escort. Two days later he entered a rehabilitation center, and later did a television interview and said heâ€™s bisexual. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Tony Siragusa, Former NFL Star, Dead At 55
content: Tony Siragusa, the charismatic defensive tackle who helped lead a stout Baltimore defense to a Super Bowl title, has died. He was 55. Siragusaâ€™s broadcast agent, Jim Ornstein, confirmed the death Wednesday. The cause of death was not immediately available. â€œThis is a really sad day,â€ he said. â€œTony was way more than my client, he was family. My heart goes out to Tonyâ€™s loved ones.â€ Siragusa, known as â€œthe Goose,â€ played seven seasons with the Indianapolis Colts and five with the Ravens. Baltimoreâ€™s 2000 team won the Super Bowl behind a defense that included Siragusa, Ray Lewis and Sam Adams. The Goose,Tony Siracusa has passed away at 55.. Iâ€™m heart broken as is all of Colts Nationâ¤ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ¼ğŸˆ Siragusa was popular with fans because of his fun-loving personality, which also helped him transition quickly to broadcasting after his playing career. Siragusa came to Baltimore as a free agent in 1997 and teamed up with Adams to form an imposing defensive tackle tandem. In the Ravensâ€™ 2000 championship season, the 6-foot-3, 340-pound Siragusa was sixth among Baltimore defenders with 75 tackles. He finished his career with 22 sacks. The news of Siragusaâ€™s death came on what was already a tragic day for the Ravens. The death of Jaylon Ferguson, a linebacker for Baltimore, at age 26 was announced earlier in the day.

topic: Bill Nye The Science Guy Is Now A Married Man
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Bill Nye is celebrating his first month as a married man. The host of the long-running â€œBill Nye the Science Guyâ€ TV series tied the knot with journalist and author Liza Mundy in May, People confirmed Wednesday. The ceremony took place in the Enid A. Haupt Garden of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., and was officiated by â€œStar Trek: Voyagerâ€ actor Robert Picardo. Photos of the nuptials were taken by former White House photographer Pete Souza. The couple wrote their own vows, which one attendee described as â€œequal parts moving and comical.â€ Mundy, a former Washington Post reporter, mentioned Nyeâ€™s mother, cryptanalyst Jacqueline Jenkins-Nye, in her 2017 book, â€œCode Girls: The Untold Story of the American Women Code Breakers of World War II.â€ Nye emailed Mundy following the release of the book, and the two began dating shortly afterward. The pair have kept their relationship mostly private. Last week, they attended the premiere of Nyeâ€™s new Peacock series, â€œThe End Is Nye,â€ at the 2022 Tribeca Film Festival in New York. And in March, Mundy was by Nyeâ€™s side at the Captain Planet Foundationâ€™s 30th anniversary gala, a nonprofit organization in Atlanta. â€œThe End Is Nyeâ€ due out Aug. 25, will feature Nye as he explores â€œthe most epic global disasters imaginable â€• both natural and unnatural â€• and then demystifies them using science to show how we can survive, mitigate, and even prevent them,â€ according to press notes. The six-episode series will include guest appearances by Seth MacFarlane, who is also an executive producer. Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: These Republicans Resisted Trumpâ€™s Attempt To Steal The Election. Theyâ€™d Vote For Him Again.
content:
Reporter, HuffPost Rusty Bowers, the Republican speaker of the Arizona state House of Representatives, on Tuesday detailed his efforts to thwart former President Donald Trumpâ€™s attempt to steal the 2020 presidential election in stirring testimony to a select congressional committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Bowers told the committee that Trump and his lawyers failed to produce any evidence of fraud, and that they asked him to ignore the law and overturn the election anyway. He became emotional, at times, as he described the barrage of violent threats he and his family have faced since. Bowers read from a journal entry he wrote in December 2020, in which he completely dismissed the then-presidentâ€™s efforts to undermine democracy: â€œI do not want to be a winner by cheating,â€ he wrote. â€œI will not play with laws I swore allegiance to.â€ Hours later, Bowers said he would vote for Trump again. â€œIf he is the nominee, if he was up against Biden, Iâ€™d vote for him again,â€ Bowers told The Associated Press. â€œSimply because what he did the first time, before COVID, was so good for the county. In my view it was great.â€ Bowers was among a small group of Republican elected officials who broke with Trump and refused to go along with the plot to overturn the 2020 election. Now, he is the latest among them to suggest that he would still support Trump in a future contest, even as the former president and his Republican allies intensify their efforts to undermine American democracy. Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, who refused Trumpâ€™s infamous request to â€œfindâ€ the votes necessary to overturn his stateâ€™s election results, did not rule out another vote for Trump in an interview with HuffPost last year. â€œI think thatâ€™s so far out in the future, I donâ€™t even think heâ€™s announced heâ€™s running yet,â€ Raffensperger, who testified alongside Bowers on Tuesday, said in November. â€œSo letâ€™s circle back and talk about that in the future.â€ Raffensperger did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s inquiry on Wednesday. And former Attorney General Bill Barr, who tried to convince Trump that his fraud claims were baseless, said in March that he would support his old boss if Trump were the 2024 Republican nominee. â€œI certainly have made it clear I donâ€™t think he should be our nominee, and Iâ€™m going to support somebody else for the nomination,â€ Barr said on the â€œTodayâ€ show. But, he added, â€œbecause I believe that the greatest threat to the country is the progressive agenda being pushed by the Democratic Party, itâ€™s inconceivable to me that I wouldnâ€™t vote for the Republican nominee.â€ During Tuesdayâ€™s hearing, Bowers described Trumpâ€™s haphazard attempt to overturn the 2020 election as a â€œtragic parody.â€ But since his unwilling departure from the presidency, Trump and his allies within the GOP have launched a far more coordinated and deliberate assault on democracy, with the apparent aim of taking control of the countryâ€™s electoral system in a way that could make it far more likely that a future attempt to undermine an election actually succeeds. Republican election deniers have lined up to run for major statewide offices and congressional seats across the country, with the key swing states that decided the 2020 contest as their chief focus. Candidates who have spread conspiracies about Trumpâ€™s defeat have already won primaries in major battlegrounds: The GOP nominee for governor in Pennsylvania attempted to overturn the 2020 results in his state, while the Republican winner in Nevadaâ€™s secretary of state primary questioned the legitimacy of the outcome and has built a coalition of like-minded candidates in an attempt to â€œtake backâ€ control of the American election system. Dozens of Republicans who have embraced Trumpâ€™s lies have won congressional primaries, and the GOP is likely to nominate election deniers in statewide primaries in Colorado, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin. In May, Raffensperger survived a Republican primary against a Trump-endorsed challenger who twice voted to contest the results of the 2020 election in Congress, and accused Raffensperger of â€œcompromisingâ€ Georgiaâ€™s elections by refusing to help Trump overturn it. In Bowersâ€™ Arizona, meanwhile, upcoming GOP primaries for governor and secretary of state have been dominated by candidates who have spread conspiracies about the last election or refused to commit to the certification of future contests. The grip Trump and his election lies hold on the GOP has inspired deep fears among experts who worry that American democracy is far more vulnerable ahead of the next presidential contest than it was in 2020, especially as the former president sets the stage to run again. Trump has continued to hold campaign-style rallies since he left the White House, and he hinted at a possible 2024 run as recently as last week. A majority of Republican voters said they would support him in the GOP primary if he does run, according to a recent poll from Morning Consult. And Trump has made it clear that his loss in the 2020 election â€” as well as his failed effort to overturn the results â€” would be the driving theme in his next campaign. â€œWeâ€™re not forgetting 2020,â€ Trump said at a Georgia rally in October. â€œThe most corrupt election in the history of our country. Most corrupt election in the history of most countries, to be followed by an even more glorious victory in November of 2024.â€ Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Filmmaker Alika Tengan Is Giving Native Hawaiians A Bigger Spotlight
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost This profile is part of our Culture Shifters series, which highlights people who are changing the way we think about the world around us. Read about film archivist Maya Cade, internet star Keyon Elkins, rapper LatashÃ¡, music historian Katelina Eccleston and artist Kay Rufai. Alika Tengan was itching to make something in 2020, after a film he was hoping to shoot that year was sidelined because of the pandemic. That fall, his friend, freelance journalist Naz Kawakami, told him some big news: He was planning to move to New York in early 2021. The two decided it would be interesting to make a movie about leaving home, and the idea for â€œEvery Day in KaimukÄ«â€ was born. That dilemma of whether to leave the familiar and take a leap into the unknown is a tale as old as time. But as Tengan explained over Zoom, â€œthat conversation is especially interesting in the backdrop of Hawaii,â€ where both of them were born and raised. â€œBecause heâ€™s a mixed Native Hawaiian guy like myself â€” heâ€™s Japanese and Native Hawaiian â€” we had similar perspectives on feeling Hawaiian but not Hawaiian enough, Japanese but not Japanese enough. I think we related a lot in that way. And he has also lived here his whole life, and so moving for him was a big deal, as it is for many of us in Hawaii,â€ Tengan said. â€œI think being Hawaiian and not feeling Hawaiian enough can give you a rootlessness, and it makes the decision to leave easier in some ways, and more complicated in some ways too.â€ They initially discussed making a documentary, but then decided to dramatize some elements â€œjust to make it a little more compelling or interesting,â€ such as adding some composite characters and having Kawakami play a more heightened version of himself. The filmâ€™s cast is a mix of trained actors and Kawakamiâ€™s real friends. â€œEvery Day in KaimukÄ«â€ premiered in the Next category at this yearâ€™s Sundance Film Festival in January, the first Native Hawaiian feature-length film to premiere at Sundance. Itâ€™s a heartfelt slice-of-life portrait imbued with a sense of place and identity â€” while not solely being about that. The movie evokes many classic genres and familiar experiences. Among other things, itâ€™s a â€œhangoutâ€ movie, a â€œdeciding whether to leave homeâ€ movie and a â€œbeing a 20-something person figuring out adulthoodâ€ movie â€” that happens to center a Native Hawaiian protagonist. There are moments of humor, especially in Naz dealing with the logistical nightmares of moving, like selling his stuff on Craigslist and getting stuck on multiple phone calls with his airline to confirm he can safely bring his cat on the long flight. Heâ€™s also trying to savor his final moments with his friends and pastimes, like skateboarding and being a late-night DJ at the community radio station. â€œItâ€™s really accurate to living in Hawaii and our experiences and our actual relationships and the way that being Asian, being Hawaiian, being mixed is so endemic to our everyday, as to not even be a part of the conversation,â€ Tengan said. â€œIt just is.â€ For independent filmmakers, a Sundance premiere has long been a huge career moment. Tengan had been excited to head to the snowy peaks of Park City, Utah. But sadly, the omicron surge forced the festival to go completely virtual for the second year in a row. â€œThat was tough. I still donâ€™t know if Iâ€™ve gotten over it, the big pivot, but it is what it is,â€ he said. Thankfully, he has been able to take the film to several in-person festivals this spring, such as the Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival and the Center for Asian American Mediaâ€™s CAAMFest in San Francisco, where it was the closing-night film. He also hopes to find a streaming home for it so that it can be seen more widely. Tengan, 34, is proud to be part of a growing wave of Native Hawaiian filmmakers. Historically, a lot of Hawaiiâ€™s film industry has been driven by outside productions filming there, he said. But over the last few years, he has been happy to see more interest in and financial support for local talent. â€œI think thereâ€™s an incredible wave of local Hawaiian filmmakers that are about to just be coming up over the next couple of years. And itâ€™s a really exciting time for all that,â€ he said. â€œThe more that we share our stories that are just specific to our experiences growing up here, itâ€™s generating more interest in those types of stories as well. So thereâ€™s more support, more money â€” itâ€™s this reciprocal thing.â€ Itâ€™s something heâ€™s been trying to do throughout his career. Born and raised in Kaneohe, on the east side of the island of Oahu, Tengan studied film at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. His first film professor, a groundbreaking MÄori filmmaker named Merata Mita, â€œexposed us to Indigenous cinema. I hadnâ€™t been studying art house films my whole life. It took me a while to get into that world. So the concept of indigenous cinema was very new to me,â€ he said. Mita, an early supporter of director Taika Waititi, showed Tenganâ€™s class Waititiâ€™s Oscar-nominated short â€œTwo Cars, One Night,â€ which hugely influenced Tengan. Another one of Tenganâ€™s professors, Lisette Flanary, who plays a small role in â€œEvery Day in KaimukÄ«,â€ invited Waititi to speak to her class in 2010, the year his breakthrough film â€œBoyâ€ premiered. â€œThat was also another huge moment for me, to see this Polynesian filmmaker talking about this film that was so specific to where he grew up, but also so charming and funny and light and all of these other things,â€ Tengan said. â€œAnd I wanted to do that for Hawaii. I felt we could do that here because we have a richness of character and story. So thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve been wanting to do ever since.â€ When he graduated in 2013, he wasnâ€™t sure exactly how to get into the film business. Adding to his uncertainty, he was gravely injured in a car accident, which sidelined him for several years. â€œI did a lot of intense soul-searching, I think, during that time. Because even when I was in film school, I was like, â€˜Am I cut out for this?â€™ and trying to figure out where I fit into the filmmaking ecosystem. Was I going to be an editor, or a writer, or a DP, or director? I had a lot of uncertainty in film school, and then the accident happened. So there was a lot of repurposing and reconfiguring what I wanted out of life.â€ When he felt ready to get back into filmmaking, a friend told him that HBOâ€™s annual short film contest for emerging Asian American and Pacific Islander filmmakers was taking submissions. â€œIt was a really good prompt for me to be like, â€˜OK, letâ€™s try to make something,â€™ because deadlines are everything,â€ Tengan said. Tengan pulled out a script he had written back in film school, â€œKeep You Float,â€ and called up an old classmate, Jonah Okano. The two co-directed the short in 2016, shooting it in one day. It started a theme in Tenganâ€™s career: deadlines, scrappiness, and working with his friends. The short, about a group of friends deciding where to scatter their late friendâ€™s ashes, was accepted into a local festival, the â€™Ohina Short Film Showcase. Tengan and other participating filmmakers got to attend a writers workshop, led by â€œBlack Pantherâ€ co-writer Joe Robert Cole. Tenganâ€™s work impressed Cole, who went on to advise him on his next short film, â€œMauka to Makai,â€ which Tengan wrote and shot in 2018. â€œJoe was amazing. It had happened right before â€˜Black Pantherâ€™ was coming out. And I didnâ€™t think heâ€™d be available at all because heâ€™d be one of the busiest people in the world. But he still really made time to help me and go over the script with me and gave really thoughtful notes. And weâ€™re still in touch. Heâ€™s a wonderful guy.â€ In March 2019, â€œMauka to Makaiâ€ played at the MÄoriland Film Festival, a major Indigenous film festival in New Zealand. That was another formative experience for Tengan. During the festival, his roommate was a fellow Hawaiian artist, cinematographer Chapin Hall, who went on to shoot â€œEvery Day in KaimukÄ«.â€ The two bonded and decided they wanted to work together. â€œChapin was like, â€˜I have my camera gear with me, and Iâ€™m going to be in Hawaii for about a week before I have to fly back to LA for a job,â€™â€ Tengan said. â€œIf I could write something in a week, he was down to shoot it. And again, deadlines are everything. So I was like, â€˜OK, great. Letâ€™s try to do something.â€™â€ Tengan wrote what became â€œMolokaâ€™i Bound.â€ It came together quickly, in part because it starred Holden Mandrial-Santos, the star of â€œMauka to Makai,â€ who is also Tenganâ€™s roommate and friend. The two attended the same high school and had similar upbringings, which helped Mandrial-Santos convey what Tengan was looking for in a star for his films. In another personal connection, they shot â€œMolokaâ€™i Boundâ€ on the steps of Tenganâ€™s old elementary school. â€œMolokaâ€™i Boundâ€ won the award for best live-action short film at the 2019 ImagineNATIVE Film Festival in Toronto, which qualified it for Oscar consideration. (Itâ€™s available to stream on The Criterion Channel.) Tengan had written the short, which consists of just one scene, intending it as â€œa jumping-off point, proof-of-concept type of thingâ€ for a feature film. With the success of the short, he wrote the script for the feature, which was selected for the 2020 Indigenous List, an offshoot of the Black List, the annual list of the best unproduced screenplays. By early 2020, the wheels were in motion to potentially start shooting the feature version of â€œMolokaâ€™i Bound.â€ But the pandemic upended those plans. Tengan found himself spinning his wheels, until he and Kawakami, whom he met a few years prior when Kawakami interviewed him for a story about the local film scene, started talking about their potential project. Once again, another deadline motivated Tengan to make the film. â€œAfter we both agreed that we wanted to do this, I had gone to his house, and I took my phone out and I recorded a voice memo. And I was just like, â€˜Tell me everything that led up to this moment for you to make this decision,â€™â€ Tengan said. â€œWe had that meeting around Thanksgiving in 2020. And because he mentioned that he was going to move in basically February or March, there was already a built-in ticking clock.â€ While continuing to bring â€œEvery Day in KaimukÄ«â€ to more festivals and find a distributor for it, Tengan is back to work on â€œMolokaâ€™i Bound,â€ for which he was awarded a $500,000 grant from Ava DuVernayâ€™s company Array and Google. He aims to shoot the film later this year, with Mandrial-Santos reprising his role. Once again, Tengan wants to cast a mix of professional and nonprofessional actors, which he says gives his films â€œa really interesting alchemy.â€ â€œI really love working with nonactors, especially for these types of films, because I think they bring something ineffable to the screen and something thatâ€™s really hard to cast for, because these roles are so specific.â€ Now with more support and a bigger profile, Tengan admits to feeling a bit of pressure. â€œItâ€™s the most ambitious thing Iâ€™ve ever done, so itâ€™s scary. Itâ€™s scary and nerve-wracking. And Iâ€™m also used to, I think, making things under the radar. So this probably wonâ€™t be under the radar, to an extent. And Iâ€™m trying to manage my expectations or feelings about that. Iâ€™ve never had expectations before. I hope that we can live up to them.â€ Adding to that pressure is his mission to keep supporting the growth of more Native Hawaiian filmmakers. â€œIâ€™m super grateful to be in this position because we worked really hard to get here. A lot of people were a part of that, and I just want to justify peopleâ€™s faith in what weâ€™re doing. I donâ€™t want to waste peopleâ€™s time, because people have been really supportive. The local film community is so supportive. And so yeah, it needs to be good for them â€” for everybody.â€ Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Kay Rufai Has Created A Safe Space For Black Boy Joy
content: Senior Culture Reporter This profile is part of our Culture Shifters series, which highlights people who are changing the way we think about the world around us. Read about film archivist Maya Cade, internet star Keyon Elkins, rapper LatashÃ¡, music historian Katelina Eccleston and filmmaker Alika Tengan. Itâ€™s around 8 p.m. in London, though you couldnâ€™t tell itâ€™s that late on a February evening by looking at artist Kay Rufai. He pops onto our Zoom call with such a wave of positive energy â€” sporting a lime green shirt with a matching hat, a gold chain necklace and a megawatt smile â€” that you might assume itâ€™s more like high noon where he is. â€œItâ€™s been a good day,â€ he said, settling into a self-made soundproof booth in his home. â€œItâ€™s been a busy day, but a good day.â€ An indication of how Rufai, 38, spends his stuffed weekdays is perched right behind him in the cubicle: a row of images of Black and brown boys grinning from ear to ear. â€œTheyâ€™re ever-present,â€ he said pleasantly. He is referring to his groundbreaking S.M.I.L.E-ING Boys Project, a photographic well-being initiative specifically designed for Black and brown boys in the Swinging City who are often reduced to dehumanizing stereotypes with no concern for their mental health. Rufaiâ€™s ongoing research-led project helps boys access their joy and other aspects of their interior selves around which they often put up boundaries. Their guardedness is typically a defense mechanism against a city that, even amid todayâ€™s cultural reckoning, largely skirts around issues of race, particularly when it comes to the police. â€œFor example, situations around violence, especially youth violence, is very racialized in the way itâ€™s reported,â€ Rufai said. â€œBut when thereâ€™s anything thatâ€™s speaking on the experiences of Black people, or people of minoritized or global majority groups, people get very uncomfortable.â€ Some of the words used to refer to Black and brown boys in the media, he says, â€œare so nondescript.â€ That language bunches kids together with no care for who they are as individuals. It particularly dismays Rufai because he grew up in some of the same neighborhoods where these boys live, in the same circumstances as many of them. He has also worked with young people who have been in and out of prison or in gangs. â€œI knew that these are not deterrents,â€ he said. â€œWe know what the recidivism rates are. I wanted to create a project that was rooted in centering the mental health disproportionalities,â€ since â€œno doubt violence is a manifestation of that.â€ It becomes clear that this is a cause close to Rufaiâ€™s heart. â€œAggressive behavior, or all these other things that are perceived as aggressive behavior or dangerous behavior,â€ he said. â€œAll these other things were manifestations of lack of mental health provisions for this demographic.â€ The S.M.I.L.E-ING Boys Project â€• the acronym stands for Send Me Inspiring Loving Energy â€• creates a safe space for boys to be their full selves, opening up dialogues around topics like aesthetics, money, health and masculinity. Ultimately, the idea is to empower the boys to walk confidently in their truths each day. Rufai captures that sense of freedom by the end of this eight-week process, when the boysâ€™ smiling faces practically beam out of his photographs. But first, he has to meet them where they are psychologically and emotionally â€• typically in a school setting â€• and establish a mutual trust. â€œSo, I walk into a classroom with 13-year-old boys, and I let them know that your voice is equally as valid as mine,â€ he explained. â€œYou donâ€™t have to respect me because Iâ€™m older. You just have to respect me because you command respect and therefore you give the same to me.â€ Once Rufai establishes this level playing field, the boys begin to behave in ways that feel more comfortable to them at this stage â€” whether that means throwing in a swear word here and there, expressing fear, sadness or anger, or vocalizing a thought that was previously difficult for them to share. The one caveat: Rufai can challenge them on what they say and encourage them to think more deeply about things, even if the subject is him. â€œAround the third session, I ask them what they really thought about me when I first stepped into the room wearing all these bright clothes,â€ Rufai recalled. â€œAnd a lot of the times they say, â€˜I thought you were gay. I thought you was, whatever.â€™ Iâ€™m not going to be offended by it.â€ Instead, he empowers them to explain how they came to that perspective: â€œIâ€™m just really interested in what you thought. â€˜We thought you were so non-masculine because you wore yellow, pink and all of this.â€™ We start to unpack that.â€ Rufaiâ€™s own youth is part of why heâ€™s made it his lifeâ€™s work to embolden Black boys to use their voices to unlock who they really are, regardless of what they believe or have been told to believe about themselves. A son of Nigerian immigrants, the artist, born with the first name Adekunle, was always taught two things: Go to university, and become a doctor. â€œMake your life worth living,â€ he said. To be fair, Rufai tried that route. He took some coursework and was on a path to study medicine. But by the third year, he became frustrated and restless. â€œI didnâ€™t want to study that,â€ he recalled. â€œI absolutely hated being in the university.â€ He channeled that agitation into his then-untapped creative side. â€œWhile I was there, I spent a lot more time writing and expressing myself,â€ he said. â€œI would just escape. Even though [I was] in the physical confines of a lecture hall, I would mentally and emotionally and spiritually be elsewhere, writing and creating.â€ This allowed Rufai to tap into, and eventually nurture, his artistic passions like poetry, photography and music. But it also meant he would have to dive into some of his own vulnerabilities that he protected from the world around him. These included growing up without his father and navigating life as a Black boy and young man. It wasnâ€™t until later in life that Rufai realized he was using these outlets as his own path toward mental health, and â€œas a tool to help process some of the complex emotions that I had,â€ he said. â€œBecause I was very aware of the range of emotions that I was navigating through, but I didnâ€™t actually have language for most of it.â€ But he found himself more and more drawn to these artistic expressions as he continued to experience life â€• primarily in London, but also in Nigeria and the United States. It gave him something he felt he was missing for a long time. â€œI really gravitated to music,â€ he said. â€œIt kind of filled that void. I listened to voices of people like Lauryn Hill and Tupac [Shakur], who were significant staples for me growing up in terms of understanding myself and my identity as a Black kid and really navigating those expressions.â€ You could describe what came later for Rufai as double-edged. He dropped out of university to begin performing and honing his art, which filled him with unbridled joy. But that shift was met with his motherâ€™s disapproval, which he says made it â€œa very tough period.â€ Still, betting on himself ended up being an invaluable move for him, and for so many others like him. Because when Rufai, restless once again, decided that he wanted his art to engage with Black boys like him on a more intimate level, he gave them permission to actively and intentionally seek their own happiness with initiatives like the S.M.I.L.E-ing Boys Project. â€œI created this project because the 13-year-old version of myself needed it,â€ Rufai said. He admits that looking after his mental health is still a conscious effort on his part each day. Since he hasnâ€™t been able to travel as much as heâ€™d like in the pandemic, heâ€™s relied on walking along the river near his home and turning on some music and dancing in the living room. â€œIâ€™m moonwalking and just being full of joy in my physical being and my body,â€ he laughed. â€œI really just enjoy listening to music that brings joy to my soul. Knowing that a lot of the work that I do is outwardly exerting, I recognize that I have to feed this so that I can be of service.â€ Still, being in a classroom with boys, seeing them begin to open up, remains his most significant source of joy â€” one that took him much soul-searching to accomplish, and one that has gifted him with other cultural initiatives around London in addition to his own self-fulfillment. â€œThis work that I do is a radical reinstatement of joy in my life,â€ Rufai beams. â€œCurating a space of Black boys that look like me and like each other, for them to be playful, fun. For me to get to be a kid again â€” because Iâ€™m there jumping on chairs, and we play games together.â€ He pauses, before adding proudly: â€œWe speak openly. We bond. That brings so much joy to me.â€ Senior Culture Reporter

topic: Jennifer Lopez Introduces Child Emme With They/Them Pronouns Before Sweet Duet
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Jennifer Lopez performed a beautiful duet recently with one of her 14-year-old twins, Emme MuÃ±iz, whom she introduced using gender-neutral pronouns. â€œThe last time we performed together was in a big stadium like this and I ask them to sing with me all the time, and they wonâ€™t,â€ the actor and singer said onstage at the Los Angeles Dodgers Foundationâ€™s Blue Diamond Gala on Thursday. â€œSo this is a very special occasion. They are very, very busy. Booked. And pricey. They cost me when they come out. But theyâ€™re worth every single penny because theyâ€™re my favorite duet partner of all time. So if you will indulge me.â€ Social media videos show the two singing Christina Perriâ€™s â€œA Thousand Yearsâ€ together. Watch @JLo sing with her daughter, Emme @LADForg Blue Diamond Gala, simply beautiful! pic.twitter.com/nZDxhYdEAp In another clip, Emme sings Bruce Springsteenâ€™s â€œBorn in the U.S.A.â€ with Lopez and belts out a solo section of Lopezâ€™s famous hit â€œLetâ€™s Get Loud.â€ I'm not crying, you areğŸ˜­ğŸ’–ğŸ’šEmme and @JLo #LetsGetLoud pic.twitter.com/J3SmtzHag7 The two have performed together before, including at the Super Bowl in 2020. Lopez coparents Emme and their twin brother Max with her ex-husband, Marc Anthony. The couple divorced in 2014. CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article referred to the event as the Los Angeles Dance Foundation gala. It was the Los Angeles Dodgers Foundationâ€™s Blue Diamond Gala. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Seth Meyers Pinpoints Red Flag That Showed Jan. 6 Plan Was 'Truly F**king Insane'
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost You know your plan is â€œtruly fucking crazyâ€ when even Rudy Giuliani thinks itâ€™s a bad idea, according to â€œLate Nightâ€ host Seth Meyers. In its third of six hearings, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021 U.S. Capitol attack painted a picture last week of how John Eastman, a lawyer for Donald Trump, helped the then-president craft a plan to overturn the 2020 election by using Vice President Mike Pence. The committee played testimony from Eric Herschmann, a lawyer and former senior adviser to Trump, who said he received a call on the morning of Jan. 6 from Giuliani, Trumpâ€™s personal attorney at the time. Herschmann said Giuliani ultimately conceded that Pence probably didnâ€™t have the authority to do what Trump and Eastman were suggesting. â€œItâ€™s incredible to me that even Rudy knew it was a crazy and bad idea,â€ Meyers said Monday. â€œRudy. Thatâ€™s how you know your plan is truly fucking insane. This is a guy who, while under multiple investigations, thought it was good idea to do a video using an Abraham Lincoln filter. That same guy looked at John Eastmanâ€™s plan and said, â€˜I donâ€™t know.â€™â€ After Pence refused to comply, a mob of Trumpâ€™s supporters laid siege to the Capitol, with some chanting for him to be hung. At one point, the crowd of rioters were within 40 feet of Pence inside the Capitol. Check out more of Meyersâ€™ roast below: Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Shiloh Jolie-Pitt Dances To Doja Cat In Viral Studio Clip
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Shiloh Jolie-Pitt has solid dance moves to go with her celebrity genes. (Watch the video below.) The 16-year-old daughter of Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt shows them off in a viral video of several dancers at Millennium Dance Complex performing to Doja Catâ€™s â€œVegasâ€ from the new movie â€œElvis.â€ The teen, wearing a Beatles T-shirt, nails the fast-paced hip-hop moves in the clip, posted recently by choreographer Hamilton Evans. Jolie-Pitt is one of six children shared by the two famous actors, who are still locked in legal battles after their 2019 divorce. Millennium bills itself as â€œHollywoodâ€™s hottest dance studioâ€ and â€œthe premiere studio of the commercial dance world.â€ The likes of Britney Spears and Jennifer Lopez have appeared there, Today.com reported. Jolie-Pitt has a few movie credits â€• as the voice of Shuai Shuai in 2016â€™s â€œKung Fu Panda 3â€ and as a baby in her dadâ€™s 2008 movie â€œThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button,â€ according to IMDb. But perhaps her entertainment calling is dance. An unnamed â€œinsiderâ€ told Us Weekly that Mom and Dad â€œare both very proudâ€ of her dancing but not â€œpushingâ€ it on her. Fast-forward to 2:30 for Jolie-Pittâ€™s performance: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Scandal-Plagued Actor Makes First Red Carpet Appearance In Years
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Lori Loughlin returned to the red carpet for the first time in years on Saturday at a benefit in Los Angeles. Loughlin, the former â€œFull Houseâ€ star who served time in prison for a college admissions bribery scandal and has kept mostly a low profile since, had cameras clicking at the DesignCare 2022 Gala to benefit the HollyRod Foundation for families affected by autism and Parkinsonâ€™s disease. Loughlin wore a long-sleeved blue dress for the occasion, her first â€œred carpetâ€ walk (on what appears to be a purple carpet this time) since the scandal broke in March 2019, People reported. In March 2019, Loughlin and designer husband Mossimo Giannulli were arrested for attempting to game the higher-education admissions process. The two paid $500,000 to a fixer to have their daughters, Olivia Jade Giannulli and Isabella Rose Giannulli, accepted to the University of Southern California as crew athletes, even though neither participated in the sport. Loughlin served nearly two months in prison, gaining release in December 2020. Giannulli completed a longer sentence. Loughlin made her return to television in a â€œWhen Calls the Heartâ€ spinoff last December on GAC Family. She reportedly attended â€œFull Houseâ€ co-star Bob Sagetâ€™s private funeral in January and appeared on Instagram Live earlier this month to promote Netflixâ€™s Comedy Store tribute to the late comedian, TMZ noted. One of Loughlinâ€™s last red carpet appearances before the nationwide sting snared her, fellow actor Felicity Huffman and other prominent parents participating in admissions bribery, was with her daughters at a Womenâ€™s Cancer Research Fund event in February 2019 in Beverly Hills. General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost
