topic: Man Who Filmed Self Screaming His Name In Capitol Riot Sentenced
content: Reporter, HuffPost Former West Virginia state lawmaker Derrick Evans was sentenced to three months on Wednesday for his part in the U.S. Capitol attack last year. Evans had livestreamed himself joining the throng of Donald Trump supporters as some individuals smashed their way into the building and then opened the Rotunda doors for the rest of the mob. He narrated his exploits as he went along, shouting â€œTrump,â€ â€œThe doorâ€™s cracked,â€ and â€œWeâ€™re goinâ€™ in!â€ â€œWeâ€™re in! Derrick Evans is in the Capitol!â€ he said once he made it though the doors. Evans later deleted the video, but it featured prominently in prosecutorsâ€™ case against him. After initially pleading not guilty, defending himself by saying he â€œcommitted no criminal act,â€ Evans took a plea deal. He told Judge Royce C. Lamberth that he accepts responsibility for his actions, seated nearby a large Evans family photo, according to NBC News. Lamberth reportedly wished Evans well, telling him that he considered sentencing Evans to six months behind bars. Evansâ€™ attorney had asked for no jail time. â€œI just canâ€™t give you probation in a case like this ... it doesnâ€™t reflect the feeling in the country,â€ the judge said, according to CBS News reporter Rob Legare. â€œI donâ€™t want another riot in the next election,â€ Lamberth added. At the time of the riot, the father of four had recently been elected to represent West Virginians in the stateâ€™s House of Delegates. Three days later, he was forced to resign. After releasing a very brief statement announcing his resignation, Evans released a second, slightly longer statement expressing regret, writing, â€œI take full responsibility for my actions, and deeply regret any hurt, pain or embarrassment I may have caused my family, friends, constituents and fellow West Virginians.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: NBA 'Mean Tweets' Are Meaner Than Ever on 'Jimmy Kimmel Live'
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost The NBA edition of â€œMean Tweetsâ€ tipped off on the same day the Golden State Warriors moved ahead 3 games to 2 in the NBA Finals against the Boston Celtics. There were winners on Twitter as well â€• if you like random fans taunting players with expletives and nasty burns on â€œJimmy Kimmel Live.â€ (Watch it below.) Stars including Russell Westbrook, Ja Morant and Zach LaVine read the insults and clapped back, but Jarrett Allen may have endured the unkindest cut of all: that he looks like Shaggy from â€œScooby-Dooâ€ when he runs. General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Chris Evans Gets Flustered Trying To Clarify His Most Perplexing Tweet
content: Assignment editor, HuffPost Chris Evans appeared on â€œJimmy Kimmel Liveâ€ Friday and tried to clarify an old tweet that got memed to infinity and beyond. The Boston-born actor was promoting the upcoming Pixar movie â€œLightyear,â€ in which he voices Buzz Lightyear â€• a character many viewers likely remember from the â€œToy Storyâ€ series. Well, sort of. â€œThereâ€™s some confusion about this movie, partially fueled by you,â€ Kimmel said, before bringing out images of two of Evansâ€™ tweets from 2020. The Marvel star had retweeted a trailer for â€œLightyearâ€ with the comment, â€œI donâ€™t even have the words.â€ He actually did have a few more words, though, and followed up with a second tweet that said: â€œAnd just to be clear, this isnâ€™t Buzz Lightyear the toy. This is the origin story of the human Buzz Lightyear that the toy is based on.â€ And just to be clear, this isnâ€™t Buzz Lightyear the toy. This is the origin story of the human Buzz Lightyear that the toy is based on At the time, Evansâ€™ tweet led to some head-scratching and a lot of jokes. (me pitching to a bored executive on Zoom)And just to be clear, this isnâ€™t Capâ€™n Crunch the cereal. This is the origin story of the human Capâ€™n Crunch that the cereal is based on. â€œAll right, well, OK,â€ Evans stammered, laughing, when Kimmel confronted him with the old posts. â€œNow, just â€• OK, you know, itâ€™s a shame. I proofread that like five times!â€ He then added some more context, saying the new film was envisioned as the in-universe movie that Andy and friends in â€œToy Storyâ€ watched that got them interested in Buzz Lightyear toys. Watch his explanation above, with the exchange about his tweet starting at 3:17. Assignment editor, HuffPost

topic: Watch 'Sound Of Music' Stars Surprise Julie Andrews With A 'Do-Re-Mi' Singalong
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Hollywoodâ€™s hills were alive with the sound of music this week in celebration of Julie Andrews and her six-decade movie career. The â€œMary Poppinsâ€ actor received the American Film Instituteâ€™s Life Achievement Award Thursday night in Los Angeles. The ceremony took place at the Dolby Theatre after a two-year delay due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Cynthia Erivo honored Andrews with a musical performance, while actors Hector Elizondo and Anne Hathaway â€• who appeared alongside Andrews in â€œThe Princess Diariesâ€ â€• also offered tributes. The eveningâ€™s most buzzed-about moment, however, was an onstage reunion of Andrewsâ€™ â€œSound of Musicâ€ co-stars. Angela Cartwright, Duane Chase, Nicholas Hammond, Kym Karath and Debbie Turner â€• who portrayed five of the seven von Trapp children in the 1965 movie musical â€• led the crowd in a singalong of â€œDo-Re-Miâ€ from the film. The Hollywood Reporterâ€™s Scott Feinberg captured the heartwarming moment in a video posted to social media. Julie Andrews is surprised by her kids from THE SOUND OF MUSIC and joins them in a sing-a-long of â€˜Do-Re-Miâ€™ to kick off the AFI Life Achievement Award presentation to her â€” what a beautiful moment! pic.twitter.com/TZYT7UNPhr Andrewsâ€™ iconic performance as Maria von Trapp in â€œThe Sound of Musicâ€ came just one year after she won an Academy Award for â€œMary Poppins.â€ The movie depicts the real-life von Trapp familyâ€™s escape from Nazi-occupied Austria shortly before World War II. It received five Oscars, including Best Picture and Best Director for Robert Wise. Sadly, not every member of the onscreen von Trapp family was in attendance. Christopher Plummer, who played Captain Georg von Trapp, died last year at age 91. Actors Charmian Carr and Heather Menzies, who portrayed Liesl and Louisa von Trapp, died in 2016 and 2017 at ages 73 and 68, respectively. Andrews has been enjoying a period of heightened visibility lately, thanks in part to Netflixâ€™s â€œBridgerton,â€ which she narrates as the intriguingly haughty Lady Whistledown. This summer, she provides the voice of Marlena Gru in â€œMinions: The Rise of Gru.â€ Speaking to â€œEntertainment Tonightâ€ Thursday, Andrews said she loves voice-over roles, joking, â€œI donâ€™t have to get into makeup and hair in the morning if I donâ€™t want to.â€ Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Nipsey Hussle's Last Moments Detailed As Murder Trial Opens
content: LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” Rapper Nipsey Hussle was gunned down outside his clothing shop in a calculated, premeditated fashion by a man upset over a discussion about snitching, a prosecutor told jurors Monday at the outset of of a long-delayed murder trial. Deputy District Attorney John McKinney said during his opening statement Wednesday that thereâ€™s â€œno doubtâ€ Eric R. Holder knew in advance that he would kill Hussle. The prosecutor described the sequence of events, including the talk about â€œsnitching,â€ before Hussleâ€™s shooting death three years ago in the South Los Angeles neighborhood where both men grew up and the rapper was helping revitalize. Two others were wounded in the shooting. In addition to shooting Hussle at least 10 times, Holder kicked the rapper in the head before fleeing, McKinney told the jury assembled in a downtown Los Angeles courtroom. â€œHe clearly thought about what he was going to do before he did it,â€ McKinney told jurors about Holderâ€™s intentions. Holder, 32, faces one count of first degree-murder and two counts of attempted first-degree murder. Hussle, a hip-hop artist, father of two, and widely beloved South LA local born Ermias Asghedom, was shot and killed at age 33 on March 31, 2019, in the parking lot outside his store, known as The Marathon. McKinney said Holder and Hussle knew each other, growing up in the same neighborhood where they were members of the same gang, the Rollinâ€™ 60s. In his opening statement, McKinney showed jurors videos and photos of the shooting and its aftermath. Images showed the shooting and Holder fleeing the scene, wearing a red shirt and bandana while carrying a semiautomatic gun and a revolver. After a two-day manhunt, Holder was arrested, and two months later he was indicted by a grand jury. McKinney said the shooting stemmed from Hussle hearing that Holder was a snitch and needed to â€œclear that up.â€ Before the shooting, he said the rapper and his two friends were having a â€œcool conversationâ€ with Holder. He said Hussle visited the store without any security. Attorney Aaron Jansen has a formidable task in defending Holder, who could get life in prison if convicted. Multiple eyewitnesses who knew both Holder and Hussle told police and grand jurors that Holder walked up to Hussle and gunned him down. Jansen has said that the killing of Hussle was not premeditated, and the shooting of the other two men was not intended at all, making the first-degree murder and attempted murder charges excessive. He is also likely to make Holderâ€™s mental health an issue. On Wednesday, Jansen said Holder was triggered and didnâ€™t have time to cool off before he gunned down Hussle saying this is a case of â€œheated passion.â€ Former gang member Herman â€œCowboyâ€ Douglas, who worked at The Marathon, said Hussle didnâ€™t use the actual word â€œsnitchâ€ while overhearing the conversation. He thought Hussle was trying to give Holder some advice in a â€œchillâ€ exchange. He said Holder asked Hussle if he had listened to his recent music, but he didnâ€™t sense any animosity between both men. â€œHe was saying â€™I heard there was some paperwork floating around,â€ said Douglas, who recalled Hussleâ€™s words to Holder. Douglas was an employee at the clothing store, cleaning the parking lot along with other duties. He viewed himself as a mentor to Hussle, saying he was like his â€œlittle brother.â€ Douglas, 49, who wore a black jacket and T-shirt with Hussleâ€™s image on both, said Hussle added that â€œI havenâ€™t seen (the paperwork.) You need to take care of that.â€ Another key witness expected to testify is the woman McKnney said unwittingly served as Holderâ€™s getaway driver, Bryannita Nicholson. Holder and Nicholson had stopped to get food near The Marathon. That led to a chance meeting and brief conversation between Holder and Hussle. McKinney said that â€œmoved Eric Holder to a point of wanting to return to the parking lot and kill Nipsey Hussle.â€ McKinney said Holder told Nicholson â€œDrive before I slap you,â€ following the shooting. Attorneys have spent nearly two weeks choosing a jury, and the trial is expected to last about two more weeks. Hussle, whose nickname is a play on a famous 1970s comedian, was given the moniker for his work ethic as he slung CDs. He spent years winning a devoted following through mixtapes and underground releases, and broke through with a his first major-label album, earning a Grammy nomination just months before he was killed. His death reverberated around the world but it was especially felt in his hometown, where people filled the streets to mark his loss and where he was mourned at a memorial at the 20,000-seat arena then known as Staples Center. In the same building nearly a year later his memory was celebrated in a performance by DJ Khaled, Meek Mill John Legend and others at the Grammy Awards, on the same day another local hero, Kobe Bryant, was killed in a helicopter crash. Hussle left behind his longtime partner, actor Lauren London, with whom he had a son who is now 5 years old. He also had a daughter who is now 13.

topic: 'Sex And The City' Deftly Portrayed The Complexity Of Choice
content: Senior Culture Reporter This article is part of a larger series titled â€œThe End Of Roe.â€ Head here to read more. When we consider what makes a great abortion storyline, we often think it has to include a character actually having an abortion. But today when the basic human right is in jeopardy, one that explores the process of deciding whether or not to even have one is also an act of rebellion. Because that in and of itself reflects a system of choice, the very thing that is at risk right now. Never mind back in 2001, when the word â€œabortionâ€ was rarely uttered in real life much less on screen, despite over 1 million abortions reported that year in the U.S. alone. But leave it up to â€œSex and the City,â€ which never shied away from taboo topics that make even some people today uncomfortable â€” like a confidently single woman throwing herself an â€œIâ€™m not having a babyâ€ shower and lamenting â€œthe funkiest tasting spunkâ€ â€” to go there. Minutes into a fourth season episode titled â€œCoulda, Woulda, Shoulda,â€ notably pragmatic lawyer Miranda Hobbes (Cynthia Nixon) tells her best friend Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker) in the middle of a bustling New York City sidewalk that sheâ€™s pregnant and will have an abortion. Not a whole lot of lead-in here â€• only introducing an unwanted reality and Mirandaâ€™s solution to it. Even for an audience that had grown used to being dropped into intimate confabs between four independent women, with friends Charlotte (Kristin Davis) and Samantha (Kim Cattrall), the subject still challenged their comfort with womenâ€™s ownership of our bodies unlike any other. But Jenny Bicks, the writer of â€œCoulda, Woulda, Shouldaâ€ and co-executive producer of â€œSex and the City,â€ felt the need to reflect a very prominent reality for women. While she and the rest of her team never wanted the show to be â€œissue-driven,â€ their intent was always to challenge the characters. In doing so, they also challenged their audience. â€œWe thought, you really canâ€™t do a show about 30-something women and not talk about abortion and the prevalence,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œI think we were aware that we were doing something a little forbidden. But also something that we wanted women to feel was OK.â€ This notion of self-granted permission comes up a lot throughout the episode, even in terms of talking openly about abortion among friends who bring their own experiences to the proverbial brunch table. Though Bicks said that the writersâ€™ room never had anyone who was anti-abortion on the show, it was important for them to incorporate â€œdifferingâ€ voices closest to Miranda who serve as outside influences, even after she makes her decision at the start of the episode. â€œEvery part of your choice is impacted by whatâ€™s happening around you,â€ Bicks added. â€œWhether itâ€™s your friends going through things, or your parents saying things to you, or what you think society needs from you. So, itâ€™s a lot.â€ The question of whether or not Miranda should tell her ex-boyfriend Steve (â€‹â€‹David Eigenberg), who impregnated her, about the abortion even carries so much weight. Miranda immediately decides not to, but the very thought of it gives the audience something to consider early in the episode. â€œThatâ€™s something else we wanted, of course,â€ Bicks said. â€œWhat are the parameters of what you owe your partner? How much is your own privacy and how much do you owe to somebody else?â€ The same questions could be posed to Mirandaâ€™s friends, in whom she has always confided. When Miranda tells Samantha and Charlotte her decision at brunch, the latter is incensed because she and her husband have been trying unsuccessfully for five months to have a baby. Charlotte storms off so the three remaining women could have their â€œabortion talkâ€ without her. Of course that affects Miranda. Maybe not in a way that changes her decision, but it makes her think about how it affects those she loves. Thatâ€™s a human reality that is just as important to reflect as the decision to have an abortion. Because it shows how nonfrivolous it is. â€œWe are honoring the difficulty of the choice,â€ Bicks said. And that journey isnâ€™t merely a subplot. Itâ€™s the foundation of the entire episode. â€œI think the mistake when it comes down to this black-and-white fighting about it [is that] it stops being about all of the complications, the gray area for women â€” still,â€ Bicks continued. â€œOnce a woman has reached that point where sheâ€™s making this decision, itâ€™s not an easy one.â€ Just as important as it is to portray the complexity of choice, is to show what support for it looks like. Samantha casually says she had two abortions and prompts Carrie to share how many sheâ€™s had (one). Their admissions also help destigmatize abortion in solidarity with their friend. Not that Miranda is or should be looking for validation, but it is important that itâ€™s still there for her anyway. â€œCoulda, Woulda, Shouldaâ€ also confronts the so-called â€œtypeâ€ of women who get abortions. To this day, abortion storylines are too often attached to the stereotype of someone younger and/or from a lower economic background and/or of color. Samantha, Miranda and Carrie are white, 30-something women who frequently enjoy overpriced cosmopolitans at Manhattanâ€™s finest establishments. Miranda, particularly, could probably provide a baby with an ample amount of financial support. Sheâ€™s also single, not particularly â€œyoungâ€ (though the whole â€œfertility cliffâ€ myth has been debunked since 2001), far from maternal and didnâ€™t use a condom. That last part, Miranda says, is because she has a lazy ovary and Steve has only one ball following treatment for testicular cancer. And like she asks, â€œIn what twisted world does that create a baby?â€ While this shows Miranda comically contending with her less-than-typical circumstances that brought her to this point, itâ€™s also her attempt to justify her choice. Carrie does the same thing in her own way. She corrects Samantha, who thinks it was the guy at T.G.I. Fridays who got Carrie pregnant in 1988: â€œPlease, can we not make this worse than it was? He was a waiter at The Saloon, OK?â€ She even lies and tells her boyfriend Aidan (John Corbett) that she never had an abortion. Later, she confesses her truth but with much hesitation. She was 18 â€” no, 20. Actually, 22. And the condom broke. Except, they didnâ€™t use a condom. â€œI should have known better,â€ she says. It might seem absurd today to think that certain situations are considered more acceptable for abortion than others â€” like, after hooking up with a guy at a â€œvery happeningâ€ hotspot versus one at a popular chain restaurant or a contraception malfunction versus no contraception. But it reflects the shame that women internalize or even make a joke about in a society that continues to judge them for their choice in 2022. Though, itâ€™s important to note that Aidan is only bothered that Carrie lied to him, not that she actually had an abortion. Yes, he is the quintessential TV boyfriend before the Internet Boyfriend was a thing. But heâ€™s also a man, so this could have gone a lot of different (read: bad) ways. Bicks and her team subverted those options. â€œWe didnâ€™t think for a second that Aidan was going to have an issue with her making a choice to have had an abortion,â€ she said. â€œIt was just, â€˜Listen, if weâ€™re in this together, weâ€™re in this together.â€™ That was really important for us.â€ But that can be difficult to accept in a society so seeped in female reproach that it can create self-doubt. â€œItâ€™s all the blame that women put on themselves,â€ Bicks said. â€œCould we have handled [it] differently? Maybe,â€ she continued, voicing the question that lurches to the front of sometimes even the most assured womanâ€™s mind. â€œBut is it always our fault? No. If we did anything on the show, it was to try to bring things that were perceived to be shameful to women at the time, and probably still, [to] light. Because they stop having power if you give words to them.â€ Thatâ€™s hard to overcome when even some medical professionals, like Mirandaâ€™s own doctor, refuse to perform abortions. He adds, â€œno judgment!â€ because even some people who claim to be pro-choice donâ€™t want anything to do with an abortion. Similarly, the episode shows how feminist women like the characters on this show can grapple with their own human contradictions, like Carrie feeling uneasy about how her romantic partner might judge her for having an abortion. â€œThis was a case where we really wanted to just get that out there and say, â€˜Look, we all feel these things, but itâ€™s OK,â€™â€ Bicks added. Each characterâ€™s nuances around abortion were deeply considered and developed over time. â€œThis was not an episode we did in the first season,â€ Bicks said. â€œWe could not have done this until the audience really understood the characters â€” and until we really understood the characters, too. Because you really had to understand the motivation.â€ That includes fleshing out past experiences that brought the characters to who they are in the episode, so that the audience can go on this journey with them. â€œWe probably spent more time talking about when Carrie had an abortion,â€ Bicks said. â€œWhat was that like? Because we were making sure that the audience didnâ€™t turn on her. And to really understand her decision was as important as understanding Mirandaâ€™s.â€ Mirandaâ€™s ultimate decision remains unexpected even watching the episode again in 2022. Because she decides to have the baby. But itâ€™s her own personal deliberations that lead her to this point, not anyone elseâ€™s. Bicks said that from the beginning she and the team knew she would have the baby, but wanted her to contend with the emotional obstacle of having something complicating her very structured life. â€œSheâ€™s not someone who really believes the universe gives her moments. Sheâ€™s not woo woo, sheâ€™s not that way. But in that moment, thatâ€™s the choice she made and she doesnâ€™t regret it. And I think thatâ€™s important too.â€ Equally as significant, Bicks added, is that she showed that Carrie and Samantha have no regrets about their own choice. Though the surprise turn of events challenges Miranda in fascinating ways, itâ€™s hard not to wonder whether she is influenced by the belief that it is her last chance for motherhood. Even Bicks realizes that had the episode been written today, things might have gone a little differently, including having Miranda consider freezing her eggs, which wasnâ€™t popularized back in 2001. â€œIt would be hard for us not to get more moralistic, which is not our show,â€ she concluded. â€œWe would always put the character first and Miranda would have that child. But boy, it would be tougher because watching someone go through an abortion would also be important.â€ While no character has an abortion during the episode, the fact that â€œSex and the Cityâ€ devoted an entire half hour to its beloved heroines complexly talking about, reflecting on and considering their experiences with abortion highlights what true womenâ€™s liberation can look like. â€œThere are a couple things that when you go back and watch â€˜Sex and the Cityâ€™ seem dated,â€ Bicks accepted. â€œAnd the thing that I would not have thought seemed dated is choice. That this is now something that is up for any kind of debate is terrifying and so wrong.â€ Senior Culture Reporter

topic: Broadway Dance Captain Nails Tonys Performance With Only 12 Hours' Notice
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost The cast of Broadwayâ€™s â€œSixâ€ capped off Sunday nightâ€™s Tony Awards with a dazzling mashup of the musicalâ€™s title track and a second showstopper, â€œEx-Wives.â€ Written by Toby Marlow and Lucy Moss, â€œSixâ€ reimagines the six wives of Englandâ€™s Henry VIII as female pop stars. Actor Abby Mueller stars as Jane Seymour, Henry VIIIâ€™s third wife. Catch the â€œSixâ€ castâ€™s performance at the 2022 Tony Awards above. Unfortunately, Mueller was unable to join her â€œSixâ€ castmates at the Tonys after she reportedly tested positive for COVID-19 earlier in the day. Producers quickly called in Mallory Maedke, who is the showâ€™s dance captain and Muellerâ€™s alternate, to play Jane Seymour and ensure that the performance would go off without a hitch. The last-minute behind-the-scenes change wasnâ€™t apparent to the audience, so Tonys host Ariana DeBose took a moment before a commercial break to praise Maedke for her hard work. â€œI do want everybody to hear this because this is what tonightâ€™s been all about,â€ DeBose told the crowd. â€œThis woman is the dance captain and the alternate who was put into this number 12 hours ago. Itâ€™s what they do because the show must go on! And this one will.â€ mallory maedke getting love after performing at the #TonyAwards with just 12-hour notice, â€œitâ€™s what they do!â€ @SixBroadway ğŸ‘‘ğŸ¤ pic.twitter.com/crRlQ8k29j DeBoseâ€™s shoutout to Maedke felt particularly fitting given the ongoing challenges of staging live theater during the COVID-19 pandemic. Though much of Broadway reopened last fall after an 18-month closure, producers have continued to take unprecedented measures to postpone or curtail performances when principal cast members test positive for COVID-19. Hence, Broadway shows have come to rely more heavily on the tenacity of artists and performers like Maedke to avoid permanent closure â€• a point that Patti LuPone also acknowledged as she accepted the Tony for her performance in the musical â€œCompany.â€ Sundayâ€™s ceremony was, by all accounts, a triumphant one for â€œSix.â€ By the end of the night, the musical had won the Tonys for best original score and best costume design in a musical. Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: topic
content: content

topic: Seth Meyers Predicts What Fox News Will Say About The Jan. 6 Committee Hearings
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Seth Meyers isnâ€™t surprised that Fox News doesnâ€™t plan to broadcast Thursday eveningâ€™s live hearings of the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the U.S. Capitol. â€œThe committee will lay out the truth of what happened and Fox will lie. Itâ€™s that simple,â€ Meyers said on â€œLate Nightâ€ Wednesday. â€œThe hearings will say January 6 was a violent insurrection fomented by an outgoing president who nearly pulled off a detailed plan for an attempted coup to unlawfully claim the power that would have installed him as an unelected autocrat and destroyed American democracy,â€ he added. As for Fox News? Meyers predicted the network â€œwill say it was just a pro-freedom patriot party where everyone peacefully toured the Capitol like they were on a school field trip having to find items their teachers gave them on a worksheet.â€ The three major broadcast networks â€• ABC, CBS and NBC â€• will cover the hearings live as will cable channels CNN and MSNBC. Fox News will go ahead with its regular programming, but plans to air the hearings on its website and streaming service. Watch Meyersâ€™ roast below: Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Kanye West Accuses Adidas CEO Of Imitating His Yeezy Slides
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Ye (formerly known as Kanye West) is apparently unhappy with the head honcho of Adidas. The music mogul, who recently took a three-month break from Instagram, returned to the platform on Monday to accuse the company of mimicking his Yeezy slides design. â€œTHIS IS YE driving down the same street Kobe passed on,â€ he wrote in the since-deleted post, referencing the legendary Los Angeles Laker Kobe Bryant. Last year, Byantâ€™s widow, Vanessa Bryant, outed Nike for allegedly releasing shoes she designed to honor their late child, Gigi, without her consent. â€œTo Kasper Iâ€™m not standing for this blatant copying no more,â€ Ye continued, addressing Adidasâ€™ CEO Kasper RÃ¸rsted directly. â€œTo all sneaker culture To every ball player rapper or even if you work at the store. This is for everyone who wants to express themselves but feel they canâ€™t cause theyâ€™ll loose their contract or be called crazy Bravery is not being afraid Bravery is overcoming your fear for your truth,â€ he added. Ye via Instagram: pic.twitter.com/w2qJnQQ8S0 â€œThis Ye with the blue paint on my face These shoes represent the disrespect that people in power have to the talent This shoe is a fake Yeezy made by adidas themselves Iâ€™m not talking to DC about this either Kasper come talk to me.â€ â€œHappy Monday,â€ he sarcastically ended the message. Since 2013, the rapper has been a business partner of Adidas, which is expected to release its $55 Adilette 22 sandals on June 23. The Yeezy Slide dropped in 2019, and the Adilette sandals are somewhat similar in style and concept to Yeâ€™s more expensive slides. In 2020, sales for Yeezy sneakers topped nearly $1.7 billion in annual revenue, which landed the rapper a whopping $191 million in royalties, according to Bloomberg. RÃ¸rsted has yet to issue a response to Yeâ€™s claims. A post shared by dripped (@dripped.dp) Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Ryan Gosling Gets Ken-ified In First Look At Bleach Blond 'Barbie' Transformation
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Someone once famously told Ryan Gosling, â€œSeriously? Itâ€™s like youâ€™re Photoshopped,â€ which seems to be the direct inspiration for his role as Ken in the upcoming â€œBarbieâ€ movie. In the abs-forward first look of the actor in director Greta Gerwigâ€™s live-action take on the iconic Mattel figure, Gosling embodies the plastic hunk in his full glory. Sporting bleached blonder than blond hair, presumably buckets of spray tan lotion and his own personalized â€œKenâ€ underwear, the star leans into the fantasy in an image shared Wednesday by Warner Bros. In the photo, Gosling ever so suavely poses against a signature Barbie pink backdrop with his muscles busting out of a denim ensemble, which includes a ripped vest and matching jeans. The photo serves as the perfect complement to the first look at Margot Robbie as the titular doll released in April. If placed side-by-side, the famous couple could even be looking at each other, given the similar color palettes and coordinating outfits. Robbie, who is perched in the seat of a pink Chevrolet Corvette convertible in the photo, however, looks a bit more â€™60s inspired, while Gosling could be lifted directly out of a â€™90s Marky Mark-style underwear campaign. Apart from Robbie and Gosling, the film will star Kate McKinnon, Alexandra Shipp, America Ferrera, Ncuti Gatwa, Simu Liu, Will Ferrell, Issa Rae and Hari Nef. Written by Gerwig and partner Noah Baumbach, â€œBarbieâ€ is set to hit theaters July 21, 2023. Details on the plot of the film remain scarce, but according to New York Times reporter Kyle Buchanan, the project will feature multiple versions of Barbie and Ken. Last month, Liu teased what fans might expect from the script, which an agent described as â€œone of the bestâ€ he had ever read. â€œHe literally said this verbatim,â€ the â€œShang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Ringsâ€ star told GQ. â€œHe was like, â€˜If I could stake my career on any one script, itâ€™s the â€œBarbieâ€ script. I really think you should do it.â€™â€ Robbie has also dropped some hints about the filmâ€™s approach to the character. Back in 2020, the actor and producer remarked on the responsibility she feels to do right by Barbieâ€™s legacy and subvert audiencesâ€™ expectations surrounding her casting. â€œPeople immediately have an idea of, â€˜Oh, Margot is playing Barbie, I know what that is.â€™â€ she told The Hollywood Reporter. â€œBut our goal is to be like, â€˜Whatever youâ€™re thinking, weâ€™re going to give you something totally different â€” the thing you didnâ€™t know you wanted.â€™â€ Gosling, meanwhile, will next be seen in Netflixâ€™s mega-expensive action thriller â€œThe Gray Manâ€ opposite Chris Evans, who surely in some alternate universe would fill out Kenâ€™s cut-off denim vest quite nicely. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Jennifer Hudson Lands Historic EGOT Status At The 2022 Tony Awards
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Jennifer Hudson joined the ranks of the exclusive group of EGOT winners on Sunday at the Tony Awards. To reach EGOT level, one must win all four of the major American entertainment awards (Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, and a Tony). The songstress and producer, who has an Emmy, Grammy and Oscar, became the 17th member of the esteemed EGOT titleholders after â€œA Strange Loopâ€ won Best New Musical. Hudson also made history as the third Black EGOT winner to take the crown, and the fifth woman to receive the distinction. â€œA Strange Loop,â€ which was produced by Hudson, was the most Tony-award nominated show of the year, earning a whopping 11 nominations. The musical follows â€œa young artist grappling with desires, identity and instincts he both loves and loathes,â€ according to the productionâ€™s synopsis. The hit Broadway show boasts more than 40 producers, including Hudson, Don Cheadle, Billy Porter, Alan Cumming, Ilana Glazer, Mindy Kaling and RuPaul Charles. Hudson previously earned a Daytime Emmy for her role as executive producer for â€œBaby Yaga,â€ Grammy awards for â€œThe Color Purpleâ€ and her debut self-titled studio album, and an Oscar for bestsupporting actress in â€œDreamgirls.â€ Hereâ€™s a list of EGOT recipients over the years: Richard Rodgers (1962) Helen Hayes (1977) Rita Moreno (1977) John Gielgud (1991) Audrey Hepburn (1993) Marvin Hamlisch (1995) Jonathan Tunick (1997) Mel Brooks (2001) Mike Nichols (2001) Whoopi Goldberg (2002) Scott Rudin (2012) Robert Lopez (2014) John Legend (2018) Andrew Lloyd Webber (2018) Tim Rice (2018) Alan Menken (2020) Following in the footsteps of another American Idol alum Kelly Clarkson, Jennifer Hudson is slated to host her own talk show this fall. They surprised me !!! I did not see this coming. Look at this cake ! The Jennifer Hudson Show is coming yal. Get ready ! pic.twitter.com/JeOImtvmMX â€œThe Jennifer Hudson Showâ€ is set to air on Fox television stations. Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Herschel Walker Says There Are 52 States
content:
Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost There are 50 states in the United States of America. But in an interview Tuesday, Georgia GOP Senate candidate Herschel Walker said there were 52. Walker was going after Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor, for recently saying, â€œI am tired of hearing about [Georgia] being the best state in the country to do business when we are the worst state in the country to live.â€ Abrams cited the stateâ€™s problems with mental health treatment, maternal mortality, incarceration rates and wages. Republicans seized upon the remark and used it to criticize her, although Abrams said she stood by her belief that Republican Brian Kemp is â€œa failed governor, who doesnâ€™t care about the people of Georgia.â€ In an interview Tuesday with the Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show, Walker said Abrams should go live in another state â€• saying she had 51 others from which to choose. â€œIf you donâ€™t believe in the country, leave and go somewhere else,â€ he said. â€œIf itâ€™s the worst state, why are you here? Why donâ€™t you leave â€• go to another? Thereâ€™s, what, 51 more other states that you can go to?â€ â€œHerschel misspoke â€• he obviously knows there are 50 states,â€ spokeswoman Mallory Blount told HuffPost. Walker is a former NFL star whose campaign has been filled with controversies and misstatements. He has faced domestic violence allegations, and recently, claims of being an absent father. Walker has talked frequently about his 22-year-old son Christian and railed against fatherless homes. But The Daily Beast reported that Walker actually has three other children he doesnâ€™t talk about publicly. He has since acknowledged his four children, saying he â€œnever denied any of my kids.â€ Walker has also said heâ€™s skeptical of evolution, pointing to the fact that apes and humans coexist. â€œAt one time, science said man came from apes, did it not? ... If that is true, why are there still apes? Think about it,â€ Walker said in March. After the massacre in Uvalde, Texas, Walker called for â€œa department that can look at young men thatâ€™s looking at women thatâ€™s looking at social media,â€ as a solution to curb school shootings, but it was not clear what that was or how it would solve the problem. In 2008, then-candidate Barack Obama also misspoke on the number of states. â€œIt is wonderful to be back in Oregon,â€ Obama said. â€œOver the last 15 months, weâ€™ve traveled to every corner of the United States. Iâ€™ve now been in 57 states? I think one left to go. Alaska and Hawaii, I was not allowed to go to even though I really wanted to visit, but my staff would not justify it.â€ He later said it was â€œa sign that my numeracy is getting a little, uh â€•â€ before an aide cut him off. Some on took this comment as further proof of the birther conspiracy, claiming that he was actually referencing Muslim countries. Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Sen. Ron Johnson Caught Faking Phone Call To Avoid Fake Elector Questions
content:
National Reporter, HuffPost Facing searing questions about the revelation he tried to give false election documents to then-Vice President Mike Pence, Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) opted to fake a phone call. He got caught doing that, too. NBC News reporter Frank Thorp V spotted the Wisconsin Republican as he left the Capitol building Tuesday. Earlier that day, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol aired damning texts sent by Johnsonâ€™s chief of staff, Sean Riley, to a Pence staffer saying the senator wanted to hand the vice president an â€[a]lternate slate of electorsâ€ â€• the fake election documents used to push the idea that former President Donald Trump won in states he actually lost. â€œHow much did you know about what your chief of staff was doing with the alternate slates of electors?â€ Thorp asked Johnson, as captured in a video of the encounter. â€œIâ€™m on the phone right now,â€ Johnson said, pointing to the device and dismissively waving Thorp away. â€œNo youâ€™re not,â€ Thorp replied. â€œI can see your phone. I can see your screen.â€ Sen. Ron Johnson so much didn't want to talk to reporters about his office trying to pass fake elector lists to the vice president's office that he tried to pretend he was on the phone. pic.twitter.com/V1VwBDs42t Caught in the act, Johnson nevertheless continued the ruse, holding the phone to his ear in a one-sided, silent conversation with no one. After 30 awkward seconds, the senator put his phone down â€• still having not uttered a word into it â€• to tell reporters the apparent bombshell is â€œa complete non-story.â€ â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re even concerned about here,â€ he said. Johnson denied any knowledge of what transpired between his chief of staff and Mike Penceâ€™s staff, saying he had no idea the falsified election documents had â€œeven been delivered to us.â€ National Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Former NFL Star Tony Siragusa Dies
content: Tony Siragusa, the charismatic defensive tackle who helped lead a stout Baltimore defense to a Super Bowl title, has died. He was 55. Siragusaâ€™s broadcast agent, Jim Ornstein, confirmed the death Wednesday. The cause of death was not immediately available. â€œThis is a really sad day,â€ he said. â€œTony was way more than my client, he was family. My heart goes out to Tonyâ€™s loved ones.â€ Siragusa, known as â€œthe Goose,â€ played seven seasons with the Indianapolis Colts and five with the Ravens. Baltimoreâ€™s 2000 team won the Super Bowl behind a defense that included Siragusa, Ray Lewis and Sam Adams. The Goose,Tony Siracusa has passed away at 55.. Iâ€™m heart broken as is all of Colts Nationâ¤ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ¼ğŸˆ Siragusa was popular with fans because of his fun-loving personality, which also helped him transition quickly to broadcasting after his playing career. Siragusa came to Baltimore as a free agent in 1997 and teamed up with Adams to form an imposing defensive tackle tandem. In the Ravensâ€™ 2000 championship season, the 6-foot-3, 340-pound Siragusa was sixth among Baltimore defenders with 75 tackles. He finished his career with 22 sacks. The news of Siragusaâ€™s death came on what was already a tragic day for the Ravens. The death of Jaylon Ferguson, a linebacker for Baltimore, at age 26 was announced earlier in the day.

topic: Gloria Estefan Shades Jennifer Lopez Over Super Bowl Halftime Comments
content: Reporter, HuffPost Gloriaâ€™s gonna get you. Gloria Estefan had no qualms about poking a little fun at actor-singer Jennifer Lopez during an episode of â€œWatch What Happens Live With Andy Cohenâ€ on Tuesday. During one segment, Cohen asked the Cuban American icon what she thought about the comments Lopez made about the 2020 Super Bowl halftime show, in which she performed with Colombian singer Shakira. In her Netflix documentary â€œHalftime,â€ Lopez complained about the time constraints of having to share the stage, calling it â€œthe worst idea in the world.â€ In response, Estefan told Cohen that she was asked to join Lopez and Shakira on the Super Bowl stage but rejected the offer. â€œLook, this is the bottom line. You have very little time, like 12 minutes or something, to get things on and off the set,â€ Estefan explained. â€œSo, could you do it with one person? Yes, but I think they wanted to throw a Miami and Latin extravaganza, and they tried to pack it as much as possible.â€ And although Estefan said that the women â€œkilled itâ€ and that it was an â€œamazing show,â€ the â€œRhythm Is Gonna Get Youâ€ singer also took the opportunity to throw a little shade at Lopez. â€œOK, and imagine what J.Lo would have said if I was the third [performer]!â€ Estefan said, bugging out her eyes. â€œI literally would come out, done â€˜come on shake your body,â€™ out!â€ Estefan joked, referring to the lyrics of her 1985 Miami Sound Machine hit, â€œConga!â€ Estefan then added that sheâ€™s performed at a few Super Bowls and that Lopez and Shakiraâ€™s show was â€œtheir momentâ€ to shine. â€œPlus, I didnâ€™t want to go on a diet in December,â€ Estefan said. â€œItâ€™s Christmas!â€ Lopezâ€™s complaints about her Super Bowl performance in â€œHalftimeâ€ werenâ€™t directed at Shakira but at the NFL. Lopezâ€™s manager Benny Medina shared his clientâ€™s frustrations over the NFLâ€™s choice of a co-headlining performance. â€œTypically, you have one headliner at a Super Bowl. That headliner constructs a show, and, should they choose to have other guests, thatâ€™s their choice,â€ he said, according to Entertainment Weekly. â€œIt was an insult to say you needed two Latinas to do the job that one artist historically has done.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Andrew Gillum, Former Candidate For Florida Governor, Facing Federal Charges
content:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) â€” Andrew Gillum, the 2018 Democratic nominee for Florida governor, is facing 21 federal charges related to a scheme to seek donations and funnel a portion of them back to him through third parties, the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office announced Wednesday. Gillum, 42, and co-defendant Janet Lettman-Hicks, 53, face 19 counts of wire fraud. Gillum is also charged with making false statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office said the pair â€œconspired to commit wire fraud, by unlawfully soliciting and obtaining funds from various entities and individuals through false and fraudulent promises and representations that the funds would be used for a legitimate purpose.â€ Lettman-Hicks then used her company to fraudulently give money to Gillum disguised as payroll payments, the office said in a press release. Itâ€™s the latest trouble for Gillum, who narrowly lost to Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis in a race that required a recount. Gillum served as mayor of Tallahassee before running for governor. In March 2020, Gillum was found intoxicated and unconscious in a hotel room with two men, including one who works as a male escort. Two days later he entered a rehabilitation center, and later did a television interview and said heâ€™s bisexual. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Man Who Filmed Self Screaming His Name In Capitol Riot Sentenced
content: Reporter, HuffPost Former West Virginia state lawmaker Derrick Evans was sentenced to three months on Wednesday for his part in the U.S. Capitol attack last year. Evans had livestreamed himself joining the throng of Donald Trump supporters as some individuals smashed their way into the building and then opened the Rotunda doors for the rest of the mob. He narrated his exploits as he went along, shouting â€œTrump,â€ â€œThe doorâ€™s cracked,â€ and â€œWeâ€™re goinâ€™ in!â€ â€œWeâ€™re in! Derrick Evans is in the Capitol!â€ he said once he made it though the doors. Evans later deleted the video, but it featured prominently in prosecutorsâ€™ case against him. After initially pleading not guilty, defending himself by saying he â€œcommitted no criminal act,â€ Evans took a plea deal. He told Judge Royce C. Lamberth that he accepts responsibility for his actions, seated nearby a large Evans family photo, according to NBC News. Lamberth reportedly wished Evans well, telling him that he considered sentencing Evans to six months behind bars. Evansâ€™ attorney had asked for no jail time. â€œI just canâ€™t give you probation in a case like this ... it doesnâ€™t reflect the feeling in the country,â€ the judge said, according to CBS News reporter Rob Legare. â€œI donâ€™t want another riot in the next election,â€ Lamberth added. At the time of the riot, the father of four had recently been elected to represent West Virginians in the stateâ€™s House of Delegates. Three days later, he was forced to resign. After releasing a very brief statement announcing his resignation, Evans released a second, slightly longer statement expressing regret, writing, â€œI take full responsibility for my actions, and deeply regret any hurt, pain or embarrassment I may have caused my family, friends, constituents and fellow West Virginians.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Teen Abortions On TV Are Still Taboo, But 'Degrassi' Depicted It Nearly 20 Years Ago
content: Culture Reporter This article is part of a larger series titled â€œThe End Of Roe.â€ Head here to read more. During its third season in 2004, â€œDegrassi: The Next Generationâ€ spotlighted abortion, with 14-year-old burgeoning gymnast Manny Santos (Cassie Steele) as the focal point of the two-part episode titled â€œAccidents Will Happen.â€ In Part 1, ahead of a gymnastics meet, Manny is dealing with bouts of nausea and thinks sheâ€™s caught a stomach flu. When Manny lends her tampons to teammate Hazel (Andrea Lewis), she says, â€œHere â€” I havenâ€™t used mine in forever.â€ Manny assumes that because sheâ€™s been through strenuous training lately, her period is just delayed. But her best friend, Emma (Miriam McDonald), is taken aback and says, â€œReally?â€ and ultimately suggests that it could be something else. Annoyed by her nosy friend, Manny walks off. However, the thought of a skipped period being attributed to something else follows her. She later asks Emmaâ€™s mother, Spike, who birthed her own daughter as a teen, for a pregnancy test. Her worst nightmare is confirmed: Sheâ€™s pregnant. Worried about being sent off to a convent in the Philippines, like her cousin, Manny begins weighing her options. The two-part episode ends with her getting an abortion. Since it aired, the episode has been heralded as a progressive catalyst for representation surrounding abortion storylines onscreen. However, then â€” and now â€” teen abortions were rarely shown on television. Screenwriter Shelley Scarrow had been a fan of Linda Schuylerâ€™s original teen series from the â€™80s, â€œThe Kids of Degrassi Street,â€ and knew that the series always touched on hot-button topics. Its revived iteration followed a new class of youth at Degrassi Community School and was widely popular in the United States, airing on Nickelodeonâ€™s Teen Nick (previously known as The N and Nick Gas). (In January, it was announced that a new â€œDegrassiâ€ reboot has been greenlit and is expected to launch in the U.S. exclusively on HBO Max in 2023.) The series touched on ultra-heavy and high-stakes issues: sexuality, sexual assault, penis pumps, disordered eating, school shootings, Islamophobia and other big topics. â€œIf your argument is that you want to teach kids to be safer about sex, then you have to have the episode where someone fucks up and goes through this, to deal with it. Because when kids watch TV, theyâ€™re fantasizing themselves in situations,â€ Scarrow said. â€œWe all do,â€ she continued. â€œYou have to be able to see yourself as a young woman, as a young woman of color, as a young woman with reproductive freedom. You have to be able to see it. I just think weâ€™re cutting out an enormous and important part of young pregnant peopleâ€™s lives.â€ The few abortion narratives on TV do not mirror our society; young people, people of color and other marginalized groups often donâ€™t see their experiences with abortion shown on screen. Instead, audiences often see youth navigating pregnancy, from MTVâ€™s reality television franchise â€œTeen Momâ€ to ABC Familyâ€™s drama-soap â€œThe Secret Life of the American Teenager.â€ And itâ€™s rare to see a balanced dialogue between characters about the options available to them upon discovering theyâ€™re pregnant. Despite airing other controversial topics, â€œAccidents Will Happenâ€ was initially banned in the United States and didnâ€™t air until a few years later. Scarrow was a staff writer for the first four seasons of â€œDegrassi: The Next Generationâ€ and the architect of the two-part episode. She talked to HuffPost about her inspiration for Mannyâ€™s storyline, the state of how abortion is addressed on screen today and what it was like having her episode banned in the U.S. HuffPost: â€œDegrassi: The Next Generationâ€ has never shied away from any topic â€” ever. Did you know that abortion was something you wanted the series to address? Shelley Scarrow: â€œThe Next Generationâ€ is based on an even older show that was out in the â€™80s. One of the hallmarks of that show, one of the things that people remembered, is that they did discuss abortion, and one of the twins on the old show went through an abortion. So when I was a kid, I remembered seeing that, and I remember discussing that with my friends on the playground. It wasnâ€™t even just me. It was just sort of baked into the show; it was something that the show had already talked about, and we knew we wanted to speak about it in a new and different way with different characters. Every year at the beginning of the writing room in â€œDegrassi,â€ we would put up the list of issues that we wanted to talk about that year. It was very much the framework of the show that we were like, â€˜Hereâ€™s hot shit we want to talk about,â€™ and abortion was always on there. It was just a matter of waiting until it was the right character and the right moment and what felt right for that person. Manny was just the obvious choice. I related the most strongly to her. If anyone ever asks me what character was the easiest, I felt like I could absolutely write Manny in my sleep. She just was this raw, beautiful nerve that I responded to. In pop culture, we donâ€™t tend to see many depictions of young adolescents of color grappling with abortion. Cassie Steeleâ€™s portrayal of Manny Santos was groundbreaking in that she was this young Filipina dealing with an unplanned pregnancy, managing her parentsâ€™ expectations, navigating fear and other issues. Did you realize at that moment that her narrative would have such a profound impact? I donâ€™t think that I viewed it at that lens, which might be a deficiency of me as a writer in 2003. I just thought a lot about who Manny was. I loved Mannyâ€™s background and Mannyâ€™s family. We did a lot of research and had conversations with Filipino friends about the culture. But I donâ€™t think we came at it that way at all. One of the great things about writing â€œDegrassiâ€ was that itâ€™s an anthology show, and I think itâ€™s, like, one of the secrets that nobody realizes is that each episode is about somebody entirely new. There arenâ€™t that many shows that do that, and so whenever you get a chance to write a character, you sort of jump into their life. And I loved jumping into that aspect of her. In the episode, we see Manny meander through the process of figuring out her options. She consults her best friend, Emma, who is staunchly pro-life, and Emmaâ€™s mother, Spike, who carried out her teen pregnancy. That episode marks one of the few times Iâ€™ve seen a dialogue between characters about abortion as opposed to assuming the fate of the embryo. As a writer, was it important to you to show that thought process and how a 13- or 14-year-old would rationalize their decisions? I think so. It was one of the writing rules of the show that an adult was never allowed to come in and tell a kid what to do. That was one of the things that we felt very strongly about, and that was imparted by Linda [Schuyler] from the original series. An adult wasnâ€™t allowed to fly in and be the fairy godmother and make the choice for the kid; all the choices had to come at the kid level. So speaking to her friends about it and reflecting it through dialogue with her friends was really important. Spike was in a unique situation because she was on the old show, and people had seen her go through it back in the â€™80s. She was a little bit of an exception to the rule, but she didnâ€™t express an opinion to Manny or tell her what to do. (A) because thatâ€™s not who Spike is as a human being but (B) because that was one of the mandates of the show. I even read a couple of years ago some people had written more up-to-date pieces on abortion choice and some people expressed frustration with Emma doing that, and saying that she was kind of a lousy friend. To me, that was sort of the core of depicting abortion. The reality of it is that people arenâ€™t going to have the same opinions as you, and I think that thatâ€™s maybe a little bit of whatâ€™s lacking in depictions and in the real world. Part of the truth of that story is the friendship of someone who doesnâ€™t agree with you still supporting you â€” and that might not be everyoneâ€™s version of friendship, but itâ€™s my version of friendship, and I think that itâ€™s also important in the abortion discussion. In consulting her loved ones, Manny goes back to Craig, who she had sex with. Viewers see Manny trying to retrace their steps, asking, â€œYou used a condom, right?â€ Manny was clearly worried about the prospect of building a future with him. Apart from advancing Craigâ€™s storyline, why was it important to you to depict them going back and forth? I donâ€™t want to say the most political thing possible, but Iâ€™m going to say the most political thing possible. I think that ultimately the actual decision rests on the woman and should rest on the woman. I just believe that very fully as a human being. Iâ€™m not going to say it was immaterial what Craigâ€™s response was, but I wanted Manny to find her way. That was because, to me, that was the ultimate message of the show: This is your decision. This is your choice. You make it and you decide who you talk to about it. You decide. The two-part episode ends with Manny and her mother at the clinic and a nurse walking Manny into a room for her procedure. We donâ€™t see her take a pill, lie on a gurney or any chilling, cold, preoperative protocol. Rather, sheâ€™s taken under the nurseâ€™s wing â€• and the screen fades to black. Why is that? I actually had a friend who worked in an abortion clinic at the time, and I talked to her a lot. I did a lot of research on that episode with her. I talked to some of her friends who were nurses. That kind of moment in your life is huge, and skipping it in any way was just not on the table. It was really important for me to see that sheâ€™s OK. Thereâ€™s so much rhetoric around abortion â€” so much angry rhetoric â€” but in my experience with friends whoâ€™ve gone through abortions, itâ€™s a decision that you make just like if you went to the dentist. Now, itâ€™s not the same as going to the dentist, but what Iâ€™m trying to say is the reality of going through the clinic and the procedure. Itâ€™s not hellfire and horror; itâ€™s a medical procedure. Itâ€™s something you go to a doctorâ€™s office for, and you do, and showing that was important. What was your reaction upon realizing that Part 2 of the episode had been banned in the U.S.? (The N, the U.S. distributor of â€œDegrassi: The Next Generation,â€ refused to air the second part of the episode for years.) I was like, â€˜I am hardcore! Iâ€™m banned in America!â€™ Like, if nothing else, put this on my gravestone. It was the only episode that was banned â€” and we did crazy shit! James [Hurst] wrote a penis pump episode that they showed, and they talked about a penis pump. And I was like, â€˜We can talk about that, but we canâ€™t deal with this very real issue that your viewers are going through?â€™ I will say Nickelodeon was very supportive the entire way through the process, and they tried really hard internally â€” and I will never take that away from them. I went on a journey with Manny in writing those episodes. I was a 30-year-old woman when I wrote those episodes, and I think that I had always been pro-choice. There is something about the act of sitting down and going through it very directly from a characterâ€™s point of view â€” and having to think through Emmaâ€™s point of view, which was 100% not the same as mine â€” that made me question abortion in a rigorous manner. I still came back around to my same decision, but I was like, â€˜This is what art does. This is what art is supposed to do.â€™ Thatâ€™s the reality for a lot of young women, and I applaud it. But I just think itâ€™s important to show all the choices and to be rigorous about them so that itâ€™s informed on all levels and all sides because otherwise you just end up in this binary. â€‹â€‹Weâ€™re still in this era where television storylines that address abortion are perceived as taboo. Even the ways in which it is depicted are very narrow, often centering a cis-het white female lead. What does it mean to you now that this is still a topic of contention on screen? Why is it important to continue to show these thorough storylines, with all options front and center? Iâ€™m aware that I am a white woman saying this, but I think representation matters. And I think that representation on everything matters. And so I think that if weâ€™re cutting out representation of what the thousands of women and pregnant people are actually doing, and the choice that theyâ€™re making, then weâ€™re not letting them see themselves on TV. And weâ€™re also not preparing people mentally. If your argument is that you want to teach kids to be safer about sex, then you have to have the episode where someone fucks up and goes through this, to deal with it. Because when kids watch TV, theyâ€™re fantasizing themselves in situations. We all do. You have to be able to see yourself as a young woman, as a young woman of color, as a young woman with reproductive freedom. You have to be able to see it. I just think weâ€™re cutting out an enormous and important part of young pregnant peopleâ€™s lives. What is your hope for the evolution of how screenwriters portray youth navigating abortion on television and in movies? What would you like to see from the next generation of writers? To me, itâ€™s truth and honesty and rigor, and I think thatâ€™s the job of storyteller, and I think thatâ€™s the job of story. I would love to see more representation, period, including women making the choice to keep a child, including women making the choice to put them up for adoption. I feel like the balance has never been equal. We have never, ever seen enough representations of this choice that a lot of young people make â€” including trans people, pregnant people of all stripes. Thatâ€™s what I would like to see: rigor, honesty, and a little bit more balance. Culture Reporter

topic: Brian Cox Is Always Asked To Say These 2 Words On Cameo
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost â€œSuccessionâ€ star Brian Cox has turned the words â€œF**k offâ€ into a personal trademark â€• and a lucrative side hustle. The actor is on Cameo, where he charges $689 to send personal â€• and profane â€• greetings to fans. And, yes, it seems like every person requesting a video has two specific words they want him to say, based on this supercut. Possible 6th love language for Dads #fyp #fathersday But while Cox is happy to drop F-bombs on the HBO series and on Cameo, he only does it for fans on a case-by-case basis, he told The Hollywood Reporter last week. During a panel with fellow actors Oscar Isaac, Tom Hiddleston, Quincy Isaiah, Michael Keaton and fellow expletive legend Samuel L. Jackson, Cox admitted the public desire to hear him curse can be awkward. â€œWell, itâ€™s not the easiest thing to say to people,â€ Cox confessed. â€œI mean, it started when I was playing L.B.J. in one of those theaters in New York. I came out one night and there was this young couple, very sweet, about 17, and they had a video and they said, â€˜Could you tell us to fuck off, please?â€™ I mean, itâ€™s unbelievable.â€ Cox then described an awkward request he received at an event for Ronan Farrowâ€™s book launch. â€œAll these Hollywood women were there and it was very intense,â€ he said. â€œAnd I was standing at the back and then [the women] all turned around and saw me and they [pointed a] camera and said, â€˜Can you tell us to fuck off?â€™â€ â€œI was like, â€˜This is a #MeToo meeting, is this really proper to be asking me to tell you to fuck off? And does that mean that I get canceled?â€™â€ Jackson said people ask him to say his trademark word â€œmotherfuckerâ€ all the time, or to record a message on their answering machine like, â€œThis motherfuckerâ€™s not home right now. And the motherfucker will call you back.â€ But Jackson demurred after Cox pointed out he could charge money to say the phrase. â€œI donâ€™t want to gouge the public. I charge them enough to come to my movies,â€ Jackson said. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Jonathan Groff And Lea Michele Lead Epic 'Spring Awakening' Reunion At Tony Awards
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Lea Michele helped turn the clock back â€• musically, at least â€• nearly 16 years when she took the stage at the 2022 Tony Awards Sunday night. The actor and her longtime pal Jonathan Groff reunited with the cast of Broadwayâ€™s â€œSpring Awakeningâ€ for a haunting performance of the song â€œTouch Me.â€ When it debuted on Broadway in 2006, â€œSpring Awakeningâ€ broke ground as an exploration of teen sexuality, mental health and sexual assault. The show received eight Tony Awards. Though Groff and Michele were the musicalâ€™s breakout stars, the show also launched the careers of actors John Gallagher Jr. (who won a Tony for his role), Skylar Astin and Gideon Glick. All were present at Sundayâ€™s ceremony. Catch the â€œSpring Awakeningâ€ Tonys performance below: The castâ€™s performance at the Tony Awards was the culmination of a nearly yearlong 15th anniversary celebration. Last year, the cast came together for a one-night-only reunion concert, staged at New Yorkâ€™s Imperial Theater under strict COVID-19 protocols. The production was chronicled in the HBO documentary â€œSpring Awakening: Those Youâ€™ve Known,â€ released last month. Speaking to Entertainment Tonight ahead of her Tonys appearance, Michele said the experience of reuniting with the â€œSpring Awakeningâ€ cast was â€œjust wild,â€ particularly given the lingering challenges of the pandemic. â€œWe managed to get the entire original cast together,â€ she said. â€œWe managed to get through the hurdles of COVID and everything and reunite and come together. And weâ€™re just so honored to be back.â€ Asked about what heâ€™d tell the younger version of himself and his co-stars about the success of â€œSpring Awakening,â€ Groff said, â€œI would tell them to take it in.â€ â€œYou know what, we did take it in back then, we really did,â€ he added. â€œSo many of the adults in the theater community and Michael Mayer, our director, they were keeping us very grounded and in the moment. If I were to experience it all again, I would just take it in all over again.â€ Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Zendaya Claps Back Over Pregnancy Rumors: â€˜This Is Why I Stay Off Twitterâ€™
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Zendaya is totally over the internetâ€™s recent pregnancy rumors. On Wednesday, the â€œDuneâ€ star seemingly addressed the swirling buzz that sheâ€™s pregnant with a post on her Instagram story that read: â€œSee now, this is why I stay off Twitter.â€œ Although she didnâ€™t specifically address the rumors, her hint seems quite direct. â€œJust making stuff up for no reasonâ€¦weekly,â€ she added. The debacle ignited after a viral TikTok video surfaced, showcasing a fake ultrasound from the Emmy-award winning actor. The video contains a photoshopped screenshot of Zendayaâ€™s Instagram, which sent fans into a frenzy, leading them to believe that she posted the big news from her account. This hit TikToK as a ki and now yâ€™all in an uproar talking about Zendaya is pregnant ğŸ˜­ Yâ€™all have to stop. pic.twitter.com/U7qJp4ZZzk Brushing off the gossip, Zendaya wrote in a follow-up post, â€œAnyway back to filming,â€ while plugging her upcoming film â€œChallengers.â€ The film, set to release on August 11, 2023, will also star Mike Faist (â€œWest Side Storyâ€) and Josh Oâ€™Connor (â€œThe Crownâ€). Even Lil Nas X had words for the sizzling hearsay. The entertainer joked on Twitter that he was â€œabout to congratulate zendaya via dm about a baby that doesnâ€™t exist.â€ He then pointed the finger at the social platform for the mix-up. i hate twitter because iâ€™m sitting here about to congratulate zendaya via dm about a baby that doesnâ€™t exist Although the hoax proved to be a false alarm, Zendaya and her boyfriend, actor Tom Holland are still going strong. The adorable duo, who have been dating publicly since last July after they were spotted kissing at an airport, shared a special moment on Instagram this month. On June 1, Zendaya posted a loving message for the â€œSpider-Man: No Way Homeâ€ starâ€™s 26th birthday. â€œHappiest of birthdays to the one who makes me the happiest,â€ she wrote. A post shared by Zendaya (@zendaya) Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Trevor Noah Wants To Know: What's The Difference Between Drunk Rudy And Sober Rudy?
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Trevor Noah mocked Rudy Giuliani on â€œThe Daily Showâ€ Monday for having the â€œliquid courageâ€ to instruct former President Donald Trump to simply claim he won the presidency on election night â€” long before all the votes were even counted. The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection made a point of mentioning at its hearing Monday that Giuliani was â€œapparently inebriated,â€ â€œintoxicatedâ€ and â€œhad too much to drinkâ€ that night. â€œIâ€™m just curious about how you even know when Rudy Giuliani is drunk?â€ Noah asked. â€œNo, because when a normal person is drunk, they say crazy things, they yell, they sweat a lot. So how does that work for Rudy? Does it work in reverse? Like does he start talking normally? His hair dye sucks back in his hair?â€ Noah was also shocked to learn that Trump coordinated the insurrection, as the Jan. 6 panel is arguing, because he didnâ€™t think Trump could â€œcoordinate anything in advance.â€ â€œThe man canâ€™t even plan where a sentence should end,â€ Noah said. Watch the full monologue here: Trends Reporter, HuffPost
