topic: Tom Cruise And James Corden Star In 'Bottom Gun' With Tea And Biscuits
content: General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost Tom Cruise and James Corden reunited for another goofy air adventure â€• and brought along some other â€œTop Gun: Maverickâ€ cast members. (Watch the video below.) On Thursdayâ€™s â€œLate Late Show,â€ Cruiseâ€™s Maverick and Cordenâ€™s Honey Butter are on a mission. But other matters get in the way. It seems the other pilots, played by â€œMaverickâ€ stars Monica Barbaro, Jay Ellis and Glenn Powell, hate Cordenâ€™s soft call sign and arenâ€™t down for tea and biscuits while the enemy fires at them. But Honey Butter wonâ€™t be deterred in the new sequel, â€œBottom Gun.â€ Last month, Corden and Cruise teamed up for a segment in which the cinema hero took the host for a ride in vintage and modern aircraft. But after the lower-budget animated outing, Cruise still tells Corden, â€œYou can be my wingman anytime, Honey Butter.â€ â€œTop Gun: Maverickâ€ is believed to have a shot at earning $1 billion at the box office worldwide. General Assignment Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Amber Heard Fears Future Defamation Lawsuits From Depp For Speaking Out
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost Amber Heard said she fears that she could face future defamation lawsuits by speaking out about her volatile relationship with Johnny Depp in a sit-down interview where she also addressed her past pledge to donate $7 million to charity. In part three of an interview aired Wednesday with NBC News, the â€œAquamanâ€ actor said she is â€œscaredâ€ that she risks being forever silenced after a judge earlier this month ordered her to pay $10 million in damages over a 2018 op-ed she published about domestic abuse. The essay did not mention Depp by name but his attorneys successfully argued to the jury that it indirectly referred to their marriage. Watch all of part two of @SavannahGuthrie's exclusive interview with Amber Heard, in which Heard discusses her future, fears about new defamation lawsuits and whether she still â€œhas loveâ€ for Johnny Depp: pic.twitter.com/xr3EX9se6K â€œIâ€™m scared that no matter what I do, no matter what I say, or how I say it â€” every step that I take will present another opportunity for this sort of â€” silencing, which is what, I guess, a defamation lawsuit is meant to do,â€ she told NBCâ€™s Savannah Guthrie. Heard maintained that she did the right thing and â€œeverything I could to stand up for myself and the truthâ€ after publishing the op-ed in The Washington Post, though she continued to insist that it was never about her marriage with Depp. â€œWhat the op-ed was about was ... me loaning my voice to a bigger cultural conversation that we were having at the time,â€ she said, with the essay being published at the height of the #MeToo movement. Heard said she had a team of lawyers review the essay before it was published and that it was never her intention to â€œdefameâ€ Depp or get him â€œcanceledâ€ over it, saying she still has love for the â€œPirates of the Caribbeanâ€ star. Guthrie went on to question her credibility and how the jury heard that she hasnâ€™t fulfilled a 2016 promise to donate $3.5 million of her $7 million divorce settlement to the American Civil Liberties Union. Heard faced intense questioning during her trial over her past claim that the money has been donated. An ACLU executive testified that she has given less than half of that money, with her last payment made in 2018. EXCLUSIVE: @SavannahGuthrie asks Amber Heard about her pledge to donate $7 million of her divorce settlement and if her statements about the money "raised questions of [Heard's] credibility with the jury." pic.twitter.com/3V2aBGxyAI â€œI made a pledge and that pledge is made over time by its nature,â€ Heard told Guthrie of the funds. â€œYou said â€˜I donated.â€™ You know that everyone thinks that you donated it, not that you pledged it. So to the jurors sitting there, do you think that they felt like that was you getting caught in a lie?â€ Guthrie asked. â€œI donâ€™t know, because I feel like so much of the trial was meant to cast aspersions on who I am as a human, to call me a liar in every way you can,â€ Heard responded. â€œThat was the trial. It was a credibility contest. That was it,â€ Guthrie said. Heard said she still plans to honor that donation and pay it in full, NBC reported. An hourlong special of Heardâ€™s interview will air Friday on â€œDateline NBCâ€ at 8 p.m./7 p.m. CT. Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: A Real-Life 'Squid Game' Is In The Works Because We're In A Real-Life Dystopia
content: Reporter, HuffPost Hereâ€™s just hoping Netflix execs wonâ€™t be featured on the show wearing elaborate animal masks. The streamer announced Tuesday that a reality competition series called â€œSquid Game: The Challengeâ€ based on its Korean smash-hit series â€œSquid Gameâ€ is in the works. Do you want to play a game? Enter to join Squid Game: The Challenge at https://t.co/MaXfZnqmvb pic.twitter.com/6gYLXlplDC Like the original scripted series, the reality show will feature â€œ456 real playersâ€ who â€œwill enter the game in pursuit of a life-changing reward of $4.56 million,â€ according to a press release. â€œAs they compete through a series of games inspired by the original show â€” plus surprising new additions â€” their strategies, alliances, and character will be put to the test while competitors are eliminated around them,â€ it reads. And what will these â€œsurprising new additionsâ€ be? Hopscotch? Heads Up, Seven Up? Dodgeball With Explosives? Well, maybe not the latter â€” because Netflix also noted that â€œin this game the worst fate is going home empty-handed.â€ So it doesnâ€™t seem like any of the actual contestants will die. Recruitment for the series is currently open to English language speakers from anywhere in the world. Although the reality show got the red light, green light, â€œSquid Gameâ€ fans have said that making the fictionalized games into a reality show misses the point of the original seriesâ€™ first season. (A second season of the scripted series was also announced earlier this week.) Season 1 of â€œSquid Gameâ€ is a cautionary tale about wealth disparity. In the show, financially desperate people kill one another in a series of kidsâ€™ games to win a life-changing cash prize for a few wealthy VIPsâ€™ entertainment. â€œSquid Gameâ€ creator Hwang Dong-hyuk even likened one of the VIPs in the show to former President Donald Trump. But if youâ€™re just a pleb who wants to see actual people murder this concept on Twitter, scroll down. I don't think I've ever seen the moral stance of a show so completely misunderstood by the general public like Squid Game has been https://t.co/VX7uEeSAGD this is actually how Netflix is doing their next round of layoffshttps://t.co/ZoO2ylgKcV hwang dong-hyuk: in my show i invented the Squid Game as a cautionary talenetflix: at long last, we have created the Squid Game from classic anti-capitalist satire Squid Game pic.twitter.com/sxNgK37K54 3) will you be doing Battle Royale or The Hunger Games next? There was a show about why this was a bad idea, I believe it was called squid game https://t.co/kOE62R6hBk Somehow Netflix missed the entire point of their own show. Netflix execs quite literally are the Squid Game VIPs https://t.co/Qff8n1IW3G pic.twitter.com/tPw9m9cJZw https://t.co/QFryz1KRXW pic.twitter.com/79fxTAPhl9 what stage of capitalism is this... https://t.co/olmk6G3PtO https://t.co/8WQkduanUs pic.twitter.com/5Wbd5ujQqE me evading elimination after losing squid game connect 4 pic.twitter.com/tYtLXmlzkU Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Lizzo Changes Lyric In New Song After Criticism Over Ableist Slur
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Lizzo has changed a lyric in her new song, â€œGrrrls,â€ after listeners pointed out it was an ableist slur. â€œItâ€™s been brought to my attention that there is a harmful word in my new song,â€ the Grammy-winning singer wrote Monday on Instagram. â€œLet me make one thing clear: I never want to promote derogatory language. As a fat black woman in America, Iâ€™ve had many hurtful words used against me so I understand the power words can have (whether intentionally or in my case, unintentionally).â€ She said there was a new version of the song with a lyric change. â€œThis is the result of me listening and taking action. As an influential artist Iâ€™m dedicated to being part of the change Iâ€™ve been waiting to see in the world,â€ she wrote. A post shared by Lizzo (@lizzobeeating) In the opening verse of the new single, Lizzo sings: â€œDo you see this shit? Iâ€™ma spaz.â€ As a number of disability advocates noted after the songâ€™s Friday release, the slang term, sometimes used colloquially to mean crazy, clumsy or incompetent, is a derogatory word that stems from terminology used to describe conditions of certain movement disorders and cerebral palsy. Hey @lizzo my disability Cerebral Palsy is literally classified as Spastic Diplegia (where spasticity refers to unending painful tightness in my legs) your new song makes me pretty angry + sad. â€˜Spazâ€™ doesnâ€™t mean freaked out or crazy. Itâ€™s an ableist slur. Itâ€™s 2022. Do better. Oh @lizzoA VERY influential figure, using the word sp@z in her new song. An offensive and derogatory term. As someone whoâ€™s written about the use of disability language, especially slang/slur words which have been used in schools, this is a huge step back.Please, remove it. On Monday, the version of the song on Spotify contained a different lyric: â€œDo you see this shit? Hold me back.â€ Some of those who initially spoke out applauded Lizzo for the way she handled the situation: Iâ€™m going to cry ğŸ˜­ Thank you so much for hearing us Lizzo and for understanding that this was only ever meant gently and being open to learning, it honestly means the world â¤ï¸. Youâ€™re a real true ally https://t.co/RbQCbAwpR6 And thatâ€™s how itâ€™s done âœ… https://t.co/il6UYqkl1I The lyric has also been changed in the song on Lizzoâ€™s official YouTube channel. Her fourth studio album, â€œSpecial,â€ is due to be released July 15. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Herschel Walker Says There Are 52 States
content:
Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost There are 50 states in the United States of America. But in an interview Tuesday, Georgia GOP Senate candidate Herschel Walker said there were 52. Walker was going after Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor, for recently saying, â€œI am tired of hearing about [Georgia] being the best state in the country to do business when we are the worst state in the country to live.â€ Abrams cited the stateâ€™s problems with mental health treatment, maternal mortality, incarceration rates and wages. Republicans seized upon the remark and used it to criticize her, although Abrams said she stood by her belief that Republican Brian Kemp is â€œa failed governor, who doesnâ€™t care about the people of Georgia.â€ In an interview Tuesday with the Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show, Walker said Abrams should go live in another state â€• saying she had 51 others from which to choose. â€œIf you donâ€™t believe in the country, leave and go somewhere else,â€ he said. â€œIf itâ€™s the worst state, why are you here? Why donâ€™t you leave â€• go to another? Thereâ€™s, what, 51 more other states that you can go to?â€ â€œHerschel misspoke â€• he obviously knows there are 50 states,â€ spokeswoman Mallory Blount told HuffPost. Walker is a former NFL star whose campaign has been filled with controversies and misstatements. He has faced domestic violence allegations, and recently, claims of being an absent father. Walker has talked frequently about his 22-year-old son Christian and railed against fatherless homes. But The Daily Beast reported that Walker actually has three other children he doesnâ€™t talk about publicly. He has since acknowledged his four children, saying he â€œnever denied any of my kids.â€ Walker has also said heâ€™s skeptical of evolution, pointing to the fact that apes and humans coexist. â€œAt one time, science said man came from apes, did it not? ... If that is true, why are there still apes? Think about it,â€ Walker said in March. After the massacre in Uvalde, Texas, Walker called for â€œa department that can look at young men thatâ€™s looking at women thatâ€™s looking at social media,â€ as a solution to curb school shootings, but it was not clear what that was or how it would solve the problem. In 2008, then-candidate Barack Obama also misspoke on the number of states. â€œIt is wonderful to be back in Oregon,â€ Obama said. â€œOver the last 15 months, weâ€™ve traveled to every corner of the United States. Iâ€™ve now been in 57 states? I think one left to go. Alaska and Hawaii, I was not allowed to go to even though I really wanted to visit, but my staff would not justify it.â€ He later said it was â€œa sign that my numeracy is getting a little, uh â€•â€ before an aide cut him off. Some on took this comment as further proof of the birther conspiracy, claiming that he was actually referencing Muslim countries. Washington Bureau Chief, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Sen. Ron Johnson Caught Faking Phone Call To Avoid Fake Elector Questions
content:
National Reporter, HuffPost Facing searing questions about the revelation he tried to give false election documents to then-Vice President Mike Pence, Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) opted to fake a phone call. He got caught doing that, too. NBC News reporter Frank Thorp V spotted the Wisconsin Republican as he left the Capitol building Tuesday. Earlier that day, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol aired damning texts sent by Johnsonâ€™s chief of staff, Sean Riley, to a Pence staffer saying the senator wanted to hand the vice president an â€[a]lternate slate of electorsâ€ â€• the fake election documents used to push the idea that former President Donald Trump won in states he actually lost. â€œHow much did you know about what your chief of staff was doing with the alternate slates of electors?â€ Thorp asked Johnson, as captured in a video of the encounter. â€œIâ€™m on the phone right now,â€ Johnson said, pointing to the device and dismissively waving Thorp away. â€œNo youâ€™re not,â€ Thorp replied. â€œI can see your phone. I can see your screen.â€ Sen. Ron Johnson so much didn't want to talk to reporters about his office trying to pass fake elector lists to the vice president's office that he tried to pretend he was on the phone. pic.twitter.com/V1VwBDs42t Caught in the act, Johnson nevertheless continued the ruse, holding the phone to his ear in a one-sided, silent conversation with no one. After 30 awkward seconds, the senator put his phone down â€• still having not uttered a word into it â€• to tell reporters the apparent bombshell is â€œa complete non-story.â€ â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re even concerned about here,â€ he said. Johnson denied any knowledge of what transpired between his chief of staff and Mike Penceâ€™s staff, saying he had no idea the falsified election documents had â€œeven been delivered to us.â€ National Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Former NFL Star Tony Siragusa Dies
content: Tony Siragusa, the charismatic defensive tackle who helped lead a stout Baltimore defense to a Super Bowl title, has died. He was 55. Siragusaâ€™s broadcast agent, Jim Ornstein, confirmed the death Wednesday. The cause of death was not immediately available. â€œThis is a really sad day,â€ he said. â€œTony was way more than my client, he was family. My heart goes out to Tonyâ€™s loved ones.â€ Siragusa, known as â€œthe Goose,â€ played seven seasons with the Indianapolis Colts and five with the Ravens. Baltimoreâ€™s 2000 team won the Super Bowl behind a defense that included Siragusa, Ray Lewis and Sam Adams. The Goose,Tony Siracusa has passed away at 55.. Iâ€™m heart broken as is all of Colts Nationâ¤ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ¼ğŸˆ Siragusa was popular with fans because of his fun-loving personality, which also helped him transition quickly to broadcasting after his playing career. Siragusa came to Baltimore as a free agent in 1997 and teamed up with Adams to form an imposing defensive tackle tandem. In the Ravensâ€™ 2000 championship season, the 6-foot-3, 340-pound Siragusa was sixth among Baltimore defenders with 75 tackles. He finished his career with 22 sacks. The news of Siragusaâ€™s death came on what was already a tragic day for the Ravens. The death of Jaylon Ferguson, a linebacker for Baltimore, at age 26 was announced earlier in the day.

topic: Gloria Estefan Shades Jennifer Lopez Over Super Bowl Halftime Comments
content: Reporter, HuffPost Gloriaâ€™s gonna get you. Gloria Estefan had no qualms about poking a little fun at actor-singer Jennifer Lopez during an episode of â€œWatch What Happens Live With Andy Cohenâ€ on Tuesday. During one segment, Cohen asked the Cuban American icon what she thought about the comments Lopez made about the 2020 Super Bowl halftime show, in which she performed with Colombian singer Shakira. In her Netflix documentary â€œHalftime,â€ Lopez complained about the time constraints of having to share the stage, calling it â€œthe worst idea in the world.â€ In response, Estefan told Cohen that she was asked to join Lopez and Shakira on the Super Bowl stage but rejected the offer. â€œLook, this is the bottom line. You have very little time, like 12 minutes or something, to get things on and off the set,â€ Estefan explained. â€œSo, could you do it with one person? Yes, but I think they wanted to throw a Miami and Latin extravaganza, and they tried to pack it as much as possible.â€ And although Estefan said that the women â€œkilled itâ€ and that it was an â€œamazing show,â€ the â€œRhythm Is Gonna Get Youâ€ singer also took the opportunity to throw a little shade at Lopez. â€œOK, and imagine what J.Lo would have said if I was the third [performer]!â€ Estefan said, bugging out her eyes. â€œI literally would come out, done â€˜come on shake your body,â€™ out!â€ Estefan joked, referring to the lyrics of her 1985 Miami Sound Machine hit, â€œConga!â€ Estefan then added that sheâ€™s performed at a few Super Bowls and that Lopez and Shakiraâ€™s show was â€œtheir momentâ€ to shine. â€œPlus, I didnâ€™t want to go on a diet in December,â€ Estefan said. â€œItâ€™s Christmas!â€ Lopezâ€™s complaints about her Super Bowl performance in â€œHalftimeâ€ werenâ€™t directed at Shakira but at the NFL. Lopezâ€™s manager Benny Medina shared his clientâ€™s frustrations over the NFLâ€™s choice of a co-headlining performance. â€œTypically, you have one headliner at a Super Bowl. That headliner constructs a show, and, should they choose to have other guests, thatâ€™s their choice,â€ he said, according to Entertainment Weekly. â€œIt was an insult to say you needed two Latinas to do the job that one artist historically has done.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Andrew Gillum, Former Candidate For Florida Governor, Facing Federal Charges
content:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) â€” Andrew Gillum, the 2018 Democratic nominee for Florida governor, is facing 21 federal charges related to a scheme to seek donations and funnel a portion of them back to him through third parties, the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office announced Wednesday. Gillum, 42, and co-defendant Janet Lettman-Hicks, 53, face 19 counts of wire fraud. Gillum is also charged with making false statements to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office said the pair â€œconspired to commit wire fraud, by unlawfully soliciting and obtaining funds from various entities and individuals through false and fraudulent promises and representations that the funds would be used for a legitimate purpose.â€ Lettman-Hicks then used her company to fraudulently give money to Gillum disguised as payroll payments, the office said in a press release. Itâ€™s the latest trouble for Gillum, who narrowly lost to Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis in a race that required a recount. Gillum served as mayor of Tallahassee before running for governor. In March 2020, Gillum was found intoxicated and unconscious in a hotel room with two men, including one who works as a male escort. Two days later he entered a rehabilitation center, and later did a television interview and said heâ€™s bisexual. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? 
    Hereâ€™s how.

topic: Man Who Filmed Self Screaming His Name In Capitol Riot Sentenced
content: Reporter, HuffPost Former West Virginia state lawmaker Derrick Evans was sentenced to three months on Wednesday for his part in the U.S. Capitol attack last year. Evans had livestreamed himself joining the throng of Donald Trump supporters as some individuals smashed their way into the building and then opened the Rotunda doors for the rest of the mob. He narrated his exploits as he went along, shouting â€œTrump,â€ â€œThe doorâ€™s cracked,â€ and â€œWeâ€™re goinâ€™ in!â€ â€œWeâ€™re in! Derrick Evans is in the Capitol!â€ he said once he made it though the doors. Evans later deleted the video, but it featured prominently in prosecutorsâ€™ case against him. After initially pleading not guilty, defending himself by saying he â€œcommitted no criminal act,â€ Evans took a plea deal. He told Judge Royce C. Lamberth that he accepts responsibility for his actions, seated nearby a large Evans family photo, according to NBC News. Lamberth reportedly wished Evans well, telling him that he considered sentencing Evans to six months behind bars. Evansâ€™ attorney had asked for no jail time. â€œI just canâ€™t give you probation in a case like this ... it doesnâ€™t reflect the feeling in the country,â€ the judge said, according to CBS News reporter Rob Legare. â€œI donâ€™t want another riot in the next election,â€ Lamberth added. At the time of the riot, the father of four had recently been elected to represent West Virginians in the stateâ€™s House of Delegates. Three days later, he was forced to resign. After releasing a very brief statement announcing his resignation, Evans released a second, slightly longer statement expressing regret, writing, â€œI take full responsibility for my actions, and deeply regret any hurt, pain or embarrassment I may have caused my family, friends, constituents and fellow West Virginians.â€ Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Shonda Rhimes Put Abortion On Screen When Few Shows Did. Hereâ€™s What It Took To Get It On TV.
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost This article is part of a larger series titled â€œThe End Of Roe.â€ Head here to read more. By the early 2010s, Shonda Rhimes had created and was running three hit shows on ABC: â€œGreyâ€™s Anatomy,â€ â€œPrivate Practiceâ€ and â€œScandal.â€ In a time when there were just a handful of TV shows that had featured abortion storylines (and often on â€œvery special episodesâ€), all three of her shows depicted abortion matter-of-factly, demonstrating how itâ€™s a part of many peopleâ€™s everyday lives and shouldnâ€™t be so highly stigmatized. On â€œPrivate Practice,â€ OB-GYN and neonatal surgeon Addison Montgomery (Kate Walsh) was both an abortion provider and someone who herself had previously gotten an abortion. And twice on Rhimesâ€™ shows, audiences saw lead characters (and in even more of a rarity, both of them women of color) getting an abortion on prime-time television. In the years since, there has been a marked increase in TV shows that have featured abortion storylines. Yet, even now, these episodes are striking in their clarity and frankness. On â€œGreyâ€™sâ€ in 2011, surgeon Cristina Yang (Sandra Oh) has an abortion, an obvious choice for her as a character. A few years later, in a 2015 episode of â€œScandal,â€ political fixer Olivia Pope (Kerry Washington) gets an abortion that goes virtually unmentioned before or after, like a footnote in the show. Moreover, when being a woman who doesnâ€™t want children still feels like a third-rail issue, both storylines are also significant in their depictions of women who unquestionably do not want children â€” and therefore, are forthright and unwavering in their decision to have an abortion. As Rhimes recalled in an email to HuffPost, there was never a question her shows would portray abortion. â€œI feel strongly that abortion should be portrayed on TV â€” especially on medical shows like â€˜Greyâ€™sâ€™ and â€˜Private Practiceâ€™ â€” even though it is in direct conflict with my own personal experience,â€ said Rhimes, who, in 2017, was named a member of Planned Parenthoodâ€™s national board. â€œPersonally, I would never make the choice to have an abortion, but I would fight for any other womanâ€™s ability to make that choice for herself. That is what choice means. My shows portray the entire spectrum of health. Health includes showing women having agency over their own bodies. And I feel strongly about womenâ€™s health and I truly believe in choice. More people should.â€ Rhimesâ€™ complex road to getting these stories onscreen reflects how thorny and stigmatized abortion was â€” and still is â€” to talk about on TV. It also reflects how the political and cultural pendulum has swung back and forth, with the mounting abortion restrictions in numerous U.S. states over the past few years, which have led up to the impending Supreme Court decision that will likely overturn Roe v. Wade. Abortion first came up on â€œGreyâ€™sâ€ as early as 2005, in the showâ€™s first season, when Cristina discovers she is pregnant. â€œAt that point, abortion seemed like a reasonable choice for a woman of her age, needs and life experience,â€ Rhimes said. At the start of Season 2, Cristina schedules an abortion â€” and coins the now-iconic phrase â€œyouâ€™re my personâ€ when she lists Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) as her emergency contact. A few episodes later, Cristina collapses during a surgery and finds out she is having a miscarriage due to an ectopic pregnancy. ABC executives had anticipated backlash to Cristina getting an abortion, so as a new showrunner on her very first show, Rhimes thought it was best to change the storyline. â€œTo be clear, the network did not object,â€ she said. â€œThey did not tell me that Cristina could not have an abortion. They shared data and told me what they feared the audience reaction would be. And I was a new showrunner. Hell, I was new to TV itself. That episode was, like, the 11th episode of any TV I had ever done in my entire life. I felt insecure about making that controversial choice for my character when I was so new to the game. The network did not change that storyline. I did. I wasnâ€™t ready.â€ But six years later, Rhimes had cemented her reputation and track record as a showrunner and was more than ready to put an abortion storyline on â€œGreyâ€™s.â€ When Cristina finds out sheâ€™s pregnant toward the end of Season 7, thereâ€™s no question she plans to have an abortion. In the final minutes of the Season 8 premiere, Cristina, accompanied by her then-husband Owen (Kevin McKidd), is seen at the start of the procedure. â€œI want to ask you one more time: Are you absolutely sure this is what you want to do?â€ the doctor performing the abortion asks. She nods and turns to Owen, who holds her hand as the procedure begins. â€œBy Season 8, I was sure of myself as a showrunner. I was sure of my place in the TV landscape. Iâ€™d told complex stories about womenâ€™s health through Addison on both â€˜Greyâ€™sâ€™ and â€˜Private Practice.â€™ And I also had spent eight seasons learning more about my character and becoming more sure of who she was and what she wanted,â€ Rhimes said. â€œBoth Cristina and I had grown. I was sure that abortion was the right choice for Cristina and for the show at that point. After all, we were a medical show and this is a medical procedure.â€ Cristinaâ€™s storyline is also uncommonly frank in the way it normalizes women who are sure they donâ€™t want children. In the Season 7 finale â€œUnaccompanied Minor,â€ Owen, who knows Cristina does not want children, nevertheless tries to talk her out of the abortion. He thinks she could change her mind on having children, an argument women who donâ€™t want children are often told. He then portrays it as a compromise for the sake of their marriage. Cristina rightly points out having a kid when you donâ€™t want one isnâ€™t a compromise like choosing between pizza and Thai for dinner. (The show further explores these themes later in Season 8, when Owen ignites an explosive fight about the abortion and their marriage.) In the Season 8 premiere, Meredith, whose domineering and verbally abusive mother resented Meredith for impeding her career, sets Owen straight. â€œDo you know what will happen to Cristina? If she has a kid that she doesnâ€™t want? It will almost kill her. Trying to pretend that she loves a kid as much as she loves surgery will almost kill her, and itâ€™ll almost kill your kid,â€ she tells Owen. â€œDo you know what itâ€™s like to be raised by someone who didnâ€™t want you? I do. To know you stood in the way of your motherâ€™s career? I do. I was raised by a Cristina. My mother was a Cristina. And as the child she didnâ€™t want, I am telling you: Donâ€™t do this to her. Because sheâ€™s kind and she cares, and she wonâ€™t make it. The guilt of resenting her own kid will eat her alive.â€ In 2015, â€œScandalâ€ was once again frank about a woman having an abortion. In some ways, the show went even further than â€œGreyâ€™sâ€ did: Olivia Popeâ€™s abortion was remarkable for being utterly unremarkable. In the holiday episode of Season 5, â€œBaby, Itâ€™s Cold Outside,â€ senator and former first lady Mellie Grant (Bellamy Young) leads a filibuster against a government spending package that would strip federal funding from Planned Parenthood. About two-thirds of the way through the episode, Olivia is watching news coverage of the filibuster, when the camera pans around to reveal sheâ€™s in a medical waiting room. â€œMs. Pope, are you ready to begin?â€ a health care worker asks. During a montage of â€œSilent Night,â€ an overhead light turns on, and Olivia grips the operating table and looks up at the ceiling, as the procedure begins. The abortion isnâ€™t mentioned again until an offhand reference in the Season 5 finale, when Fitz (Tony Goldwyn) tells Olivia: â€œI support your choice â€¦ not that you needed it.â€ The abortion is like a blip in the course of Oliviaâ€™s day. It does not require an explanation or need to be a matter of discussion, reinforcing the message that this is her choice and hers alone. As Young and Rhimes recounted to The Hollywood Reporter in 2017, ABCâ€™s Standards and Practices had strong objections to the extremely brief scene of the procedure and wanted to cut it. â€œI said: â€˜Go ahead, alter the scene. Weâ€™ll just have a lot of articles about how you altered the scene,â€™â€ Rhimes said at the time. Rhimes recalls now that she had girded herself for a protracted battle with network executives, taking steps to preempt their objections. She anticipated there would be pushback to showing the abortion itself, as well as the fact that â€œOlivia choosing not to have Fitzâ€™s child was a powerful statement about womanhood and the rejection of a dangerous fairytale of happily ever after that a lot of people did not know how to handle.â€ â€œThere were lots of phone calls from the network asking me not to do it,â€ she said. â€œI really wanted to show the procedure because I wanted to remove the stigma and fear associated with it. I knew that would be a battle. So we carefully prepared ahead of time. Earlier on the series, we told the story of a woman in the military who had been raped and we showed Olivia holding the military personâ€™s hand as she had an abortion. We got very few notes on that scene and it aired. When it came time to shoot Oliviaâ€™s abortion, we shot it and edited it so that it was basically almost shot for shot the exact same scene. That meant that even though the network objected to the scene, they were unable to change it. Because they had basically already aired that very same scene.â€ Rhimes remembers that â€œevery aspect of that episode was a battle with the network â€” from Mellieâ€™s Planned Parenthood funding filibuster to the use of Aretha Franklinâ€™s â€œSilent Nightâ€ as the source music for Oliviaâ€™s abortion,â€ she said. â€œI have never fought so hard for a â€˜Scandalâ€™ episode.â€ At the time Cristinaâ€™s and Oliviaâ€™s storylines aired, each was lauded as a huge deal, a groundbreaking moment on TV. Since then, the landscape of abortion depictions in pop culture has changed considerably. In 2016, there were just 13 abortion-related plotlines on major scripted shows in the U.S., according to the Abortion Onscreen database, compiled by researchers at Advancing New Standards in Reproductive Health at the University of California, San Francisco. By 2021, there were at least 47 abortion-related plotlines on 42 shows. These can include a character getting an abortion, contemplating one, disclosing a past abortion, or providing support to someone deciding to get an abortion. However, the groupâ€™s research has found that TV still falls short in capturing the full range of abortion stories, whether itâ€™s in the kinds of protagonists (usually white and wealthy), barriers to abortion access, or safe alternatives to the surgical procedure, such as medication abortion, which will become increasingly vital in a post-Roe world. No matter the circumstance, showing a major TV character getting an abortion still feels like a significant cultural moment. Rhimes believes these episodes on her shows would certainly still be a big deal had they been made now, particularly as abortion remains so highly stigmatized and politicized, and the country heads toward a post-Roe landscape. â€œIf you had asked me six years ago, I would have had a different answer. But we are moving backwards so fast on womenâ€™s rights that I obviously think any episodes on abortion would be a big deal now,â€ she said. â€œAnd letâ€™s be clear: Nothing will normalize abortion on TV as long as a womanâ€™s right to choose is not normalized in real life. We all need to stop waiting for TV characters to do the powerful change-making work that we should be requiring of our real-life elected officials.â€ Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: 'Jeopardy!' Contestant Makes Monumentally Bad Guess About Michael Caine
content: â€œBatmanâ€ fans couldnâ€™t â€œget no satisfactionâ€ after one â€œJeopardy!â€ contestantâ€™s blunder. Contestant Mazin Omer gave a wonky answer on Monday when he received a clue featuring a picture of actor Michael Caine, who played Alfred Pennyworth in Christopher Nolanâ€™s â€œBatmanâ€ series. After seeing the photo of Caine, Omer guessed that the actor was Mick Jagger, lead singer of The Rolling Stones. Watch the clip of the â€œJeopardy!â€ goof-up below: Incredible  pic.twitter.com/ThispaiH7E Twitter users joked about the screw-up after it aired on Monday. #jeopardy is on 30 minutes earlier where I live than where my mom lives. Just texted her: Someone is going to say Mick Jagger and you will yell at the TV. The Michael Cain/Mick Jagger response will live on as an historic bad answer. #jeopardy Would watch A Muppets Christmas Carol remake with Mick Jagger. No question. https://t.co/hnJKmZ3Hkf Caine may not have written songs with Keith Richards in his career, however, Jagger has allegedly impersonated Caine in the past. Welsh actor Rob Brydon, in an appearance on â€œThe Graham Norton Show,â€ said Jagger once broke out the impression at a house party. â€œMy wife and I were leaving down the stairs from the first floor, and as weâ€™re headed to door I heard â€˜Rob, Rob,â€™â€ Brydon said. â€œAnd I looked â€˜what, what,â€™ and [Jagger] was on the landing and he was like: â€˜Donâ€™t throw those bloody spears at me.â€™â€ Brydon was confused but later realized Jagger was doing an impression of Caineâ€™s role in â€œZulu.â€ Watch Brydonâ€™s recollection of the Caine impersonation below:

topic: Jennifer Aniston Rocks Courteney Coxâ€™s â€˜Friendsâ€™ Dress She Stole 20 Years Ago
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Jennifer Aniston knows the meaning of timeless style. While getting her hair dolled up by stylist Chris McMillan on Sunday, Aniston showcased more than just her new cut on her Instagram story. She also happened to be sporting the dress she stole from Courteney Cox on the set of the hit show â€œFriendsâ€ over 20 years ago. The actor shared screenshots of Cox in the now-infamous black floral lace dress that Coxâ€™s character Monica originally wore in the 22nd episode of Season 8. â€œDoes the dress look familiar?â€ Aniston jokingly wrote alongside a side-eye emoji. â€œStill got it!â€ McMillan also shared his own image of the dress as he posed with Aniston showing off her new haircut. A post shared by C H R I S M C M I L L A N (@mrchrismcmillan) â€œFriendsâ€ aired on NBC from 1994 to 2004. Last May, the cast gathered for a reunion that premiered on HBO Max. Leading up to the reunion, the cast members told People magazine that they kept mementos from the original set. Aniston admitted to ripping off the aforementioned ageless dress from Cox. â€œI went into her line of clothes and I pulled it out, and I still have it and wear [it] to this day,â€ she shared. â€œIt has tiny little flowers with a black lace V-neck and a little cap sleeve with a little slight ruffle of black lace,â€ the actor explained at the time. â€œI still have it to this day, I still wear it and it fits,â€ she added. Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: The Rockford Peaches Are Back In 'A League Of Their Own' Series Reboot
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Diamonds are a girlâ€™s best friend once again in the forthcoming reboot of â€œA League of Their Own.â€ Amazon gave viewers a first look on Tuesday at the new Rockford Peaches with a teaser for the eight-episode series, which debuts Aug. 12 and is based on the beloved 1992 film of the same name. Abbi Jacobson of â€œBroad City,â€ who co-created the show with Will Graham, leads the cast as Carson Shaw, while ChantÃ© Adams, Dâ€™Arcy Carden, Gbemisola Ikumelo and Roberta Colindrez are among her teammates. Actor Nick Offerman also stars as the teamâ€™s manager, Casey â€œDoveâ€ Porter. Like the movie, the new â€œLeague of Their Ownâ€ is set in 1943, the same year that the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League was created. The womenâ€™s league was formed as Major League Baseball was thrown into crisis mode during World War II, when many male athletes were drafted. Catch the trailer for â€œA League of Their Ownâ€ below. According to press notes, the series differs from its film predecessor by taking â€œa deeper look at race and sexuality, following the journey of a whole new ensemble of characters as they carve their own paths towards the field, both in the league and outside of it.â€ By all accounts, there are some pretty big cleats to fill. Directed by Penny Marshall, the original â€œLeague of Their Ownâ€ starred Geena Davis, Tom Hanks and Madonna and is widely regarded as a classic. Rosie Oâ€™Donnell, who played one of the Rockford Peaches in the film, reportedly will make an appearance on the new series. Appearing on â€œThe Drew Barrymore Showâ€ last year, Jacobson said that the series evokes â€œthe spirit and the joyâ€ of the movie while exploring more of â€œthe realities of what was really going on in 1943.â€ â€œA door opens for a lot of white women and white-passing women that get on the league that we all know from the film,â€ she explained. â€œBut what about the Black women who were not allowed to try out and who had to sort of carve their own path to play baseball? Itâ€™s also a really queer story.â€ Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Samuel L. Jackson Says Finally Getting Oscar 'Wasn't A Big Deal,' Blasts Recent Ceremony
content: Senior Reporter, HuffPost Samuel L. Jackson finally received his first Academy Award last year â€• not that heâ€™s been checking on one over his legendary career. Days before presenting Will Smith with his post-slap statuette, the actor was awarded an honorary Oscar at the Governorâ€™s Awards, which he said ultimately â€œwasnâ€™t a big deal for meâ€ in a recent interview with the Los Angeles Times. â€œI was past it. I was never going to let the Oscars be a measure of my success or failure as an actor,â€ Jackson told the outlet. â€œMy yardstick of success is my happiness: Am I satisfied with what Iâ€™m doing? Iâ€™m not doing statue-chasing movies. You know [whispers]: â€˜If you do this movie, youâ€™ll win an Oscar.â€™â€ â€œNo, thanks. Iâ€™d rather be Nick Fury. Or having fun being Mace Windu with a lightsaber in my hand,â€ he added. Jackson was previously honored with a Best Supporting Actor Oscar nomination for his role in Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s â€œPulp Fiction,â€ but the award ultimately went to Martin Landau for â€œEd Wood.â€ Heâ€™s never been nominated for another performance since. The Marvel star said he believes he should have been recognized for at least two other Tarantino projects â€• â€œJackie Brownâ€ and â€œDjango Unchainedâ€ â€• describing the latter film as his â€œbest shotâ€ for winning a trophy. â€œItâ€™s the most evil character Iâ€™ve ever played and they generally reward Black people for playing horrendous sâ€”,â€ he said. But Oscar-bait roles havenâ€™t been whatâ€™s driven Jacksonâ€™s career so far. Heâ€™d much rather be known for starring in projects that â€œmade me want to go to the movies when I was a kid.â€ â€œIâ€™m satisfied because thatâ€™s who I am. Iâ€™m the guy who does the lines that people see on T-shirts,â€ he said. â€œThereâ€™s actors who go their whole careers and no one can quote a line theyâ€™ve said in a movie.â€ â€œPeople go to watch my movies to see how crazy Iâ€™m going to be or see how many times I say motherfâ€”,â€ he added. â€œWhatever gets them in the seats.â€ His less-than-favorable opinion of the ceremony was only further soured by this yearâ€™s show, which left him a â€œlittle tickedâ€ over a truncated tribute to the late Hollywood icon Sidney Poitier. â€œThe greatest actor we had in Hollywood died and they gave him, what, 10 fâ€” seconds,â€ Jackson said. â€œThe reason Will Smith won an Oscar is because of this guy. The reason for Denzel [Washington], the reason for me, the reason for Danny [Glover], the reason for everybody is that guy, and he deserves more than 10 fâ€” seconds of your time.â€ Jackson went on to blast the decision to instead give screen time to various athletes who introduced a tribute to James Bond onstage at the ceremony. â€œThey have their show. They have the ESPYs. Go do that,â€ he said. â€œThis is the night Hollywood celebrates fâ€” Hollywood. That thing that we used to have when I was young, watching it and wondering, â€˜What am I going to say when I get mineâ€™ was the glamor of it all, the extravagance, the mystique that is Hollywood. Some of thatâ€™s gone.â€ Jackson recently appeared in the Apple TV+ limited series â€œThe Last Days of Ptolemy Greyâ€ and will soon make his return to the Marvel universe in two upcoming projects. First, heâ€™ll star in the Disney+ series â€œSecret Invasionâ€ alongside Ben Mendelsohn, Olivia Colman and Emilia Clarke, before reuniting with Brie Larson in the upcoming Captain Marvel sequel â€œThe Marvels,â€ which hits theaters in July 2023. Senior Reporter, HuffPost

topic: New Doc Examines 'Carol' Author Patricia Highsmith's Complex Love Life
content: Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost Author Patricia Highsmith achieved global fame with 1950â€™s â€œStrangers on a Trainâ€ and 1955â€™s â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripley,â€ but a new documentary reveals her private life to have been even more multifaceted than her novels. Filmmaker Eva Vitija pored over many of Highsmithâ€™s personal notes and diaries for â€œLoving Highsmith.â€ The film, which will be screened at the 2022 Provincetown International Film Festival in Provincetown, Massachusetts, this week ahead of a planned wider release, is a compelling look at Highsmithâ€™s romantic relationships with women during her lifetime. A Texas native, Highsmith spent much of her adult life in Europe, settling in Switzerland. She died in 1995 at age 74, just four years before â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripleyâ€ was adapted into a smash movie starring Matt Damon and Jude Law. The author drew heavily from her own life while writing 1952â€™s lesbian romance â€œThe Price of Salt,â€ which was published under a pseudonym, Claire Morgan. In 1990, the book was republished as â€œCarol,â€ this time under Highsmithâ€™s name. The book was the basis for the 2015 film starring Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara. Catch the â€œLoving Highsmithâ€ trailer below. â€œLoving Highsmithâ€ features interviews with several of Highsmithâ€™s surviving girlfriends, and paints the author as a somewhat divisive figure in the queer literary canon. She is believed to have viewed homosexuality as a psychological defect and often mixed homoeroticism with homicide, most notably in â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripley.â€ â€œPatrica Highsmith was a child of her time. And she wasnâ€™t fighting for gay rights,â€ Vitija told Variety in April. â€œFor her, love is such a brutal experience that extinguished her as a person that it is an experience of death, so murder is never far. In the love-scenes of â€˜Carolâ€™ and how she describes them, death is always around the corner.â€ Still, Vitija emphasizes that Highsmithâ€™s â€œwildly romantic and poetic sideâ€ is the focal point of her film. â€œIt was a Patricia Highsmith completely different from the one I was reading about in biographies or mainly articles in newspapers,â€ she said. The Provincetown International Film Festival will screen â€œLoving Highsmithâ€ this Thursday and Saturday. Other highlights of the five-day event, which runs from Wednesday to Sunday, include the Sundance Audience Award winner â€œCha Cha Real Smoothâ€ and the gay romantic comedy â€œFire Island,â€ starring Joel Kim Booster and Bowen Yang. Organizers say the festival will also showcase local filmmakers like Todd Flaherty, whose dark comedy â€œChrissy Judyâ€ will have its world premiere Thursday. Senior Culture Reporter, HuffPost
